description:
Yuet Lee is quite a force to be reckoned with, and made famous by celebrities within the USA, those visiting from Hong Kong, members of the food and beverage industry (especially the Canto types), and how can we forget the stoner munchie drunk and high AF clubbers (or the party animals amongst us who don't take it to the next level like that, but have had quite a few drinks) who need to binge and purge a little bit and then force some killer grub down the pipes in hopes of soaking up the alcohol and who know the F what flowing through one's veins after such activities. Somehow YL comes to the rescue for all of the above crowd and hits the right notes with their food, like Stan Getz and Antonio Carlos Jobim serenading their lesser known Bossanova classic with noblimente, "The greasy stir fry from Ipanema".

In any case, no excuses are needed really to come here. You could even have a mediocre meal at say, Michelin Star Mister Jiu's, and feel that you need some blue collar Cantonese "izakaya" style delights in order to send you home more satisfied.

There's so much going on in the menu here. For best results, get well versed in the Dark Side of the Cantonese food force. And figure out what they do well, quickly.

Quick, fast, hot food is the order of business here. So get dishes that focus on intense wok stir fry (or if deep fry is your thang) and have a chit ton of flavor. The magical combinations of grease, intensity of the wok sear and heat, and umami together (from the soy sauce and other ingredients) will create some magical chemical reactions that send your brain roaring and yearning for more. And if you already have enough alcohol in your system, so much the better!

I don't know what it is, but seriously, alcohol makes the food taste better here. Especially if it is already in your system. But you are more than welcome to start sober, then down a few ice cold beers during dinner and see for yourself if it gets gradually better (or try a meal here without any alcohol in your system or during dinner).

Tried so far:

Singapore stir fried rice noodles - it's not bad, and if you have the munchies this works nicely

Soy sauce supreme fried noodles - it's a decent rendition during the late hour, and is almost always a de facto dish that needs to be tried if you have quite a bit of seafood and need some carbs at the end (instead of a fried rice)

Beef chow fun (dry fried) - A touch greasy but the remainder of the plate has no excess pool of disgust. A very notable and worthy rendition and the wok sear is intense and so aromatic, when you eat it right away (hint, don't let it sit!). Every strip of rice noodle (ho fun) is coated beautifully with the soy sauce. For better results, add a little chili sauce for some acidity, bit of a kick, and cutting the grease.

Sweet and sour pork (I believe the sauce is made with sour plum of some sort) - it's a very interesting prep where it is a touch saucy, and is very different than the typical ketchup pineapple vinegar version. It works but it's not the greatest

Peking spareribs - this one is actually far superior. There is actually some complexity in the orange themed marinade and the wok stir fry sear intensifies that quite a bit. Much better than the sweet and sour pork. Grease is goodness here.

Pork belly, fermented shrimp paste and tofu clay pot 大馬站煲 - the control of the savory, the umami, and the aromatics is pretty intense with this. Fermented shrimp paste can be overpowering but they did it right here. The addition of chives really brings it all together. The tofu is the star here, surprisingly. 

No doubt other stir fry classics like ones involving crab, or salt pepper squid are requirements here. But don't be afraid to venture a bit further out, and get out of the Panda Express Moo Shoo Poo Poo Doo Doo side...it seems the YL galaxy is a bit wider and versatile than previously thought...
author: Ken K.

description:
We came to eat to this place cause they were open late. 

We arrived at 1.35 ordered a small wonton soup for almost 9$ had no flavor. Also had a chicken and rice i did not like that either. 

I wanted vegetables with meat, this was chicken bok choi recommended, i but it had no much vegetables and again no flavor, was gross. 

For a coke, the small soup and dish chicken dish we payed almost 30$ without tip. 

This restaurant was a real bad choise should have had a pizza instead.
author: Andrea T.

description:
I'm on my way to trying every Chinese restaurant in the area, so these comments/notes are more for me to remember my experience.

This restaurant is a little touristy and is more expensive compared to some of the hole-in-the-wall restaurants in the area. It has a bunch of pictures on the wall of celebrities that have visited and dishes range from $10 - $13 each.

I was with a non-Chinese friend, so ordered some generic items. The Beef Chow Fun was delicious and had a great wok flavor. The second dish we got was beef with broccoli - I know, not super authentic, but the Chinese Broccoli was well cooked and the sauce was decent. I would come back for the Chow Fun, but not the beef with broccoli though. Not a standout dish.
author: Christina L.

description:
Hands down the best Chinese broccoli & chow mein I've had a lot had and I have had a lot!
Atmosphere- don't expect much
Service- do not have expect much
Good- oh my! I can't remember sit to go back and try more!!!
-The Chinese broccoli  was prepared perfectly and had this fantastic charred/ meat flavor to it.
-The cho mein.... Gosh I don't know what to say other than perfect. You MUST go there and try it your self!
Loud & totally family friendly expect I'm not sure if they have high chairs.
Enjoy!
author: Ashley G.

description: Located on the corner where there is no parking. This has been on tv with food celebs eating here. Park at the parking lot up the street where the police department is. The service was great they seated me right away and gave me some suggestions. I ordered the wanton soup, great Wanton with pork and shrimp mixed inside, the soup is light and allows the wanton be the center of the attention. The beef chow fun was well flavored and meat very tender, my favorite and I ordered the boneless chicken with kungpow sauce, slight spicy with more veggies and little bit of chicken. The dish needed rice with it and you need to order it separate. Over good authentic chinese food.
author: Thomas K.

description:
I haven't been here in ages, but Yuet Lee has certainly been around in SF Chinatown for ages.  Correctly or incorrectly, I've always associated it with being more of a tourist-centric spot. This time, I was invited by a friend to join her and her mother, both of whom have great taste in Cantonese cuisine, and was pleasantly pleased with our meal.

Definitely Get:  The whole steamed fish, simply, but deliciously prepared with ginger, green onions and cilantro.  It's my favorite method of preparation, and it was executed flawlessly.  Moist, tender, flaky.  I could eat this everyday, seriously.

We also had a veggie, which I don't know the English or Chinese name to, but it's in my picture, and it belongs within the cauliflower family.  It's something that isn't on many menus that I've seen, and it was done well.

The deep fried tofu itself was good, but I didn't care for the sauce that topped it.  I'm not into sauces at all, and the tofu would've certainly held its own sans any sauce of any kind.

The salt and pepper calamari was good, and is a dish listed as one of their specialties.  I probably would venture trying other dishes before doing a repeat of this.

They also serve lobster, which looked really darn good! So good that I'm tempted to return simply to get that.  I believe it was approximately $35.00/lb., which isn't at all bad, given that it would easily be twice as much in a haute restaurant.  

No ambiance to speak of.  No thrills, no frills, basic hole in the wall place, with corresponding service, but good food, if you select correctly, at a very good price point.
author: Lori N.

description:
This will get you off the paleo diet quickly. The noodles are laced with crack that will keep you dreaming about them days after, plotting your return to this secret house of flavor. The late-night seeker of sustenance will count himself lucky if he happens to stumble upon this noodley siren-call station.

I love their family-style service and attitude. It's the perfect Chinese Diner feel for Chinatown, and yes, they are open late! As a former New Yorker, I deeply appreciate any food-serving establishment open past 12, as most of them close by then, or earlier, at least in the Chinatown district.

I've heard there's an early bird discount on weekdays. They also have very generous portion sizes. Needless to say, with the new laws, you might consider this as a post 4:20 PM field trip. This will answer the munchie craving better than any bag of fritos. Proceed at your own risk, however, for your taste buds will never settle for an old, dry, crunchy snack again when you could be eating from the succulent dishes at Yuet Lee. Yes, you will have FOMO every time you don't eat here from now on. At least where munchies are concerned. Be warned.
author: Viv R.

description:
Omg 

1. Please try the seafood soup : this is one of the dishes that they're known for. The broth was light and clean. Soup came with fat chunks of fish, squid, shrimp, and bok chuy. So dang good especially with soy sauce and jalapeños added 

2. Salt and pepper squid : the best. The best , the best. Perfect balance of salt and seafood my god this is good. If you love fried calamari please try this dish they're known for. Make sure you dip the squid in the jalapeno salt sauce they bring you. 

3. House chow Mein : also good. Skinny noodles. I always add the chili sauce . Yum 

Apparently some of the 49ers have eaten here. Locals love it. You wont have to deal with tourists and still get quality Chinese food:
author: Mariana D.

description: I actually been coming to this place for about 20 yrs. it's very authentic and the food I get is always delicious. I never leave dissatisfied. It's right in china town which is nice. The service isn't the worst , there is a little language barrier but that's ok. That makes the experience even better in my opinion. I will continue to come to this gem of mines in beautiful SF!
author: Al C.

description: I went to this place several/many times about 15-20 years ago. Decided to take my son to show him Chinatown and take him to an old FAV. I was not impressed with the food. Maybe I set my expectations too high; maybe I've been exposed to more high quality food since I was there last (?). The chicken dish did nothing for us. The green veggies were "eh". The noodles and the sauce over the noodles were still good but the meat was of marginal quality.
author: Richard M.

description: Only mediocre at best. The place might have had notoriety at one time but not anymore. I believe this is a different owner since having Anthony Bourdain, Jackie Chan, Emeril Lagasse, and Guy Fieri. I came here because during lunch it was the only place that was pretty empty and had no wait time. Well, I should have taken that as a hint that it was not good. At lunch time on a Sunday and it's slow and all the other places on Broadway is busy. Hmmm. I had ordered some jook(rice porridge) with sturgeon. The porridge you can tell had gelatin to thicken it up. Not good. I had already had jook yesterday somewhere else in Chinatown and that place had phenomenal jook. (See my review of Yee's Restaurant) I also ordered a simple Chef's special chow mein which had seafood, beef, chicken, and pork. It was decent but I wouldn't come here just for the chow mein. I think anyone who sees the man in the picture with all the celebrities should know that that is a different guy and different owner, cause the food now is not so hot and it would be best to find a busier place to visit in Chinatown.
author: Patrick T.

description: This joint is always crowded with tourists and natives alike. Late night munchies after the club? No problem. Classic Cantonese cooking right in Chinatown. Hot, greasy, and simply authentically delicious. Note to the gwai lo's: if you order a scramble, do it right and ask for it runny - that's what a real Cantonese scramble should be like.
author: Joyce Z.

description: I gave two because the food is not that bad. BUT the service is TERRIBLE! If you want some dining experience, this is not the place for you.
author: Jerry H.

description:
This restaurant is way overpriced for the quality of the food and dirty looking place.

The best thing about this place is that it is open till 1am which is late for SF. We were starving at 1230 so we went here before closing.

We ordered a small chicken wonton soup, chicken with Chinese vegetables and a Coke for $30 before tip. The chicken wonton soup was good. The chicken with Chinese vegetables was not good. The chicken tasted like it was spoiled. The can of Coke cost me $2.50. On top of that they charge you $2.25 for a bowl of rice.

They were putting up the chairs while we were eating and dragging the trash bags through the restaurant. This was not a good dining experience.

We really should have gotten slices of pizza and a Coke at a pizza place. The food would have been better and I would have saved lots of money.
author: Joe L.

description:
Food: Boneless Chicken w/ Mango, Beef Curry over Rice

Review: Food came out in less than 8 minutes, but the quality of it overall was alright. The mango was a little too sweet, and the chicken quantity was small. The beef curry was more quantity wise, but there are better options elsewhere.

Overall: Won't not go back with number of options in Chinatown
author: Tony C.

description:
Food was good and service was good at first. I definitely recommend for the food, but one part of the experience was very disappointing. 

They advertise 15% off during happy hour which was 4:30-6:30. We arrived at 6pm and were done eating around 6:50. Upon making mention of the discount the lady attempted to tell us we arrived after 6:30. She attempted to dispute when I made mention that we had arrived around 6pm.

Fortunately the manager came over and fixed the situation before I had to present the time stamped photo we took in front of the restaurant at 6pm.

Everything else was good but this small act of dishonesty.
author: Terrance S.

description:
Anthony Bourdain loves this place for a reason.  Service is sh$t but in my opinion this place is the best late night chinese grubbing spot at 2am.  You can Get all the classics within minutes.  I've eatin at places like these in philly and New York and this place is up there in terms of flavor and authenticity.  
Soy sauce chicken, sweet and vinegar pork chops, sautéed chinese veggies (skip the chow fun). 


Food 4
Service 2
Overall 4
author: Patrick C.

description:
Great little hole in the wall. We had prawns and porridge both delicious!
Fast service too. Would go again.
author: Marija M.

description: We've been coming to this place for years a regular spot, the owners and wait staff are really friendly they do the food according to our preferences, great place to eat after bar hopping
author: Anjana P.

description:
This place sucks.  With all the great Chinese food around, I don't know why I stumbled into this sad, smelly, dirty and inhospitable place.

Food was bland and lacked flavor but the service is what really blew my mind.  Upon paying my bill, I was physically stopped at the front door while a balding man yelled "you have to leave more tip!"  

Fuck this joint, don't believe the celebrity photos from the 90's on the walls.
author: Ian R.

description:
The Two of us always order the same two dishes here at Yuet Lee for the last 30 years, We think no one makes them better. They are delicious and they make a perfectly satisfying delicious meal.

Salt and Pepper Calamari 
Always crisp, and never greasy, 
The batter is pale, perfectly fried because the oil is at the right temperature. We like the lemon to squeeze on every last drop on the calamari. 
The calamari comes with a dip of Chinese vinegar and sliced jalapeño which is so tasty and addicting.

Beef Chow Fun 
The Chow Fun at Yuet Lee has the best wok flavor of any chow fun around we don't think any one cooks it better. The Chow Fun has the perfect  ratio of meat to noodles sprouts and veggies. The noodles are always perfectly done never gluey.
author: Joseph M.

description: I just had a wonderful meal of chicken Chow Mien noodles. Good affordable food is hard to find. I found it here.
author: Benjamin T.

description:
Came here for an early dinner for a work dinner before going to watch Beach Blanket Babylon. We got seated in the big round table. I wish I can tell you what food we ordered but since one of us knew the owner, they just kept on bringing food to us. All we requested was salted fish fried rice and chow mein. My coworker requested walnut shrimp but of course they didn't have it. They gave us this fillet fish dish that was realllly good. It looked bland but it tasted really flavorful. That was my fave. The ones we specifically ordered (fried rice and chow mein) was my least favorite.
Not the best restaurant I've been to but definitely a go when in the area.
author: Claire J.

description:
Tofu seafood...Tofu clay pot are very good..but don't recommend roast duck or boiled chicken.
Too many bones..little bit of meat  ....but the sauce is good.vegetables are ok. Service is ok.please check your bill since they already included the tips
author: Supawat J.

description:
Their Beef Chow Fun is amazing!! The noodles are so fresh I mean gummy good fresh! I would have taken a photo to show how amazing it tasted, but all gone! 

FYI use their takeout chopsticks with caution. Those things will give you splinters.
author: Amy T.

description:
I'll try to make this short. Overall I give it a three. 
Food: 3/5  nothing to special
Presentation: 3/5 they could use an upgrade on their plates
Restaurant: 3/5
Staff: 3/5 they kept waiting at our table when we needed more time to order, but I didn't mind it too much. 

What I ordered:
1. Beef chow fun dry: it was pretty good compared to the other restaurants in the area. The beef was juicy and soft. I ended up ordering two orders of this
2. Half a Peking duck: Since the Peking duck is left hanging by the stove they had to reheat it in the oven. This made the duck dry. 
3. BBQ pork fried rice: I like the pork here. I have had this dish at other places. Many restaurants end up making the pork really dry and you don't even tase the barbecue flavor. I felt this dish was well seasoned. 
4. Beef chow mein: This dish was mediocre. I have tasted better. There was a lack of flavor in my opinion. 
5. Braised tofu: nothing special here. Wasn't bad nor good. 
6. Chinese broccoli and oyster sauce: it is hard to mess this dish up. The broccoli was crunchy, as they should be.
author: Amy T.

description:
Has been my go to since 2009 after a night out. This place hasn't really changed. Simple, fast Cantonese style service. Don't expect it to have the typical American service style. They don't bs around here! 

You sit, you order, you eat, then leave because you're taking up a table haha

Got the salty fish and chicken fried rice, Chinese broccoli and clam with black sauce. Yum!!!
author: Miyouko W.

description:
I ordered Yuet Lee through Postmates and the food arrived pretty fast. 

I was craving for some savory dish so I tried their Chicken with Black Bean sauce dish. I personally really liked it--not oily; the dish itself was super flavorful; the ingredients were pretty fresh. In addition, a bonus--everything at Yuet Lee was really affordable. 

I will definitely order it again from Yuet Lee in the future.
author: Clare L.

description: We had a great time. Noodles, soup, beef, pork, clams. All good. Unlimited rice. Consistent following on service. Great times
author: Chisung L.

description:
Absolutely love!!!

This is a must come!!!

Hands down the best Chinese food I have ever tasted in my life.
author: Letty H.

description: This place is awesome! Idk why people have low marks. Seafood is super fresh. Service is great! One of the best spots in Chinatown for good food.
author: Elin D.

description: This is one of the best Cantonese restaurants in SF, and the service was faster than any other restaurant at dinner time. We ordered a soup, a fried noodle and a fried octopus. We waited no longer than 3 minutes on the fried noodle and the soup. Food was really decent according to my HK friend. When we asked for the to-go box, it didn't take them more than 1 minute to box the left food up. I would highly recommend this site if you want to visit downtown SF and maybe take a walk at China town and grab something to eat.
author: Ula C.

description:
When you find a good, reliable hole-in-the-wall restaurant you stick to it. For me, Yuet Lee is one of those places: delicious, authentic food in a no frills setting. It's fast and it's affordable as well. 
I've been coming to Yuet Lee on and off for about 10 years now - it's a definite every time I visit. (You also know it's good when taxi drivers make a bee line for their fried rice at 1am.)
I love their salt and pepper calamari,  the shrimp with scrambled egg and their fried rice. Servings are fairly generous as well. 
If you dine early on weekdays there's often an early bird discount (although it's closed Tuesday's).
author: Bernard O.

description: This my go to Chinese restaurant in town for the past twenty years. The seafood is the freshest and the best you can find. Traditional Cantonese cuisine was in a non fashionable location that only offers the best food in town.
author: Bill B.

description: Be aware! The restaurant charged me 20%tips on the bill.  5 bucks for two people rice.
author: Jiaqi L.

description: Great authentic cantonese food! Servers were super friendly too. Ordered chow fun with beef, a soup, and a fried squid. Exceptional qualities. But the place is slightly pricier than the other chinese places in the area in china town.
author: King W.

description: Tall waiter slammed our receipt down after we gave a 17% tip when we only had our water filled once. Never coming back. Be happy it wasn't a 10% tip.
author: Matt F.

description:
So good! Service was great,  food was fast, hot and delicious!! 
Mongolian Beef and shredded chicken chow mein was yummy!!
author: Crissy C.

description:
This restaurant is about three hours away and it is completely worth the drive, evertime. Staff is friendly and the food is a taste you can not get anywhere else.  Fried calamari, house chow mein with crispy noodles, pork & oyster clay pot, braised (any) vegetable,  and pork fried rice are all staples.  Duck is great, though I did not order it this trip.  Flounder is the new adventure on this trip, and I'm glad I was aboard.  

Eat at a table with a lazy susan and order family-style with family and/or friends. Affordable for a group.
author: Noëlle M.

description:
Late night ... famished...I know I'm not truly starving; but it feels like it! Craving Asian comfort with spice.
It's been ages since I've been to Yuet Lee. First of all I am truly grateful this place exists and feeds hungry drunk folks all night long til almost 3AM. The good is decent. It's San Francisco after all. It's just not great! I had the Hot spicy seafood combo with soft tofu in clay pot . It was more like lightly spiced soft tofu clay pot with a little seafood swimming in the tofu. The flavor was just ok. A solid ok.
author: Suzi C.

description:
Ordered beef chow fun - yum $11.99

Plenty of flavor and evenly coated noodle with lots of onions and sprouts for crunch

Good amount of beef, beef was tender and flavorful 

Resturante was decent for the location, service was fast and friendly.  

Can't wait to try other dishes.  Will update
author: Jason M.

description:
Food.  5 stars 

Value.    5 stars

Service.  5 stars 

Cleanliness.  3 stars 

If you're ever in San Francisco Chinatown you have to try this restaurant located on the corner of Broadway and Stockton.  

Tip ...   this place specializes in seafood. 

However, I also like their Beef with ginger and green onions.
author: Edward M.

description: Besides Shanghai dumpling this is the other best Chinese in the city! The table service isn't flowery, but it's efficient. Flavors are authentic and delicious. I don't think they use MSG because I've never had any issues, but you'll have to ask.
author: Eyla C.

description: First of all the menu prices on yelp are much lower than the actual prices when you pick up your food. I ordered the Chefs Chow Mien for $9.25 when I picked up my food I received a bill for $13.75 and when told the lady she called the manager who basically told me to get out in a very rude tone. AVOID THIS PLACE LIKE YOUR LIFE DEPENDS ON IT!!!!!!!!
author: Kharey R.

description:
Iconic San Francisco Chinatown late night establishment.
Back in the days this is where everyone ate after clubbing on Friday's & Saturdays.
Used to be open to 4 am, now only to 2 am. 
Not much has changed except the closing hours and the prices. 
Basically your coming here for several dishes:
1. Salt and pepper calamari 
2. Ginger onion crab
3. Black bean clams
4. Salted fish fried rice
5. Boiled prawns. 
Throw down some Tsingtao's, it will be a good night 
! If you want good service , don't eat in Chinatown.
author: Dub C.

description:
Yuet Lee was once considered the best spot for Chinese food in San Francisco. But this was also 20-30 years ago before the explosion of Chinese dim sum/seafood restaurants into the South SF scene. Now Yuet Lee is a destination for Chinatown tourists and Anthony Bourdain's television fans. 

It's true that Yuet Lee does not close at 3am anymore, they close at midnight actually. We arrived here at 11:40pm but the staff allowed us to dine in despite the kitchen closing at 11:45pm. The staff was quite friendly to us despite our late arrival. We were never rushed out from the restaurant, though they did warn us they would be cleaning up while we ate. 

We ordered the parsley with minced pork porridge and the beef & egg rice noodle dish. Both entrees were very good. I liked the flavor that the minced pork brought into the porridge, no soy sauce necessary! The chicken rice noodle dish was not greasy at all and tasted delicious. While this was not necessarily the best Chinese food I have had, Yuet Lee definitely serves up  better and fresher food than many of the other competitor restaurants around Chinatown!

I can find myself here again if I need a healthy fix of Chinese food. But if you are looking for late night Chinese eats, you might have to head down the street to New Sun Hong Kong Restaurant.
author: Philip M.

description: Kitchen was super super fast , and food was awesome !! I ordered the pork kidney and crab and clam . They were all delicious! Especially the clam !!! Restaurant was clean and the restroom was clean too . Service was so so . But I definitely will come back next time .
author: Jessie H.

description:
I can honestly say I was born here, my mother has been coming here for over 30+ years and we have never been disappointed. The sizzling chicken in a clay pot....ORGASMIC!!! Lol. The garlic prawns are amazing. The only thing you can say negative about this place is, it isn't the greatest location as it's in the red light district of San Francisco, but every bite makes up for that. When you go just don't take my word for it but look at the walls of continuous attendance of celebrities. 

Cheers
author: Darrell C.

description: Terrible service and overpriced dishes. Had their seafood combo hot pot and was good at all. Apparently soups of any kind or entrees doesn't come with rice. It'll have to be ordered separately. Will definitely not be eating here again. Don't let those pictures of the chief with famous people fool you. Will definitely not be eating here again.
author: Fodang L.

description:
It is a good, but not amazing spot in Chinatown for authentic Chinese food. The beef chow fun is very good. My friend, who is not Chinese, ordered the Kung Pao chicken. It definitely has a kick to it. One of my favorite things in a Chinese restaurant is congee. Unfortunately, I was very disappointed by the congee at Yuet Lee. It was too watery and I could not eat much of it. The restaurant is a little more expensive than most. For example, the congee I ordered was almost double the price I normally pay for it in New York.

If you are visiting San Francisco and looking for recommendations, feel free to message me through Yelp and I can share my itinerary, which includes my Yelp reviews. The information for an electronic copy can also be found in the link via my Yelp profile.
author: Patrick W.

description:
Service was so so, kitchen was super fast, 
We had cashew prawns (good) and bbq pork chow mein (great). We also had hot tea which was served in plastic cups (very odd).

Overall would recommend but not worth a special trip to us.
author: Caitlin A.

description: If and when you try this place, order Their curry beef. It is to die for. I love how well it was seasoned. Not too spicy. So delicious.
author: Summer M.

description: Everything is good until they calculate the tips for us and left us no choice to pay that amounts...
author: 安

description:
I have been here once years ago in the middle of the night so I know that this place opens late. And I came here again for dinner recently confirmed that they open till 3AM!!!

I had the fried garlic shrimp with chow mein. It was delicious but on the salty side. We also had the salt and pepper squid and that was made perfectly! It was lightly batter and not over fried!

The decor is very old school and photos line the wall but we are here for the food right?! Food is great, decor is on the run down side!
author: Tiffany C.

description:
First time here. Ordered the ginger n green onion crab along with their spicy garlic prawns. 
.
Spicy Garlic Prawns.  
Wow ! One of the best I've had in a long time. Good amount nice sized prawns. Tons of garlic n seasoning has a great aftertaste. Garlic, Spices n Sweetness at the end. Beautiful dish.  Loved it.
.
Ginger n Green Onion Crab
Crab was fresh. It was okay nothing special. I wouldn't recommend buying it at the seasonal price of $44 like I did.
.
Overall,
Loved it. Prawns were amazing.  Will go back just for that alone.
author: Hungry K.

description: Found this gem after checking out the overrated China Live which is only a few doors down. We weren't hungry but ended up deciding to have an early dinner here. We got enticed by the celebrity photos and thought it must be good. We weren't wrong! Had chow mein, singapore noodles, salt and pepper pork chops, half order of roast duck, and garlic shrimp. All were very good and better than average. I'd say the shrimp was the highlight though. Not the most cleanly or charming place, very casual but worth the money.
author: Lizzie L.

description: We discovered on our trip to San Francisco that Chinatown shuts down around 5:30pm! But thus place is still open and has alot of character!
author: Bethany V.

description: It was our first day in SF and my family and I had not ate since our arrival and people in the restaurant seemed to enjoy their food. This food seemed somewhat new to us so we all went in to ask the waitress for a menu. After a minute or so of looking at any dish that could have been appetizing, the cook/host comes out and asks us what the problem is and before we can explain that we were simply looking at the menu, in an immature way he yells "Bye" repeatedly as he guides us to the exit kicking us out of the restaurant. It somewhat made our trip sour.
author: Liz M.

description: Really nice large portions of noodles. The seafood is super fresh especially the shrimp, scallops and crab. The ginger green onion beef is also very good and the staff is efficient. The atmosphere is a bit cheesy and touristy but who cares.
author: Nina L.

description:
Friends and I would stumble in here a lot after club nights. It is pretty expensive but the food comes out quick, hot, and it is consistent. 

Over the times I've been here I always get porridge since it is comfort food to me. And it helps with drinking. I'd say you only remember it if it is bad since porridge is one of those things that should never be messed up I'd say. One day I'll try other versions of porridge rather than pork and preserved egg though I still always hope they'll make a tofu version of it at some point. 

Aside from that this last time I had gotten a spicy seafood and soft tofu claypot. The spiciness wasn't as spicy as I thought it would be but the tofu kept consistency and the flavors were there.

Again a bit expensive. But it is open late. I figure if I can spend 10-12 bucks on a drink at a club, honestly this isn't that bad considering haha.
author: David C.

description: We ordered the duck for an appetizer, it tastes like whale blubber. The waiter became physically violent when he saw my tip. Let's just say Yuet Lee is one of the 15 most slimiest restaurants in SF. The Chow mein reminded me of the little worms I would see in gutters at grade school after winter storms. Yuet Lee is a storm, a very scary storm.
author: Elijah C.

description:
Like others have mentioned before me, the service and tip policy at this place are absolutely horrendous. They do 'force' you to leave a certain amount of gratuity despite being basically MIA the entire time, or being super rude when they do actually give you attention (I really don't know what's worse). The place is also very dingy and truthfully the only reason that I or anyone else goes here is mere convenience as it is open late and the location is close to where I live. 

The food itself is decent at best and oftentimes I question the quality or origin of some of the meat being used since some of it has a really gross chewy texture. Given how cheap they are about their tip policy, I wouldn't put it past them to partake in sourcing some sort of domestic animal or rodent just to save a few bucks. The kicker is that the food is also pretty expensive especially for what it is. 

I usually go for Elaine's Kitchen down the street for my Chinese comfort food needs - the food and service are leaps and bounds ahead of this place, and the prices are much more reasonable for the quality and quantity of food (especially their weekday lunch special which can't be beat). Unfortunately, Elaine's is only open until 10pm so only pure desperation will ever bring me back to Yuet Lee ever again... And even then, I may just settle for Panucho's or Golden Boy if it comes to late night munchies.
author: Jonah L.

description: We loved this place! If you want a place that has been around with some local flavor, then this is the place for you! Located in San Francisco's China Town, we found it because our first choice was too crowded but we are glad that we came here! We ordered a fish dish, beef chow fun, & sizzling pork! All of the food was so good that we had no leftovers! The staff was nice and patient when we ordered and asked questions! An over all great experience! When I told my friend, a local San Franciscan, that we came here, he proclaimed that it was visited by Anthony Bourdain as well! A great find.
author: Shelly S.

description:
Very casual....do not dress up!!
Located at the heart of Chinatown....easy to get to and great walk to, North Beach where Italian  section of the city, for a coffee.
I always have plain rice porridge, steamed shrimps, clams with black bean sauce and garlic.
They will give you finger bowl after eating shrimps with your fingers.
author: sola T.

description: Smaller place with a tiny old bathroom, but still better than most other China town eateries. Love the friendly customer service, food is yummy especially their salt and pepper!
author: Angela H.

description:
The only times I've ended up at Yuet Lee have been after a night of bar-hopping in the immediately surrounding area, and craving something carb-y and delicious for late-night drunk munchies. Yuet Lee does provide well for that, but I wouldn't come here for a regular meal.

THE GOOD.
+ Varied menu with food that comes out quite fast
+ Cash/card accepted
+ Open til 3 am

THE MEH.
- Food is average (although if you're inebriated, it's amazing)
- It's kind of a divey-restaurant (didn't even know a restaurant could BE a dive)

It's a very specific circumstance that would bring me back, basically.
author: Claire S.

description:
This place sure seems popular and comes highly rated.  As always I think I ordered the wrong thing (story of my life), but what I ordered was pretty decent.  I'm a noodle whore so not quite sure why I didn't order something with noodles, but of course when I saw the table behind us with noodle dishes (and me with a full belly) I was pretty sad.
We found street parking within 1/2 a block.  I was metered at 25 cents for 6 minutes so 2.50 per hour... kind of steep, but this place is efficient and quick so unless you're going to wander after you probably won't need more than 45 min.
Some things seemed high others seemed reasonable.  One table ordered a live crab which was huge, brought to his table and shown to him before it being prepared.  This is a hole in the wall place, as with most in chinatown, but I think that's where you get the best meals (if you don't order the wrong thing).
author: Kelley S.

description:
In a sea of dim sum and bakeries, this traditional Cantonese-style sitdown restaurant is a godsend.

Walking through Chinatown, my wife and I wanted a place where we could sit down and have a quality Chinese meal after walking up the hills of San Francisco for more than an hour. This place couldn't have fit the bill any better.

I was just a tourist, so I'm not sure what people are talking about regarding this not being one of the best restaurants in San Fran's Chinatown. All I experienced was lightning fast service and excellent Cantonese-style cooking. I had the Roast Pork Chow Mein and it hit the spot. It was made in a matter of minutes and it tasted just like how I'd expect, coming from New York and its Chinatowns.

If you're looking for a traditional sit down Chinese restaurant where you can order a nice big dish to enjoy, this is it.
author: Kevin F.

description:
This is a late review but I was here on January 1, 2016.  One of my first meal of the year! My buddy from Seattle and I fell upon this place using Yelp and we were in Chinatown.  There were various restaurants that were not open due to it being new year.  

We walked into this restaurant not knowing what to expect.  It was fairly busy but we got seated right away.  As we browsed the menu, it had a large selection of food.  We ordered a fish soup, beef chow fun and duck.  We got our food in less than 10 minutes.  That was the quickest service that I ever got in a restaurant.  The food was great.  The soup was very herbal and healthy like how my mom makes it at home.  The chow fun was not overly greasy and had the right amount of flavor.  Duck was authentic.  The cost was also reasonable as well.  

The restaurant was small and a bit clustered.  So it was very loud.  If you don't like tight space with the sound of woks in the kitchen and people chattering 5 feet away from you then you won't like it here.  I didn't mind it too much.  

I would definitely come back here when I'm in town.
author: Xai L.

description:
The decor?  Kinda awful.  You come here for the food.
The service?  Hit or miss.  Get the owner if you can.  He's the best.
The food?  Solid.

No frills, bare bones, & wonderfully divey.  I hadn't been in in a really long time, but this was one of THE SPOTS back in the day.  And they've got the celebrity pics to prove it.  Nicolas Cage was a regular.

I found that while it wasn't as good as it used to be, it's still solid solid.  There were 8 of us, so we got the big group table in the middle, w the lazy susan.  We ordered about 10 dishes...

The scrambled eggs w beef.
Fish in black bean sauce.
The Peking spare ribs.
Beef w broccoli.
The salt & pepper pork.
Mongolian Beef.
Fried rice.
House chow mien.
The salt & pepper squid.
Wonton soup...

I think I'm forgetting something...

I tried almost everything, except the egg & beef dish.  It's just not for me.  My favorite?  The Peking spare ribs.  Delicious.  The chow mien was good & appropriately greasy.  Same for the fried rice.  Everyone was happy.

The place is an institution.
It also happens to be one of the favorite restaurants of Mr. Bist, the owner of the Amber India empire.

That's saying something, right?

And the love from Bruce Lee doesn't hurt either.

Yuet Lee is another SF late night staple.

3 & 1/2 stars.
author: Veronica M.

description:
After hitting up China Town, my parents and I were starving and decided to eat somewhere nearby since the BNB we were staying at was in Pacifica. On the way back to the car, my Dad spots this place adorned with the photos of the owner with various hosts from Travel Channel and Food Network (ie Samantha Brown and Andrew Zimmern), plus the Zagat stickers from 2011 - 2014. I checked the reviews on Yelp and it had 4 stars so it must be good right? So we decided to eat here.

Little did we know we were about to embark on the most uncomfortable dining experience ever! It was terrible. If somebody from the restaurant is reading this, it was the Host and the Cook who helped serve the food working Sunday, 8/31/2014 Labor Day weekend, around 8:30pm. They are the ones who gave my parents and I terrible service and ONLY reason why I'm writing this college paper length Yelp Review.

Okay.

First of all, when the Host (middle age Asian man, gray hair, glasses) took our orders, he did not come across very well. He sounded like he was annoyed. I tried to shrug it off because it was Labor Day weekend, but nope! When he came back to arrange our table, this guy haphazardly tossed our napkins before us. Now I'm not a stickler for placing napkins on a table - nobody should be - but I'm pretty sure a Host does/should not toss napkins in front of the guests. For the plates, he arranged the table super rushed and sloppy like he wanted to get away from us.

Shortly after that, an Asian man in a white button up shirt (I can assume he was a Cook) came over with a bowl, placed it onto the table and walked away...without telling us what it was! The hell? My parents and I were staring at each other blankly wondering what it was. It wasn't until Mr Grumpy Host came back shortl to let us know it was the Chicken Noodle Soup my Mom ordered. The Cook came out again and placed a plate of noodles on the table and murmured a barely coherent 'Noodles'. That was my Dad's Vegetable Noodle order, so he sheepishly rose his had to accept the dish. Shortly after that, the Cook came back with the Clam with Black and Pepper Sauce. This time he just handed it to me. The hell? This guy didn't even talk to us!

The WORST part of this dining experience came while my parents and I started eating. In our peripheral, we could see the Host leaning against the table next to us. We were NOT the only party there. We were at a table close to the BACK of the place. There was at least 4-5 other parties in the restaurant, so why stand there facing our table? Shouldn't you be closer to the door or maybe even looking at the door? 

So here we are, trying to eat and this guy is watching us! Awkward and uncomfortable! I couldn't fully enjoy that delicious Clam dish and that dish was REALLY good. You could tell the clams were fresh and the meal was very hearty. I've never had clams made outside of a Progresso Clam Chowder can, so I was very satisfied. But I couldn't fully enjoy my dish with a middle aged Asian man hovering over me, watching my family and I eat. When I requested more water, this guy sounded even more annoyed. Okay seriously, was this guy scheduled when Zagat, The Food Network, and The Travel Channel stopped by? Or was he on his best behavior? 

The entire time we were there I never saw him once, check on ANY other table except to just deliver their food. He just stood there next to OUR table, watching. To make it worse, that table he was leaning on had a group of people on their phones. Not eating, just sitting there and playing on their phones. These people had to have worked there because the Host didn't say anything to them either.

When we were done, he never asked us if we needed a doggy bag or if we were ready for the check. He overheard us talk about the check and a doggy bag AND THEN brought it to us. This guy really did NOT deserve any tip at all. As soon as my parents decide to leave the change for him, we were out of there ASAP. 

Outside, my parents were LIVID! My mom too, was mad about how he tossed the napkins on the table and my Dad was saying that he felt really uncomfortable being watched. So it wasn't just me feeling this way. They too felt that this restaurant gave us terrible service.

So overall, despite my Clam Dish being exceptionally delicious (I'm smiling thinking about it), that's the ONLY reason I'm giving this place 2 stars. One for how good it was and another for the freshness of the clams. Other than that, terrible service combined with a VERY uncomfortable dining experience docked it the other three stars.
author: Janel B.

description:
Don't be fooled by yelp saying it closes at 3am.. because this place closes at 12am. 

I rarely come to Chinatown anymore so I haven't been here since.. maybe a couple of years.

This place never changes. Same pictures always displayed on the walls. Same kitchen. Same workers. Only thing that changed is the price! 

I was taken back from how much the prices have gone up. $28 for a deep fried flounder? Wtf? Seriously?

If you brought a purse or bag with you, make sure you keep it closed. If it doesn't, keep it off the floor and away from the walls.. I don't  doubt there are hitch hikers that will be more than thrilled to climb in. (Roaches).

Just an fyi. .
author: Crystal L.

description: Minimum purchase per person is $8. My boyfriend and I wanted to share a bowl of porridge, but the waitress said only one of us can eat it. So I had to watch my boyfriend eat. This is non sense.
author: Caron Z.

description: Love this place! Chinese food is authentic, tasty and delicious!
author: Bell A.

description:
I would have loved to give 0 stars. The food was great. But the service was horrible!! Waitress demanded more tip$. 

At the end i paid my bill and added a small tip,  unfortunatly all i could afford that day was 3bucks tip. (left some $ at hotel so i dont spend it all) my husband has cash on him and was going to add more before we left.
 Before he had a chance she got crazy on us saying, "is that a 3? Only 3 dollars? I thought i did good service,  didnt i? " I asked to speak to the manager and all he did was try to justify her behavior and telling me the % ur supposed to tip. 

First of all,  thats a recommendation of whats suggested to tip, it is not mandatory. 
Secondly, as a previous waitress YOU NEVER TREAT CUSTOMERS THAT WAY!!? Some people tip good, some dont tip at all,  and some tip all they can afford. 
Third,  i always tip more that 3dollars but now after this experience i am really going to evaluate my server and their attitude before i give them any of my hard earned money. 3 dollars or any dollar. Lol 
Lastly,  i looked on my bank account and this lady even refused to take my 3dollars. What an attitude. No gratitude at all and actually an insult to us. Treated like a dine and dash person.. Omg i really cant believe this happened. It turned a great experience into a horrible unforgettable one. 
I will never return to this place to dine and i dont recommend anyone go support their service and behavior towards paying customers.
author: Tori Y.

description:
The food is palatable but their prices and profit margins are twice of nearby restaurants which would be fine if their food wasn't also very relative. 

The 2 things ordered was summed at around $50 and we gave a 5 dollar tip considering there was 1 server, the serving distance from the kitchen was small, we were one of two parties there and the server didnt served us 50 dollars worth of food so much as we just paid 50 would be significantly less anywhere honest.

All would  otherwise be fine if it not  for the fact the the server asked us  for a min 30% tip,  insufficient from our only b/c the percentage scaled off of their ridiculous prices. 

I believe in tipping but that's seriously disproportionate.
author: Bowen C.

description:
Ordered the salt and pepper squid, as well as the flounder filet over rice with garlic and green onions.  5 stars for the squid!

Minus 3 stars for the service, however.  I'm OK with the typical "I don't give a shit about you" Chinese restaurant attitude, but this is the first time in my years of growing up Chinese in San Francisco that I've had the waitstaff count my tip in front of me, and subsequently complain for more.  The woman who counted our tip didn't even wait on us while we dined.

I recommend getting to-go from them in the future so you don't have to deal with their piss-and-moaning about how they deserve more tip for shitty service.
author: Amanda W.

description:
Worst food in SF. The Singapore style 'thick' rice noodle is as thin as 1mm; the Kung Pao Chicken 'ball' is actually sliced meat and not 'Kung Pao' style at all; and the beef porridge was burned.

Above all, a 18% tip was added automatically.  I have no idea why I spent $50+ here and started my Sunday like this. WOULD NEVER COME BACK
author: Maggie N.

description: This place is unbelievable. The food, the staff, and the atmosphere. You can tell the restaurant has survived the ages from the pictures on the wall. The decor is outdated, but the food is consistently delicious. My favorite being, jing du ro paí translates to Beijing style pork spare ribs. They taste best after a long night at the bar. You can also ask for a side of jalapeños in soy sauce to munch on while you wait for your food.
author: chad w.

description:
I never thought that I will find a hidden gem in china town, San Francisco. The salt and pepper calamari is absolutely a must try. The peking spare ribs are also awesome. The food here are slightly more expensive than other chinese restaurant, but I can guarantee that you will not regret spending that extra buck.

Unfortunately, sometimes the portion of the food might not be consistent.
author: Johan K.

description: Don't come here if you're stuck on choosing a place to eat! My family and I came to this restaurant because we couldn't decide on any others. I can't speak on their Chinese food, but the food was so flavorless. The meats were fatty. Service was bad. And this place is expensive. Not only all of that, they charged a 20% tip already on the bill, which the service wasn't worthy of. Do noooooot come here!!
author: Victor P.

description:
The last time I stepped in to this place was about 15 years ago.  The food was awesome, the portion size was worth it and lastly, the price was right.  This restaurant was mainly for locals that knew where to grab a late night bite.  

Fast forward:  I came here last night to grab a bite before the Fourth of July firework show.  I should have stayed away after seeing so many photos outside the restaurant of celebrities that patron this place (hint, not always good food for relying on celebs photos).   This place seemed to change tactics that cater more to tourists.  The prices for most dishes were dramatically high for this place (similar prices at fancy Chinese restaurants, and this one is not). The food portion was also smaller than years before.  And the quality taste was not addictive as before (maybe no MSG?). There was nothing special here anymore that I could remember from the past. 

For the good part, the service was great. I can't knock that off. Nice staff that are tentative. 

Overall, this place seems more for the tourist. The prices don't justify the taste or portions size,but then again, SF has gotten expensive to live in this city that most hole in the wall joints are charging more to pay the staffs.  The food was edible but I could find better places that are cheaper and tastier.
author: Chan M.

description:
San Francisco Chinatown has tons of Chinese restaurants that run the gamut from hole-in-the -wall non-english speaking bargains to higher priced snob faux Chinese offerings.  Yuet Lee is a higher priced local family restaurant that delight all who partake.  

Our favorites include the sweet sour porkchops and the Chinese broccolli.  Somewhat rushed but the service is quick and businesslike, not rude.  Not the cheapest but well worth the wait.
author: Ric C.

description: I sure do love love this place! It's really hard to find a legit Chinese restaurant in the city that's not too Americanize and open till 3AM! Each of the dish portions are HUGE and the waiters and waitresses service are always friendly when I visit the spot. The food comes fairly fast and all of them are deliciously on point. I highly suggest everyone try this spot out if you crave Chinese food. Their food won't disappoint you (oh! I would suggest salt and pepper spare ribs, Porridge, chow mein, fried rice, soups.............etc!)
author: Tiffer C.

description:
Table of 10 with family size portions of delicious Chinese to share? Yes, please.

Don't expect fancy, just go in and expect to stuff your face. Visiting from the spot in Orlando that is coined the ViMi district, I have high expectations since I frequent Chinese and Vietnamese places weekly. 

Since we had a huge group we ordered a ton of dishes to mix and match and get a full range of their deliciousness. Everything I had was great! The veggies really stood out, the bok choy was fantastic and all the noodle dishes were addictive. 

Really glad we stopped in here and enjoyed a family style meal. Everything came really quickly right after we ordered it so that was a great way to start off our evening out!
author: Colleen B.

description: too expensive their prices on their website arent up to date and boy is the food not good enough i got some beef chow fun and some bok choi in garlic sauce $27 what a rip off.
author: Chris T.

description:
This place is SUPER pricey! Everything was mediocre and oily. The restaurant itself could use a deep cleaning. I was afraid to use the condiments. Just by picking up the vinegar bottle I could see a visible ring along the inside on the bottle. Hello! Dump out the vinegar and clean the bottle eeeewww. 
Can't imagine what else hasn't been cleaned.

Don't plan on returning unless was accompany friends that dragged me here.

Service was attentive (cause I was with a party that spoke Chinese fluently).
author: Liz N.

description:
The Yelp site says they're open until 3am. When we walked in it was about 11:40pm on a Monday. We just came out of a concert and headed over when we saw that it was open late. As we walked in they looked extremely unhappy. We were seated and rushed immediately to order. We were asked repeatedly about 3 times until we asked what time they closed. They said midnight. When we pointed out that it says 3am online and on the menu, the waiter angrily said that it only applied to Friday-Sunday even though it said Monday-Sunday on the menu. We all looked at each other and decided to leave. 

We walked down the street instead and found a place that closes at 1am and decided to eat there instead. 

I would just avoid that place completely. I was fine with just settling with whatever to eat so late at night but not with that attitude! Won't be coming back at all.
author: Ashley R.

description: This can be the worst restaurant in SF. The foods is not good as the name out side board. The price is little height and servers was slow. Moreover, they also put the TIP in the receipt and force the customer to pay too. Never come back.
author: Khoe T.

description: Horrible...over priced crap. Terrible service and tasteless. I'm an American, yes, a white boy; but does that mean I cannot uses chopsticks? When I asked for them...before the food came, I had to ask again twice. I asked the lady that took out order to make it spicy...no heat what so ever. We all told her, there is no heat/spice here. She told us, that's the way we make it. So, what, we have to eat whatever the cook makes??? Can you take it back? No, we will charge you for two orders....Then, there was only three slices of garlic in a large vegetable dish and overloaded wish soy souse. When we paid and finishing our diluted tea, the waiter had the nerve to come back and ask for a bigger tip...for what??? Okay, no problem, tip erased, 0 zero, nothing, good-buy.
author: Rayson R.

description: My friend and I came here on Chinese New Year the year of the Monkey.  A lot of places were closed for the special holiday but not this famous place. It has been open for over a decade and it was pretty neat to see the famous wall with a variety of famous actors and actress on the wall. One was Jackie chan with the owners of the restaurant. Don't be intimidated when walking into this small room. The young lady was very attentive to our needs. I ordered the wonton soup With noodles as it was delicious! It's so filling I Should of gotten the wonton soup without noodles like my friend did. She ordered the wonton soup with duck. I would recommend this place of you are really craving that need for warm soup to fill up your appetite in china town
author: Nessa C.

description:
Yuet Lee is a great restaurant. Since restaurants in Chinatown generally don't excel in ambiance or service they have to be judged purely on the goodness of their food. For general dining Yuet Lee is the restaurant I go to. I've heard that chefs in San Francisco go here after work because they're open late but also because chefs would know a good place when they find it. The restaurant is a fixture in Chinatown, I believe open at least 40 years.

This is one restaurant where you can close your eyes and randomly point to things on the menu and know that most everything will be reasonably good. It comes down to the talent of the cooks and they seem to be good ones.

About specific items:

Pepper salted squid: Pretty good but for me not a must have

Steamed minced pork with salt fish: A good must have dish

Salt fish fried rice: Good

Pork fried rice: Good

Chow meins: Good

Chinese broccoli with beef: Good

Pea tips: Good
author: John W.

description: Very good curry crab here. 1 star off because it's really expensive. But otherwise, cooked very well and the food is delicious. Definitely worth the money!
author: Praveen G.

description: The food is decent but prices are higher than rest of chinatown. They open really late so if you're craving some salt and pepper squid at 2am, this is the place to go. Apparently the north beach police station officers frequent this restaurant. I was not able to confirm so if you're a cop and you frequent this restaurant, please give this review an upvote.
author: Anni D.

description:
If you want to get treated like a piece of s""t please come here.

I'm honestly surprised by how down hill the food and service has gone. Okay, why would someone pay $20 for some friend prawns. My bf and I ordered a seafood soup and some deep friend prawns. We received a child portions bowl of egg noodles with some measly pieces of boo chou and two shrimps. What a RIPOFF. Not only that when I asked the waiter for the check she rolled her eyes at me.  The $20 shrimp plate made me want to scream. There was maybe about ten pieces of shrimp on the plate with a few half-a**ed pieces of jalepeno. I could have bought food at freak' panda express that would have been better.

I used to come here for fried rice when I saw the prices I knew it was time to bail out.

Anyway...when we were about to pay the check came out to $30! We were so insulted. Let me repeat $30 bucks for some child's portion noodles and a few pieces of friend shrimp!

It gets worst. The waitress then tells us we didn't tip the full $15%. Look lady, if the service was bad I don't want to give you more tip.  She then comes back a second time and tells us AGAIN that we didn't tip enough. I was ready to kill someone.

This place must be a tourist trap. I am seriously DISGUSTED. by this HORRIBLE place.
author: Julia Q.

description: Everything we ordered was delicious and flavorful! So glad we found this place. Salty spare ribs, chicken fried rice and beef chow fun delish. We couldn't stop eating!! Zagat rated!
author: Monica B.

description:
After 25 years of going to this place, I am throwing in the towel. It used to be great but after repeated disappointing visits over the past couple of years, that's it. I'm done. 
The food is sloppily prepared and served, the place is dirty, and the help has an indifferent smug attitude. Blah blah blah. Bye bye bye.
author: Moe B.

description:
I was deep in a drunken stupor like most people when I dragged my friends here. 

All I remember were:
-Salt and pepper squid was really bland/boring and I might've cursed out yelp for this recommendation outloud
-The spareribs were spectacular and made me forget ladylike manners
-I kept saying I wanted korean chicken wings before passing out
author: Tian Q.

description: I concur w/ others who have submitted recent reviews of a negative nature.  First, Yuet Lee appears to serve dishes that are consistently not hot enough, ie., lukewarm at best.  The chow mein and beef stew in noodle soup we had today didn't have much more than a hint of bok choy; and the beef stew (ngow nom) looked like resuscitated old meat with an excess of untrimmed fat. Secondly, since when do restaurant personnel have the right or authority to insist on what THEY regard to be a decent tip?  This isn't the only establishment in Chinatown that haggles with customers about the size of tips.  [At least one restaurant in J-Town is notorious for intimidating customers into leaving bigger tips.]  Well, this WAS a convenient eatery that now and again, depending on the chef on duty's mood and other factors, served some semblance of a decent Chinese dish.  Not dining here anymore.
author: Benjamin T.

description:
Bad service not friendly 
stuff super dirty
 restrooms food was ok 
nothing special 
Won't be coming back to this place
author: Galaa B.

description: We ordered 3 bowls of wonton noodle soup and 1 plate of chicken fried rice. The quality was OK and the quantity was better than most. What was not OK, exactly the same as Maggie N's review below of 7/10/16 was that an 18% gratuity was added onto the check when there was no written notice either on the menu or posted in the restaurant. When I questioned the manager she admitted that there was no notice but that "this is what we normally do"  Its not only illegal but TOTALLY UNETHICAL and the kind of practice that drives people away. Some how our meager lunch cost us $46.50,  My next complaint will be filed with the City of San Francisco. NEVER RETURN here on general principal.
author: Marc Z.

description: Decided to try this place as apparently Jackie Chan ate here before. Ordered the "famous dishes", salt and pepper squid and Peking spareribs and their young chow fried rice. Though it was their most famous dishes it did not live up to my expectations as it was overly seasoned, left a bad after taste and the fried rice was had too much oil. The meal was overpriced and the employees chased for tip.
author: Czarina D.

description:
Why did you steer us wrong, Anthony Bourdain???

My friends and I came here for some quality Chinese food as recommend by Anthony Bourdain, saying "well worth the trip..."

The restaurant itself feels a bit greasy but I care more about the food. We had a party of 5 and we were starving after the whole day. The employees seated us quickly and we began to order. We started out with 5 dishes. Unfortunately for us, the portions were much smaller than those served at many other Chinese restaurants. On top of the small portions, everything looked good but tasted SOO BLAND (EXCEPT THE PORRIDGE. That was fine.) We ordered 3-4 more dishes, hoping for better quality and actually leaving with a full stomach. The next few dishes were just as bland; very disappointing. At least the cook on the dishes was good. 

I did leave the restaurant full, but I probably ate around a third of all the food. With a bill totaling ~$120 before tax and tip for 8-9 bland dishes, I definitely do not recommend this restaurant. The quality of food and portion served is NOT worth the price. However, it does open late so if you are in the area for a small bite, it's a good option. 

Hm.. just to close off, I would like to say we didn't get the salt & pepper prawns Anthony Bourdain recommended. Was that the problem? Ha.
author: Jonathan C.

description: Food was good and they open till 3am which is a plus. But the price was a little too high. Probably won't go back as we find something cheap but food was good as well.
author: Jiawa Z.

description: The salt pepper shrimps were perfectly crisp and flavored. The beef chow fun was also very tasteful and well prepared. The steamed sea bass was bland as well as another beef dish that I did not care for. They had very little selection on veggie dishes - was told out of season. Service quick and atmosphere... Mom and pop shop.
author: Jo J.

description:
When we first walked in, I was a bit hesitant in staying. It looked like your typical hole in the wall Chinese place with sticky tables and dirty floors. However, plastered all over the restaurant walls were photos of Eric Tsang! One of the funniest Kungfu actors in HK with their restaurant's chef! If that guy can eat here why can't I? Ambience aside or lack there of, the food was a different story! 

The salt and peppery squid was fantastic! Lightly battered and super crispy! No wonder they're well known for it! 

Salty fish and chicken fried rice: always my fav fried rice! Was very tasty here and so much more flavourful than the famous upscale Kirin in Vancouver!  

Beef and gai lan (Chinese broccoli): very fresh veggies and the beef was marinated nicely! Almost melts in ur mouth. I make mine slightly less tenderized but that's just how Chinese restaurants make em' since the beginning of time. 

I'd come here again! I looked to our neighbouring table who ordered the beef chow fun and that looked delish too!
author: Jocelyn L.

description: $33. For this!?!? Chicken still bloody...ginger in hot pot was ridiculous amount...won't be back!!
author: Larry D.

description: For SF in Chinatown this is my favorite place. The ambiance is not that great but the food is good. The seafood is really fresh and the price is decent. It is fairly flavorful but not too spicy. The fish is really fresh.
author: G L.

description: They have gotten worse and worse. I love the part of the menu that is not touristy or normally considered to be enjoyable by fans of typical American style Chinese food, but the past 2 times I've been, I've been convinced by my server to order somethings else and each item has been absolutely terrible.
author: Sean C.

description: I would like give ZERO，the two kind of meat and the nuts all not fresh at all. I have been tried so many restaurants like this type, but this restaurant is the worst one. This restaurant also very dirty! And they added the 18% tips without notification！When I doubt the total price，they still didn't tell us！
author: Sophia G.

description:
Shrimp and scrambled eggs for the win!! And that sweet soy with jalepeno.. Beef stew and BBQ pork hong kong style crispy noodles.. 

This place had been around since the 70s still the same vibrant green and red corner spot w the hole in the wall super seasoned wok quality. My dad introduced me to this place in the 80s and I think I shall pass this place along to my kids when they're born ahah.. 

I don't mind the sometimes rude service for a quick taste buds trip down memory lane to me it's well worth it!!
author: Fredo G.

description:
Overall, the food is a 2; but I give them credit for staying open late.  So, 2.5 rating from me.  

No matter how many times I eat here over the years, I'm underwhelmed by the food they serve late at night.

Because some of my other favorite places had closed for the evening, I recently had the Seafood Chow Mein for about $11.  The dish came with squid, scallops and shrimp (that were a little tired and not super fresh).  The chow mein noodles here are really thin (like vermicelli) and always come out dark like they were cooked in a bunch of soy sauce.  But, it doesn't taste salty.  So, I think the oil is just old and dark.  In fact, when I ate it, I had to add soy sauce to give it a bit more flavor.

Yuet Lee is an institution and there are pictures of famous people and Chefs on the walls.  Perhaps when the Cooks spot the famous people, they make much more extra effort to put out good food with high quality ingredients.

Since I'm not famous, I'm just going to have to focus on eating at places that consistently serve high quality food at a fair price.

Given how much Asian food I eat, I'd say my rating is fair when compared to the other Chinese restaurants I have rated.  It's not easy to get a 4 or 5 from me.
author: Roy C.

description:
This is not a regular restaurant review.  I'm calling this restaurant out for outright cheating their customers on their bill and for bullying them for tips.

The 1 star is not for the food, which was to be expected for a hole in the wall dive, and not for the price, it's expensive for 2 people coming out of an 8:45pm movie, came out to be over $80.00.  The menu price is a bit on the high side, but that's not how they get you.

We did not order anything like a whole duck, 1/2 duck or any duck or lobster or crabs.  Nothing fancy.

The 1 star is for, we believe the waiter cushioning another $11.00  to the bill for something we don't know.  The receipt was written in Chinese.  We added each item, then compared to the menu, and there's $11.00 we don't know where that came from.   

Even this doesn't deserve a 1 star.  Maybe it's service charge.

Not even the sloppy service, or the pushy sales tactic to order a platter instead of the smaller portion - heck that's still our decision we own up to that.

No, the 1 star is for yelling and bullying us LOUDLY for not leaving a tip amount that they thought was fair to them.

I kid you not:  

I figured that the mystery $11.00 was their tip or "service charge".  We still left another tip on top of that $11.00!

Maybe they're used to drunks that come in after partying and don't see the $11.00 padding or just let them slide one too many times.  We weren't drunk, and one of us reads Chinese.

I dug in my heels even further when the waitress came over after we paid and said our tip wasn't good enough.  She called over another waiter and complained to him loudly in front of every patron in the place trying to shame us.  

The 2 of them stood there and bullied and yelled at us:  A solid 5 minutes of berating us and telling us that a large tip was mandatory.

I said it's a tip, we ordered a good size ticket, we've been good customers, this is what we want to leave as a tip for the service.

The male waiter said, if this is your tip, take your things and leave now.

Well, I guess if you go to Yuet Lee for dinner AND you're sober at 11:30pm, just roll over on the bill padding and tip expectation or get your phone camera out for a nice show.
author: S P.

description: I've been going to this place for ages but finally getting around to writing a review. This place is a tiny hole in the wall at the corner. The place itself is a little run down but the food is spot on delicious! You can't go wrong with anything on the menu. But prices have increased over the years due to famous people visiting.
author: Mark D.

description:
Old school cantonese restaurant in SF chinatown. Meaning this place is not fancy, not good to go if you want to impress a date, but definitely where you want to go to order real cantonese dishes.

I ordered the beef with runny egg on rice (which is not on the menu but you just have to know they make it). I always order this dish in these types on places as it brings back memories of ordering this as a kid. For those who appreciate traditional cantonese flare, this is a can't miss.
author: Steve L.

description: What's not to like about this place? Good Chinese comfort food, fast and good service, big menu, decent prices, and late night hours.  It's not fancy and there's nothing special about the atmosphere, but for a late Friday night dinner in Chinatown we got exactly want we wanted - no waiting, solid food that were on our table within 10 min after ordering. The fact that the waitresses came by frequently to refill our water and tea, and actually smiled, was an unexpected treat in Chinatown.
author: Sarah W.

description:
I enjoyed my lunch experience here.  
It was a weekday at an off hour, so there wasnt many other people in there.  

I read some complaints about poor service, but I didnt experience any of that... food came out quickly, we paid cash and left.  

I had the pan-fried noodles, which were very good.
author: Aaron S.

description:
Their food just tastes so much better after a night out at the bar scene!  

I had a waiter that asked for more tip in the end.  The biggest turnoff after a dining experience.  I guess I was a dollar off from 15%, but the service wasn't that great to begin and end with - especially when there are drunk people walking through the doors and demanding to be served during the late night hours!  The waiter was upfront and insistent about having to be tipped more when service was alright!  I am just surprised on how they can ask for more tip when they didn't even focus on our table the entire time we were dining!  This was my first time experiencing a waiter asking for more tip and not feeling embarrassed about it.

Chinese food was good and the restaurant is conveniently opened late.  However, watch out for the stingy waiter and tip whatever you think is reasonable! 

There is another Chinese food restaurant down the block that offers the same type of service, similar food dishes and you're not forced to tip them the norm of 15% if you don't feel like it.

Yuet Lee, you would have been my go to spot for late night munchies on Broadway, but not with that waiter who forces his way on having to be tipped the norm when service was below performance!  Ahem, my teapot at my table was not refilled and you didn't even come on over to see if we needed anything else.
author: Tiffany D.

description: Service was horrible food barley had any flavor and portion was small. On top of that the waitress demanded a tip. I will never eat here again or reccomende it to anyone. I guess they don't know what "customer service" means.
author: Yoichi K.

description:
If I am going to have Chinese food...I want it to come from a place like this!
I am usually picky about where I eat and what it looks like, but I make the exception for Chinese...because you will only get real good (cheap) grub from a place like this.

There isn't bells and whistles - although there is an AWESOME lazy susan in the middle of a large table...that turned out to be the perfect tool for our family style dinner.

About 10 of us popped in, and took over the place. They looked at us as if we were aliens - that's cool - we were a super eclectic group - but we all had one thing in common - we were ready to eat.

We ordered so many things, it's hard to remember, but they were all great. Soup, noodles, bok choy, salt and pepper squid, fried rice (pork), some other pork offerings, chicken and I washed it down with a beer. They serve single servings of wine that come prepackaged (I had seen it on the show Shark Tank, but never in person.)

We would give that lazy susan a spin and everyone would grab as they pleased. It was great. If anyone missed their chance at picking at their favorite, they would try to stop and reverse the wheel...good times!

A great family style meal, that left everyone stuffed - and we gave leftovers to a homeless man.
author: Blue A.

description:
Came here for lunch today after walking Chinatown for a bit... We were their first customers since they just barely opened at 11. Brother said this place was recommended by Anthony Bourdain... so I'm thinking this place must be good! First look at the place...old and dirty....but its like one of those family restaurants that survived for 30 years, therefore it must be doing something right. Stepping into the place I saw pictures of food network chefs and food critics and also some Hong Kong stars...definitely have high expectations for them.

 We ordered 4 dishes...their famous salt and pepper fried squid, double-side fried shredded pork chow mein, beef stew wonton noodle soup and a mixed porridge. So here's the breakdown:

Beef stew wonton noodle soup - noodles were good and the beef was tender but only three wontons...which was ok. 

Porridge - smooth and lots of meats but can use a bit of salt.

Double side fried shredded pork chow mein - really good! Crispy noodles and the pork was super tasty.

Salt and pepper squid - they are famous for a good reason! My favorite dish out of the four. Definitely a must try!

Overall not a disappointment...the food is msg free too!
author: Joanna L.

description:
Yuet Lee has the best Chinese food in SF. Ive been eating there since 1983. With that said,  ny experience tonight was less than stellar.  I paid the tab by credit card and was going to leave the tip in cash.  After signing the charge slip the waiter approached our table to tell me that I did not include the tip  I explained to him that I  will be tipping in cash, he mumbled something and walked away. He then proceeded to stare us down with his sidekick  (a female waitress who did not serve our table ) as though it was a intimidating tactic and we would succumb to their starring powers.. We asked for 2 items to be boxed, as I  counted out the tip. The waitress came back with our boxed food and rudely asked why we weren't leaving a tip which I had in hand. I  tried to explain to her we're leaving cash, but apparently she had a hearing problem cause she kept repeating "why you no leave me tip?" 

We walked out and left no tip. Across the street we ran into the original waitress whom was very nice and give her the tip.

Never in my life have I been bullied into leaving a tip. Yuet Lee just lost a faithful customer and I will never recommend this restaurant to anyone.
author: Jory L.

description: I had the sweet sour pork chop over rice with baby Bok choy.  Very tasty but a little pricey service excellent. Place was clean for Chinese restaurant. Would go again convenient location and open till midnight
author: Ray L.

description:
There is nothing fancy going on here. In fact, the atmosphere reminds me a little of my gramma's apartment with the pressed wood tables, bright yellow lighting and chachkies and faded pictures all over the place.

However, the food is excellent, the service is very attentive (read: they basically watch you eat) and they have a large round table for 9 with a huge Lazy Susan that is AWESOME.  

I am not even 100% sure of everything we got.  Since we were a large group, our Yuet Lee veteran ordered for us. I know there was wonton soup, bok choy, salt and pepper squid, chicken and asparagus, noodles, fried rice, white rice and more. All so tasty and savory.
