Walkable from the Financial District - maybe 15 minutes.

This is simply a great place for a shedload of savory Asian food, and I wish I could go back for more this week (but I live out of state!!)
author: Heidi P.

description:
I really don't understand the price. One bottle of Tsingtao at $5.50?! The inside looks like it hasn't been changed in years, and it probably hasn't. But people don't go to Chinatown for the decor.

As for the food I thought it was pretty good. Many people have been going here for years and they can probably vouch for the authenticity better than I can. But was the food worth the price? Absolutely not. Portions were small. Definitely not worth the price.
author: Gina F.

description: At first when they were giving us the waters it came hot and I was like oh no it's hot. Then I smelled the water and I was like oh no it's bad. It's gonna taste bad. Then I took a sip and it actually wasn't too bad. We ended up asking for iced water and I was like oh no it's probably gonna be bad too. I took a sip and it wasn't too bad like the hot water. It had a unique taste to it which is hard to describe. Other than that the food was bomb but -1 star for service
author: Justin N.

description:
You'd think these guys never saw a newspaper before. There's more newspaper clippings on the walls than walls themselves. But, who cares, really. It was a dining experience that'll go down in the record books...if there even is a record book to begin with. 

We busted the door down with a group of 10 and made our way around the menu in familial dining style. Salt and pepper squid, chow mein, white fish, soup with pork dumplings, other pork items, noodles with other seasoned/sauteed meats. A cornucopia of choices and all were fantastic. TsingTao Beer abounded, plastic bottles of wine, and, I'm sure, other weird alcoholic beverages to be had

Terrifying bathrooms situation: Check
Cheap meal: Double Check
"Would I go back" status: CHECK
author: Benjamin G.

description:
This restaurant is a legend for me. I went there for so many times and the food never disappoint me. The salt n pepper calamari and peking spear ribs is a heaven. The garlic noodle and black bean clam also good. I think the restaurant needs some improvement in the cleanliness, but everything else is fine.
I highly recommend this restaurant
author: Christofer K.

description: Came here on Sunday for lunch. We ordered tofu beef over rice and vegetarian chowmein.  Both were surprisingly good.  Price is moderately high (11.50 for chowmein) but is expected for most restaurants in SF.
author: Elena H.

description: Good food, terrible service. Seems like everyone recently is getting harassed to leave a tip.
author: Jewelle B.

description: This place is the definition of Tourist Trap... Tried it two  times and food here is really below average. They make everything really quick your meal would probably be ready after 5 minutes. Anyone who wanna pay a couple bucks more for below average food can give it a try...
author: Roy O.

description: Never go there again.  Best food ever.  Best service ever and best food ever.    While I was eating and the old man were keep looking at us. Because we were talking about the food. They were really really not good.    Finally i payed and I only gave them  few dollars tips and he said: u guys are so save.    I was like Why am I need to pay for the tips with  the worst service
author: Sam B.

description:
Barbecued pork chow mein, dry fried, without gravy.  One of the best dishes you will ever have.  This place has ruined me, because no other chow mein has ever held a candle to theirs.  

We went recently, and also ordered their beef and broccoli, and salt and pepper squid.  The squid was perfectly seasoned, crispy, and delicate.  

They're open late, until midnight I think, so there is no excuse to not go.
author: Anika E.

description:
While the food is decent and tasty, the PORTIONS are terrible. They either need to cut prices in half or double/triple the amount of food they give. There are two types of Chinese restaurant: A. the greasy-decent-cheap-supersized portions or B. the five-star-quality-expensive-tiny portions places. This place fits in neither category.

For 6 people at 2am, "family style" dining came out to be $16 per head...for 2am drunken munchies!! If it weren't for the whole duck (which costs $27 fyi) we would have had to order twice as much food. Seriously, make the trek out to Noriega and stick to ABC Bakery. For $16 I could have ordered 2 dishes...by myself.

WHAT WE ORDERED:
- Whole Duck ($27): I don't know how you can cheat people out of a whole duck.. so this was the only portion that was huge.
- Salt and Pepper Calamari (~$15): decent, not memorable
- Braised Tofu (with mix veggies $9): a dozen TINY pieces of tofu, one mushroom sliced, some shredded carrots, and maybe 7 baby bak choy-- served on a tiny dish you'd imagine an appetizer would be served on.
- Sweet and Sour Pork ($10.50): a laughable amount of pork...maybe a dozen tiny cubes? right, because each of us got about 2 pieces...also served on the tiniest dish.
- Chef Special Chow Mein (Hong Kong style, $9.25) : Smaller than a typical lunch portion
- Rice (~$7): The only thing they were generous with

**But get this, they did give us the "Insider" discount** As we asked for the check, my boyfriend asked if they had included gratuity. A reasonable question, since 8 of us were seated but only 6 of us ate, places usually charge 18-20% for parties of 6 or more. The waiter said (in Chinese of course) "For OUTSIDERS we charge gratuity, but for INSIDERS we don't." So hooray for being a group of Asian kids and my boyfriend for speaking fluent Chinese? No automatic gratuity add. 

OUTSIDERS BEWARE.

$6 minimum/person and $20 minimum for credit/debit
author: Jenna H.

description:
I hesitated for the longest time because the outside always reminded me of the old Hong Kong gangster movies.  I'd always imagine something bad going down and people would flip those large dingy round tables upside down and bust out their machetes.  But I finally mustered up the courage one day and I never looked back.  I come here for the beef chow fun.  And the beef chow fun only.  It's greasy, no noodle is left naked (uniform soy sauce color :D), and hits the spot.

4 stars for beef chow fun.
2 stars for cleanliness.
3 stars for ok service.  They've never been rude to me.
author: Michelle S.

description: Tonight , I had a bad experience at this restaurant ...the waiter count the money in front of my face , not only 1 time but twice and told me I have to leave a 6 to 7 dollars tips , that's not right , u don't demand your customer to give u tips ..
author: Shane W.

description:
I've walked past this place a lot whenever I visited SF and never went in until recently.   It was for post drinking late night food and everything hit the spot.  The only comment I'd make is that the salty spicy squid could have been saltier and spicier...

give it a go.
author: David N.

description:
We visited this restaurant a few years, and we felt that the food quality has gone down.
We ordered a steam fish that had a mediocre sauce, but at least the fish was fresh.
The clams with black bean and pepper didn't taste good at all because I think the chef didn't take the time with cooking it, so it lacked the usual " wok aroma".
The yeung chow fried rice was sloppily cooked with minimal favors.

The service was also lacking, but you can't expect much from a hole in the wall Chinatown joint.

I would not come back.
author: Kalvin C.

description:
Ummm can you say FOOD POISONING! I should have walked out when I saw the pigeon walking around inside with no cook or waitress fleeing him out, only giggles in response. 

Food poisoning is so very debilitating when you have to work on organizing your storage space. Luckily, there was a gas station that let me use their bathroom. Nothing, nothing in the world is more embarrassing than having to throw out your underwear. 

I even called the San Francisco Department of Health to file a complaint. Stay away if you like to stay healthy!
author: Colette T.

description:
Hungry in the middle of the night? You can always count on some decent late night grubs in Chinatown. 

While I wouldn't call the food fantastic, it is more than adequate given the limited options at that hour. Their wonton soup, highlighted as chef's special, was just alright. I did not find the wontons particular delicious but they did put a lot of other ingredients such as chicken, squid, bok choy, carrots and more. The portion is very generous even for just a medium size bowl. 

Rice noodle was overcooked and on the verge of falling apart. Roasted duck was average. The Chicken and Vegetable Egg Noodle tasted almost exactly the same their wonton soup. The broth for both wasn't half bad though.

This place is a full house even when it is close to their closing time. I guess a lot of people need late night quick fix.
author: Mona W.

description:
It's lost a lot over the years. Food, ambience, service, all sub par.

When we first sat down I turned around to look at the tanks with the live fish. I noticed several were dead (the fish not the tanks). Ditto for the crabs. Not a one of them was among the living.

We ordered sweet/sour pork with plum sauce, mango chicken and chow mein with prawns. They all sucked. The mango chicken was way too sweet and the chicken included every part of the bird but the beak. Seeing mystery meat with big globs of fat attached is a bit much to take. The pork in the sweet and sour pork consisted of equal parts fat, gristle and meat. The sauce was decent but I didn't want to think about the rest of what I was eating.

The place is filthy. Trash and food on the floor. Flies buzzing around. The restroom would have scared off a homeless guy.

All in all, go somewhere else.
author: Vance B.

description:
This place is a trek to get to since it's right smack in between Chinatown and North beach. The only good thing about this place is the calamari and maybe the Hong Kong style noodles but also, they open pretty late for club goers.

Anyways, I'm giving them 1 stars because the customer service is pretty bad but what do you expect from a place like this. 

From my experience, you walk in, sit down and get dirty looks from the waiter/tress if you don't speak their language. You order your food and they bring it out. Also, the WORST part is they demand tip! who does that? like really I'm tipping you for service not food (you're not the chef). Geez, but anyway they will snarl at you if you simply ask to get change --- to tip them! Or better yet, they will request for you to TIP them. I'm Appalled! But really, what do you expect from a place like this? I rather go to Clement street or Irving where the service is much friendlier and the food is just as good. 

Recommendations: I think the owner of this restaurant should revamp the place, clean their dishes precisely, and add friendly staff because they give the dirtiest looks to customers. So RUDE and don't demand tip from your customers! There's a reason why we are not tipping you.
author: Julia K.

description:
I have been coming to Yuet lee since 2010.

SKIP the typical dishes you would see at western chinese restaurants. That is NOT the way to go at Yuet Lee.

1) Splurge out and get the LOBSTER NOODLES... trust me, you won't be disappointed.

2) On a budget? Get the fried beef ho fun, or the Salted fish & chicken Fried rice (they do this better than HONG KONG and my sister insists on coming here every time she visits!!)

3) Westernized dishes: Imperial spare ribs and black bean clams are both great dishes. The salt and pepper squid is not bad but don't ever get it for take out as it gets soggy!

LOVE PENNY AND HER TEAM!!!!! ALWAYS QUICK AND EFFICIENT AND KNOWLEDGABLE.
author: Amber S.

description: Good food and very fast. We ordered more than 7 dishes but we didn't have to wait more than 15mins and we got all of those. Unfortunately, I didn't like the smelling in the restaurant, it likes moldy smell
author: Phuong N.

description: One of my favorites in all of Chinatown San Francisco. Authentic and delicious. Service is good and friendly. Go for the crab, it so goood. #chinatown #sanfrancisco #dungenesscrab
author: Wilfred W.

description:
The food was not very good and it is way over priced.  $4.00 for a coke?

We tried the salt and pepper shrimp based Anthony Bourdain's recommendation and it was completely disappointing.
author: Brandon S.

description: Food came fast, great service , but food was a bit bland, otherwise it would of been 5/5.
author: Delena N.

description:
Had two of their specialties: clams with black bean sauce and peeking pork chops.  The sauce on the former was gloppy and relatively uninteresting, but OK.  The clams were tasty, but overall the dish was nothing specialy.  The pork was much worse: super oily like it had been fried at two low a temperature, and the sauce was one-dimensional--sweet, with nothing else, spice or otherwise.

Service was not terrible, but we ordered rice and they assumed we wanted two rather than one, which annoyed me--they didn't assume we wanted two orders of our entrees--especially since rice, white rice, cost $1.75 a bowl!
author: Craig Z.

description:
Between this and New Sum HK, Yuet Lee is always going to be my default choice because they have a more authentic cantonese menu. My favorite is the stir fry clams with spicy giner and black beans sauce and I always order that dish.

The place is more like a hole in a wall than an established venue but anybody who has dined in Asia knows that is where you get the best food. I agree that it is more pricey than other HK restaurants but to me it's worth the premium. 

Perfect choice for a night cap before heading back down the south bay.
author: Alex L.

description: I was a bit scared to eat here when I saw the reviews but it wasn't so bad. They took. My order right away and I had beef and tomato rice plate. I also got 15% off cause I came in during the happy hour. The food was amazing. Better than the dish I had in my hometown, Houston. It was a good portion at a good price. Service was good as well. I only gave it a four star because the atmosphere was a bit awkward but it was overall great.
author: Jei L.

description:
We have been eating here since the 90's. You come here cause of great food only. 

You don't come here for great service, customer service or cheap price. I have never been nor known a Chinese Restaurant that offer such a thing.

All turds dining out, 15% is an automatic tip so get over it or fast food is your option or get a better job.
author: Tony S.

description: Came here today for a work meeting and the food was mediocre at it's best. Some dishes were way too salty while others were too bland. We ordered the roasted pork clay pot and it was very watery and salty. I've never had a clay pot like it and was completely disappointed. Probably the best thing I had was the beef chow fun. Something I want to note was that we found a hair in our soup.. Our server took it and brought us new bowls. NO BIG DEAL! but the chef was screaming at her! That poor woman... She returned with a new bowl of soup with red eyes and a red nose. It was evident that she was crying and I felt so bad. No one should ever cry at work. Best believe we left her a big tip.
author: Kenitha Y.

description:
Loved the salt and pepper squid.  Great pan fried noodles too.  The braised pork chops rocked too.  

Super fast service.
author: Fareed T.

description:
I've heard so much about this place I had to give it a try while staying in SF for a night. My first impression walking in was that it was packing at midnight and the customers were not all Asian, surprisingly. Usually these restaurants are just filled with hungry Asian people who are either coming from the bars or just hungry asian people who stay up late. 

We ordered the fired calamari, beef chow fun, and chicken yellow curry. All the dishes were flavorful and had different flavors, unlike many Chinese restaurants where every dish tastes the same. Definitely recommend the fried calamari and beef chow fun. The curry was good too but nothing extraordinary. They have a huge selection on their menu so I'm sure everyone can find something they enjoy. Nothing was too pricy. Bill came out to be about ~$25. OH yes, they DO take credit cards unlike most Chinese places. 

I must say though, my favorite thing was the free sauce they give. It's jalapeños with soy sauce, giving every dish a punch of the right type of spiciness that Sriracha doesn't give. 

I'll definitely be back! :)
author: Sally H.

description: So so so good!!! Right my by place (short walk from nob/Russian hill or north beach), awesome hot, fresh Chinese food.  Share the seafood clay pot of you're with friends, or grab the flounder w asparagus in black bean sauce over rice for just you.  Tasty and super affordable.  Go Yuet Lee
author: Christian S.

description: Ordered curry beef. Greasy curry and the beef wasn't cut into strips- it was like the bottom of a flyer, one chunk with strips hanging off it.
author: Johanna S.

description:
Im from LA so when everyone told me to go to Chinatown I figured it doesnt matter where u eat...

Wrong.

So my family ordered 2 plates of chow mein, kung pow chicken, shrimp fried rice, and 4 sodas. Total was 75 bucks lmao, so no kidding when ppl say this place is pricey...
The waitresses did the very minimum and felt the need to add 10 bucks for their tip, ive been to miami and gratuity is included so I guess...

But the chow mein tasted like top ramen, I guess I expected more cus I can go  to any hole in the wall place in LB and eat a whole tray of chow mein to myself lol so the chow mein at this place is totally diff from any hole in the wall ur used to. The rest of the food was wtvr

I wish I would've researched more before choosing to eat here. Wish I wuda took a pic of our food too.

I wouldnt recommend this place at all.
author: April C.

description:
You don't really go to a Chinese restaurant and expect great customer service.  And this place did not disappoint.  Bad service and the  food was mediocre.  Tips were optional from my understanding.  I normally tip well above 15% if they deserve it.  I felt that they didn't deserve anything but I still tipped.  As my partner and I were leaving, the waitress stopped us and pointed at tip and said "That's not enough tip."
I should've taken the tip and left but I didn't.  

I'm never coming back.  There are better restaurants out here in the city.
author: Benjamin B.

description: Not sure about the other dishes but the congee is great! There is a pretty big selection of different types and there is public parking one block away.
author: Lily P.

description: Honestly, the food was good but I thought the prices were a bit high. This is a place that has authentic Chinese food so don't expect to see orange chicken on the menu. Otherwise it's always busy and consistant.
author: E L.

description: Delicious fresh, salt and pepper calamari, really carefully cooked and tender.  We also had broccoli greens with mushrooms, again, light, clean flavors and so tasty.  We started with my favorite, the won ton soup with barbequed pork (char siu) which I think is one of their specialties.  $37 for these three dishes (for two people) and totally delicious.
author: Abram M.

description: I was visiting the area. Bombass food freal. I don't eat shellfish but my ma absolutely loved the ginger and green onion crab ! ($42) and the portion was HUGE. They season all of their dishes very well. We also got the chinese brocoli with cod fish and beef chinese noodle. All delicious !!
author: Johnny K.

description: This lady had the nerve to ask me not to bring in outside food. I refuse to eat here. I'm sitting and waiting for my friends.
author: Noelani C.

description:
Yuet Lee is my Chinese restaurant of choice whenever Im in San Fran.  I have been going there since college also.   I've learned to look over at the aquarium and ask the waitress, who knows me very well now, what preparation they would make out of what interests me. From the aquarium,  I've had unbelievable fresh scallops on the shell here, crab, steamed shrimp by the pound with a ginger dipping sauce, shellfish, fried and steamed fish.   There are two kinds of salt n pepper shrimp here, I like the dry and chewy. The Ong Choy in shrimp paste is authentic and yummy here.   Look out for dishes with crispy garlic, really really out of this world.   

On top of it all, all other non-seafood dishes are delicious.  Sometimes, I would have chow fun and salty fish fried rice just to savor the utter simplicity of the flavors in these dishes.........so well made.  It's such a divey place and I like that the owner cares about the consistency &  quality of his food and has not upgraded or made his restaurant high-end. 

I have come here over 200 times  easily and I have not had a bad dish served to me here    There's nothing like Yuet Lee for Chinese Seafood in SF!!


JYFMY!
author: Will S.

description:
Service here is not great at all. But who expects great service from any Chinese restaurant. I walked in to order to go and she looked extremely unhappy. I ordered the liver pork porridge. I HAD NO LIVER. NOT EVEN ONE PIECE. Taste was bland, and in the end, I found a small fly in my porridge. Black bean sauce with spare ribs wasn't bad though. As they gave me my order, he rudely put it in my face, web I said thank you, no you're welcome. 

The cafe a few doors down is sooooo much better. Their service is not superb, but a lot better. And for the price.
author: Maxine L.

description:
So with both Yuet Lee and New Sun Hong Kong offering classic Chinatown late night bites, how does one decide on which business to frequent?  Service at both are as you'd expect from late night C-town restaurants, brusk and to the point.  So do you go with the restaurant with the green trim or the one w/ the yellow trim?

I guess the next attribute that I judge an eatery on is the food.  My fave late night dish is (in Mandarin) hua dan niu ro fan. Slippery Egg with Beef over Rice.  Well, let's class it up and call it Satin Eggs with Beef over Rice instead.

I mention it and another dude is like, "I love that dish, but always forget to order it".  We order 2 of that item.  What arrives is simply stir-fried beef over rice.  We tell the waiter, the cook breaks two raw eggs over the already cooling dishes, mixes it in, gives the dishes back to us.

If you've never had the dish before, the eggs are supposed to be fully cooked, in case you were wondering.

And you guessed correctly, Sun Hong Kong has NEVER messed up this, or any dish.  Sun Hong Kong wins in my book.

But then again, Yuet Lee has pics from the 70's of the owner w/ celebrities, so if you're into that, you might pick the green trim.  But you run the risk of getting some raw food.  Which might be good for raw foodies?
author: J S.

description: Me and my mom ordered fish claypot which has fish and roast pork.  Oh boy, the roast pork tasted rotten., like it had been days then reuse. I told the waiter which called the cook. The waiters and the cook said it was not stunk without tasting it. So, I told them to try it, which both of them said no. My mom told him to take the dish and get her a new one in Mandarin. At the end, he told us that he gave 1/2 discount. Wtf. I just kept quite. Told my self to write this review. I have been eating in this place since 1984. Guess,  they lost a  big big families customers. This is my first review.
author: Frans S.

description:
I was visiting from NY with some friends and stopped here after reading all these great reviews. We wanted to eat light but just could not stop ourselves, it smelled amazing in there with loads of pictures of all their meals hanging around. I found myself exponentially hungrier with one glance.

We ordered chicken fried rice, some kind of chicken chow fun, a Shredded Chicken Chow Mein, and this chicken mango something. (I'm sorry I just cannot remember their exact names). Everything was AMAZING. Incredibly affordable. The fried rice came out within 5 minutes of ordering. Then each meal followed suit within 3-5 minutes of each other. Big ol plates, we wrapped so much to go.

Yes, could be described as a hole in the wall. But its cheap, big, fast and tasty. So I'd take that hole anyyyy day.
author: Danielle Z.

description:
Came here after a failed dinner attempt at Zero Zero, I get full off of hot pockets more than I do with their pizzas.  My buddy growing up in SF and raised in Chinatown, swears by this place as 'the spot'.  Looking at the pictures, the ever so eloquent Samantha Brown has been here and enjoyed their dishes.  

A bit dingy looking with tables packed pretty closely and some sketchy looking Asian male patrons, this place is definitely the place where locals get their fill.

My friend and I shared the beef with green bean dish as well as bean curd with mushrooms in brown sauce.  I don't remember if those were the exact names, but I swear they were something of that nature.  

Overall I liked the beef with green beans the better between the two, but can't say that it was orgasmic.  It all tasted very homey (which is by no means a bad thing!) although, I wouldn't necessarily make it a point to stop here every time I come to SF because I have my little spots down in the San Gabriel Valley area in LA where I can get the same stuff.  However, I have to say that the food, location and run down dinginess with patrons who look like they used to run the streets in Chinatown back in the day....I find this place completely charming in my book.
author: Priscilla C.

description: Best remaining hole in the wall OS Cantonese BBQ duck, roast pork and 300 item menu .  All the locals go! That's the bottom line they know
author: Lawland L.

description: Good food...but if they are going to be this way about prices (see picture)......then I can't recommend......it.
author: Mag N.

description:
For the money, this was the very best of the Chinese establishments since the 70's, and usually had decent service.

Well, recently, the waitresses make the late Edsel Ford Fong of Sam Wo seem like the pope: incredibly rude, even for Chinese standards. 

Never again!
author: George T.

description: Food was okay, but the biggest issue was the service.  The waitresses were rude as they were slamming our dishes down onto the table and snapped at us when we asked for things. The biggest issue however was the mandatory tip they made us pay.  For the horrible service, that made us pay 15% but calculated wrong and it turned out to be over 20% in tip.  Additionally, they added the tax over everything including the tip, so we had to end up paying even more.  As we were leaving, we heard the manager of the store yelling at the waitresses telling them to not tell customers about the tip anymore.  This place obviously tries to scam their clients and I will not be coming back.
author: Derek V.

description:
I usually stay away from Chinatown for good Chinese foods. I took my Caucasian friends here for an exception, Kam Po. But it has closed down for the night when we arrived. YL was the closest choice. It opened late. Customers were Asian tourists and non-Asians. The foods were typical mediocre Chinese cooking for tourists, in a not too "hole on the wall" setting. I can't complain about the foods knowing what to expect before walking in, except one thing, they charged American price. $$$

There are 50 plus Chinese restaurants around this area with better (relatively speaking) and cheaper foods. Maybe only a few handful open late.

What I don't get was their lousy service. First, it's a small restaurant. Then there were at least 4 wait staffs. We didn't get much service unless you call ordering and placing foods/beverages on our table as service (I call it minimal requirement for getting money from us). And serving us soup from the big bowl to small bowls once. There was no water. No refill of my small cup of tea. No checking on us. We were practically being left alone. I had to ask for our check. This was poorer service than typical Chinese restaurants.

The waitress questioned my small tip. And cursed after my explanation for lousy service.

The irony thing is that if they want to serve Chinese style, like minimal service, don't expect much tips. If they want tips, work their hands and feet for it. My grandmother always said money don't grow from tree... but maybe it did in their village.

I don't like to pay for insult in short. And I prefer some Chinese standard service. Good luck on your visit!
author: Zack W.

description:
One of my friends raves about this place intently.  He always wants to go here if we're around the North Beach/Chinatown area.  Unfortunately, we never get to go because Yuet Lee doesn't open that late.  Luckily for me, today, I got a chance to take my parents here.  We didn't order anything exotic.  Although, I almost ordered the salt & pepper whole crab.  I should have, I think it would have been wickedly good.

My parents and I got to try the Boiled Chicken w/ Ginger and Green Onions,  Salt & Pepper Pork Spareribs, Salted Fish & Chicken Fried Rice, and an Abalone and Chicken Noodle Soup.  I didn't care too much for the Abalone and Chicken Noodle Soup, but everything else was great!  The boiled chicken was so delicious.  I even at some skin which I usually don't.  The Salted Fish & Chicken Fried Rice was just great!  It was definitely one of the best salted fish and chicken fried rice dishes I've ever had.  And, the Salt & Pepper Spareribs were just as good.  They could have gave a few more though.  For $11, we really didn't get much, compared to other Chinese restaurants.

The lady that waited on us was cool!  She was on top of things, and extremely helpful and patient.  For a Chinatown restaurant, it's absolutely worth a try in my book.  Read their top 10 dishes that I failed to see before ordering.  They have it posted on the walls.  It looked like a good guide to order the right things at Yuet Lee.
author: Jules S.

description: I would never come back here again. Since they cooks our food raw and we had a bug inside of our Wonton Noodle soup. The waiter is really mean and they gave us the ugly looks.NEVER RECOMMEND!
author: Khanh T.

description: I'm a fan.  Noticed this corner joint for years but never ventured in until last night coz everything was closed.  Lots of celebrities from Hong Kong visit here - I guess the cook is pretty darn well known.  The service was awesome - so unexpected from a Chinese restaurant.  Serving - super generous.  I'm happy and will be back again.  R&G - move aside - not worth it.
author: Koalie W.

description: I came across this place by accident and I'm so glad I did.  I had the Shrimp Noodle Soup (spicy please?) and it was so good.  Not a huge trough of brother a few shrimp and some noodles, but rather a ton of fresh veggies, plenty of medium sized shrimp, noodles of course...just not too many and the perfect amount for lunch.  As I've said before I rarely give five stars, but 4-stars for this place is gratuitous.  It seems a little old and could use a makeover on this inside, but the server was sweet as could be and that made up for any lacking in the ambiance.  Eat at Yuet Lee!!!
author: Sean M.

description:
It was my first time eating here. When I went into the restaurant, it was small.  It look bigger from the outside. I saw them preparing wontons on one of the dining tables. Raw meat and veggies.  I didn't want to see that while I was eating. There were flies flying around. Some of them landed on my food. Finally some of the people on my party got sick from eating the food.  Stomach ache. We ordered four dishes a clam plate a shrimp plate a sweet-and-sour pork plate and a plate of barbecue beef. We also had rice. When we were done the bill totaled $65. Including eight dollar tip we paid a total of $70. It was expensive. Also, each plate was very small in portion.  It was my first time eating there and it is definitely my last time.  I do not recommend anyone going there to eat.  When in Chinatown, all the other restaurants have big portions and are not as expensive.  

This place is expensive and the potions are very small.  Maybe that's why they give you smaller serving plates.  Everything is served in this small size oval plates.  The eating plate they give you is also small.  So when you put food on it, it'll look like a lot.  Just take a look at all the posted pictures and you'll see what I'm talking about.  Don't be fooled by the pictures.  They looks like a big plate of food, but in actuality, the actual plate holding the food is so much smaller compared to any other restaurant.  And that's what gives the illusion that it's a big full plate.

Then they serve rice in this big bowl.  When we were out, we asked for more rice.  What did the waiter do??  She didn't take that same big rice bowl to give us more rice, she took one of the unused eating rice bowl and give use that little rice.  Really??

The actual menu is a joke.  Looks like some a kindergarten class put it together  with all the cut out strips of paper that was glued onto the menu to cover up other items and prices.  With the price they're gouging from the customers, you would expect them to have better looking physical menus.

It's not even a high class restaurant.  I don't know what it's so expensive.  For that money, I can take it elsewhere and have a 5 star meal without flies touching my food and not have to see raw meat being prepared on the dining table next to me.
author: Jack L.

description:
I can't believe that I've never reviewed Yuet Lee, given that I've been coming here for 19 years. My then-partner and I discovered it around New Year's after getting out of a late show; the Stanford students' guide (in those pre-web days) listed it as one of the gems of late-night dining, and recommended their still-famous salt & pepper squid. We were hooked, and it became a tradition for me when in SF. 

The cuisine is mostly Hong Kong/Cantonese with a heavy emphasis on seafood, though there are some meat and vegetarian items on the menu for those who don't eat seafood. Chicken in ginger sauce and beef chow fun are both good. The wor noodle soups seem to have been removed from the menu, but on our most recent visit we got the wor dumpling soup (no noodles, but both shrimp and pork dumplings); the soup was so good that my partner, who dislikes most seafood, gave me the shrimps and scarfed down the rest of the soup. 

Salt & pepper squid is one of their specialties (they do the same treatment with prawns, but I've never ordered them). I have to admit that the squid varies somewhat from visit to visit. Sometimes it has tons of pepper and is very spicy; last time it was more like a squid tempura. The batter is always light and crisp, balancing the slight chewiness of the squid, and it comes with a jalapeno/soy/cilantro dipping sauce. 

Like many smaller restaurants in Chinatown, they prefer cash. Service is brusque but fast. The atmosphere is more divey/hole in the wall than fancy, but the food is consistently good.
author: Cage H.

description:
One star... This restaurant has some serious manner issues...
1. The waitress will stare at you while you are eating, the whole eating journey
2. They self tipping! Demanding tips from customers, will not let you go until they got the amount of tips they think they "deserve"  

The food however, is good! Recommended dishes;
1. Peking spareribs
2. Salt and pepper calamari  

The food pricing has been increasing nonstop for the last 4 years. 

Check everything on your bill before you pay.
author: Amelia H.

description:
Yuet Lee is an SF Chinatown institution and rightly so. For one thing, it's opened late--to around 3am I think--and thus draws in an eclectic crowd of clubbers, locals, cops and other interesting folks in the wee hours. Also, it's a superb example of the classic, no-frills, Cantonese seafood house. The emphasis is on fresh, diverse, dishes and the menu is long and varied enough to live up to this mission with items such as salted fish with diced chicken & bean cake, sauteed crab, fresh crab in curry sauce, pepper and salt roast spareribs and braised catfish with black bean & roast pork. 

The clay pot dishes--such as the aforementioned catfish--are superb but I have never had any form of seafood here that I didn't enjoy. The serving sizes are more than ample and often downright generous and while the service can be impersonal to a degree, it is mostly prompt--you don't expect the staff to fawn over the patrons in a place like this, either. Other stand-out dishes include their soups, especially the General Li's Mixed Ingredients Soup however their won-ton soup is even quite good--you really cannot go wrong with Yuet Lee. I would advise possibly coming here around nine at night--after the dinner rush but before they get far into the night and perhaps out of some things.
author: Mike W.

description: overpriced, horrible food. waitresses chased us down for not giving them over 10% tip. don't eat here
author: Beatriz G.

description:
Delicious Chinese food, a must go. Best thing is you can pay with credit card with an order minimum (I believe) of $10. 

Looking for excellent Chinese food, come here.
author: Lina K.

description: I have been coming here for 20 years and and its still amazing. Clams with Black bean sauce is recommended!
author: Naj S.

description:
I came here for the second time, got delicious wonton noodle soup at 1am after clubbing and realized, do you know why this place tastes so good?? 

MSG + DRUNK FOOD 

yeahhhhhhh buddy.
author: Raquel Y.

description: There were only a few restaurant open in chinatown after a night out in Downtown SF. Chose Yuet Lee because that's what my friend recommended. The service is amazingly fast and the food is pretty satisfying too... But I feel that this place is either overpriced or they overcharged us. We ordered 4 dishes and our bill came out to be $65. These dishes were around $6.75 from what I remembered seeing on the menu. We either totally overlooked that one dish that was $20+ or they overcharged us... We were too drunk and tired to deal with it besides everything on the receipt was in Chinese.... So we just paid and left... I would probably still come back but I'll check the price next time!
author: Risa Y.

description: The food here is a bit pricier than most simple Chinese restaurants. The service is quick but a bit hostile. The food was pretty good. But I would definitely head to Broadway Cafe before heading here since their prices are more reasonable for the same type of dishes.
author: Jackie B.

description:
Came here for a late night meal on a Saturday night and the place was poppin.  People of all sorts coming in and out but they were able to seat people quickly and food came out quick too.

Prices are regular and food was pretty good and not too oily.  Everything is quick quick quick which is important for these late night meals!
author: Esther S.

description: I would never recommend this restaurant, I went to dinner with my boyfriend, this Chinese food caused us a strong food poisoning. Really bad hygiene in the restrooms, So bad customer service.
author: Angelica L.

description:
Hands down the best dumpling noodles in the City.  Yup, you heard that right.  

The noodles are perfectly al dente, the broth light, but the best are the dumplings.  These little delicacies have just a tad of shrimp and meat, with a dash of mushrooms, woodears, and bamboo, and just slightly sweet and salty.  The skin is also thin but flavorful in the soup.

Really quite yum.  Come here late night after a long night out.
author: Mark M.

description: Loved the clams. Didn't care for the salt and pepper squid because I thought it was too salty. Food came out super quick. Place is kind of ghetto, but it makes the place seem authentic.
author: Faith B.

description: This place is great for some greasy but good noodle dishes. Nothing fancy, yet still good food. It's a little pricey, but what do you expect in San Francisco?
author: David T.

description: I took a friend of mine to this place late night who was visiting from overseas. The food was terrible and the service was even worse. Despite this, I ended up putting some tip but the lady comes back and says its not enough...what??? Are you kidding me? I told her this is all I am going to give and you should not be asking for more tip. She then goes to this guy with glasses who comes over to me tells me the same thing. I could not believe this was happening. I told him, "I am requesting you to not force me to give you more tip." He kept insisting until he gave up and walked away. I am NEVER EVER giving my business to this place.
author: Farhan K.

description:
Seafood is fresh and delicious. There is tons of MSG but eh, what do you expect from an authentic Chinese restaurant? It would be rather suspect if msg were missing :p

Would not recommend sitting downstairs.  They can get busy so they may seat diners downstairs.  Doesn't seem safe...

Casual dining. Not a place to go all dolled up.
author: Lev E.

description:
I was pretty wasted. I don't remember much. 

Food? Yes. Duck noodle soup was salty.
Green? Lots of green. Who painted the place?

Ok that's all I got after a night of drinking at Sip.
author: Alfred Y.

description: Yay latenight  after a night full of fun. Waiter rush us due to kitchen was closing which was very thankful they still welcome us to din in. Food and service was on point. We had the Mongolia beef fried rice and black bean clams.  Mos def will return after a night out in northbeach sf
author: Linda B.

description:
Normally on an ordinary schedule like everybody else, Matt will never eat anything past 8pm. But after attending and watching the Warrior's game at Oracle Arena, in which they won, Matt has used ALL his energy to cheer for his home basketball team.  Matt was here way past his dinnertime.

Matt landed at one of Emeril's favorite Chinatown restaurant, who by coincident lost one of his shows earlier in the week. The corner Chinese Restaurant was quiet, with a few people dining and wrapping up their meal for the night.

Matt was in the mood for some greasy and oily, but popular Beef Chow-Fun (Dry Style). The $6.00 dish is slightly more than other neighboring Chinatown Restaurant, and with a soothing cup of tea, the noodle-plate was good enough to refuel his lost energy sustained from the basketball game. 

There are many restaurants in the North Beach/Chinatown area, but Matt was very fortunate to find parking in front of this corner dining location. Hey, The Warriors won, front parking, and a solid meal, can you ask for a better night?
author: Matt G.

description:
Are you drunk? Are you tryna grub on some dank ass chinese food? Tired of ABC or can't make D&A's cut off time? Well....

Come on down to, Desperately in Need of a New Exterior Paint Job Yuet Lee, on the corner of Broadway! 

Can't decide what to order?? Don't order Chinese food often?? No sweat...

-Beef Stew w/ rice 

-Minced Beef over rice (get that egg raw and mix that ish around asap!) 

-Salt and Pepper Spareribs

-Fried Rice 

Minus one star for the bullshit premium you have to pay after 12am or whatever.  Limited menu with higher prices, expect to pay around $10 per dish. minus one star for not having Salt and Pepper Tofu, that's my shit, I threw a fit the first time I heard that.  Also for counting the money right in front of your face to make sure you didn't shortchange them or are tryna do somethin sneaky.  Those drunk dine and dashers... always ruining it for the rest of us!  Gosh..
author: Randy N.

description:
In my many years of living nearby and spending many a night at Rosewood or down the street at the bars in North Beach, I somehow never made it to Yuet Lee. That is, until this weekend when we arrived late at night from LA starving and craving some authentic Asian food. Right away I knew this would be the perfect opportunity to finally try this neon green beacon of light. That, and San Tung was already closed for the night. 

First of all, the fact that this place is located where it is and open till 3am earns it at least three stars all on its own. But even beyond its convenience, Yuet Lee serves up some yummy and authentic tasting (at least to this Korean) Chinese food that really hits the spot. 

I ordered the beef with tomato over rice and although I felt that it was a bit skimpy on the beef, I enjoyed the flavor of the sauce and the portion was hearty for the price (I think under $7). Cody P got the chicken broth with noodles and although he was afraid it would just taste like his usual chicken noodle soup, this one definitely had that Asian punch to it... something about the broth that was more pungent and Asian tasting, though it's hard to describe how. The egg noodles were plentiful and Cody P was very happy with his choice, especially after washing it down with a cold Tsing Tao. 

The servers aren't very chatty or gregarious but they're on their shit and they get the stuff out quickly. The ambiance, as anyone who has been inside can tell you, is nothing to write home about but that's part of the charm... I'd be suspicious if all of a sudden the place got a fresh coat of paint and no longer had random hand-written signs taped to the walls. This place is what SF is all about!
author: Christina P.

description:
World-famous Salt and Pepper Squid brings me back again and again.  I will drive all the way from Vallejo for nothing more than a plate of squid fried crisply to perfection.  While visiting Pier 39, I will hike the hills of SF for a plate (or possibly 2) of my favorite dish.

Clams in black bean sauce also shines and I cannot claim to have tried many more dishes from the menu because I am usually full of calamari.  The service is mediocre and the place is dirty, but if you are visiting SF, I will always insist that Yuet Lee for salt and pepper squid is a MUST.
author: Cyndi C.

description: Do not eat here. This restaurant use to be good 20yrs ago but no longer. The place was dead the portions were much smaller than I remember and the service was absolutely horrible. The food server said there was an $8 minimum and brought out dishes that were lacking counted money before we could get up from table and asked for a tip. I was truly appalled.
author: Michelle S.

description:
As a warning to readers: this review is based on my dietary habits and how accommodating Yuet Lee is to the veg diner. My family has been coming here for years, and while there are certain dishes that are absolutely delicious (see my first review), since I've been a vegan, I can't enjoy this place too much.

Of course, the menu is meat-heavy. No bigs. But it seems as all the vegetable dishes are served in oyster or fish sauce. Which is not vegetarian or vegan... So when I ordered the braised tofu - which comes in oyster sauce - I asked for it to be in a different sauce. After some confusion about what I was asking for, the server said it could be made in garlic sauce. The result was... eh. It wasn't bad; it was just average. I have a feeling that the rest of the vegetable dishes are kind of similar.

So, if you're veg, my recommendation is just to stay away from here. On the other hand, if you're omni and love MSG, go for it.
author: Natalye R.

description: RUDE RUDE RUDE!!! Just because we don't speak Cantonese doesn't mean we get charged extra or get rude service! They treated us differently. Very harsh when speaking. They don't listen to your request. They have huge attitudes. The host at the door was the worst! He should be fired! His service was horrible. Had a huge attitude the entire time we dined. Food was good but we just couldn't get over the service. We didn't want to tip much because it wasn't worth the service we received. Still tipped and they hounded us about it. We just left. Not worth the trouble. I wouldn't give them any more of my money unless I was dragged to. One star for good food.
author: Joe J.

description: I really wish there was an option to not give this place any stars at all. The service was horrible. What I would expect is a smile no bad looks and just serve us. My friends ended up getting sick. That's two people throwing up. The place is filthy. When we were leaving we were nice enough to leave $3 for tip. Bill was $38.35 we gave her $41.35 she counts the money in front of us and says there isn't enough. Says that we owe her a six dollar tip. Forget that!! She didn't deserve it. Won't recommend this place at all. Don't go!! Trust me!!
author: Cecily H.

description: I loved this place.  What an experience. My friends brought me to China town to explore and they brought us here. I really enjoyed it. The Mongolian beef & salt &pepper pork was amazing. The beef fried rice was so yummy. The food came out very quick. The only reason I take off a star for being over priced.
author: Nik P.

description: I almost never review, but this place was pure sh*t. Now, I was raised up in these parts and remember the good food from my childhood...and so my friend and I went in with high expectations and we were literally giddy when the food came. Sadly, the soup had no taste at all. Literally bland ... and the wontons were raw in the middle. RAW in the middle! They folded their wontons in such a way that the dough did not cook all the way through. Not fit for human consumption.
author: K P.

description: I do not know how it got this many stars but I'd like to start off my saying, STAY CLEAR FROM DRINKING THEIR WATER! I must say I've never been to such a place that the water had such a strong odor. and plus they get it from the tap with no filter but it may have been mold build up or something in their faucet. It was actually really disturbing. The food was not all that great either. The service was absoltely horrible. Its only lasting still because it is in San Francisco. Sigh.. never wanted to write this kind of review but the people need to know!
author: Sothary C.

description: Food was fair. Waitress was lazy, never refilled water, sat and ate her own food then added a 20% tip because according to the manager she was doing us a favor since we weren't from here....Texas is in US. Ripped off!!! Manager did nothing when we asked.
author: Annette P.

description:
So if you call and talk to them in Cantonese, they WILL take reservations.

You still get the same rude service though, it's part of the experience.
author: Caroline C.

description:
food: tasty, but pricey and i've had better at that price point and better at lower price point. 
atmosphere: it is that chinatown calling. 

Summary: good to go for fun in a group. Don't think I will go back though unless I had to for some reason.
author: P L.

description:
We had to hurry for a quick lunch and the other place around the corner that we've tried before had shuttered.  Hubby wanted to try Yuet Lee because of the raves in the past.  I think it's gone downhill.  The place needs remodeling - badly.  It's not a good sign when most of the diners there are tourists.  
We tried:
Beef with bean cake rice, $6.25.  Some beef slices, sliced tofu, slivers of carrots in a gravy over rice.  Not so good, but hubby liked it.
Beef stew won ton soup, $6.  The beef stew pieces were tough, chewy. As if it wasn't cooked long enough.  The won tons were large, with chunks of shrimp mixed into the pork - some of the meat wasn't cooked through, still pink.  

Maybe we didn't order the right dishes, but YL wouldn't be the 1st place I'd come back to for Chinese food.
author: Ry T.

description:
I'm a fan.   But it was ' a okay!!'
We went there late night   My son & his Arch classmates had a good experience here .. And from the looks of the food , it all looked fantastic ... Welllll!!!.. We mistakenly got take out.. Mistake one 
Then we ordered the standard Chinese faire.. Shrimp fried rice , beef & Chinese veggies ...and chow mein
While waiting for our order we watched as many delicious plates of food emerged from the tiny cubby hole kitchen, which is situated smack dab in middle of the restaurant .  At one table a group of older gentlemen had their wine bottles set up , waiting for their feast ..  
I guess we showed our tourist badge ... 
We returned to our hotel, with our 'takeout '.. & we where disappointed .. The shrimp must have disappeared , in the shrimp fried rice .. The chowmein was so so , but the beef n veggies was pretty decent 

We will go back , ESP now that I saw the restaurant profiled on new Tavel channel show
author: Debra S.

description:
Came here for some rice porridge and was surprised by how poor the service is. I know I came in sweats, since I live just a block away, but the waitress treated me like I was a teenage delinquent. I wanted just the plain rice porridge, and she immediately grabbed my menu away from me and said that they don't serve that, and gave me a look to imply that I should leave. 

I was confused why there was no rice porridge, since it is listed plainly on their menu, so I asked if it is an item that is just out today (weird for a staple food item to be out before the dinner hour even hits). She said that I was not allowed to order the plain rice porridge on its own and could only get it if I bought it in conjunction with another porridge that had meat in it. I don't think that they should list an item on the menu if they won't sell it, and I think that if she didn't want to sell me the rice porridge on its own, she should have let me look through the menu still and pick another item instead of hastily dismissing me.

I don't usually let one experience at a restaurant discourage me from ever returning again, but after today's trip, I can say plainly that I will never come back again.
author: Melody L.

description: They say they're open, but when you try to place an order they tell you they're not open and give you an attitude. Completely unappreciated and disrespectful. This place is terrible.
author: Penny B.

description: Late night munchies? This is not the place to go. Yes, Yuet Lee has been featured on tv/newspapers and a celebrity spotting site in the house but seriously I found the vicinity to be disgusting. I came here on a late night after hours and the restaurant was packed. Customer service was awful, our waitress barely spoke english, never smiled, and used a dirty towel to wipe our table. When we received our food, I saw the most outrageous thing-COCKROACHES climbing the wall next to my table! Food: is okay-aka drunk food, as it is located on broadway. I lost my appetite after my horrible experience.
author: Kathy V.

description:
Good food but went up 100% in price the last 5 years thanks to Anthony Bourdain. Founder in black bean sauce is tasty. 
Update: This place closed down
author: Belgian D.

description: Customer Service - is none existent. There are no friendly smiles or welcome feelings. Cleanliness is a major down fall. When a cup of hot tea (served in a tall thin plastic cup) fell over on the table they used the rag they keep by the cash register, the same rag they used to wipe dirty tables over and over to clean off our table while food was on the table. Instead of picking up the plates to clean he allowed the dirty tag to rub the platters the food was on.
author: Nicholas D.

description:
Not gonna come back here anymore!!!! CUSTOMER SERVICE SUCKS!! FOOD was ok.....
Watch out for the guy waiter wearing glasses sucks!!!! BOO!!!
author: Day S.

description:
If you like mediocre ingredients hastily prepared, laden with goopy corn starch, and indifferently presented on plastic plates -- and if you enjoy overpaying for all that -- this is the restaurant for you. Atmosphere is not good and service is indifferent.

It's a tourist trap. You can do so much better in the same neighborhood for less money.
author: aaron c.

description:
Not sure how this got the best chinese in SF by anyone.
Food is average, decent amount of MSG
Noodles were more dry then fresh.
It's average by SE Rose City standards.
There is much better spots then this in SF.
But for the price, it's your typical dive chinese spot.
author: Andrew S.

description: This had to be close to the worst Chinese food I've ever had in San Francisco's Chinatown. Ordered beef chow fun with no bean sprouts and added Chinese broccoli. Super oily, tasteless, only goid thing was the meat was tender and not overcooked. The Young Chow fried rice had the smallest shrimp I've ever had in fried rice. The tenderloin beef was tender and cooked medium / medium rare.  Good, but not special enough to warrant the $17 price. Maybe the food is better during the day, but I doubt it. Thay say they are best for seafood but everything else was below par.
author: Scott B S.

description: The Mandarin Spare Ribs are absolutely awesome.  Fucking awesome.  They will put you in a food coma, however, even with the tea.  But yum, yum, yum.
author: Joe E.

description:
Whenever I go to SF, I always come here for lunch! This place is quite small with little amount of tables but their food is bomb!!! The food here is seriously the closest to authentic food from China that I've tasted. Hands down best beef chow fun I have tasted! I just love how thin the noodles are and the amount of "wok hay" (smokiness from cooking on a wok) is just right. I'm not a big fan of bean sprouts, so I substitute it with bok choy. I also love their Wonton noodles! Noodles are not soggy and the shrimp in the wonton is perfect. 

The service is good. The lady is prompt. I always get the same server. I think she recognizes my family and I even though we don't go to SF frequent. The prices are reasonable for what you get. It's also cool to see all the pictures of celebrities along with their autograph on the wall.
author: Cindy A.

description: Meeehhhhh. I like New Sun Hong Kong better...though this place is cheaper.
author: Margaret R.

description: Had family style with my bf and nearly ate everything on each plate. Great if you're looking for good food and fast service.
author: Dee P.

description:
I have been coming here for 30+ years and the food is delicious and service is lightening fast. I have never been disappointed in the food, service (fast, non nonsense and courteous), or atmosphere. 

Salt and pepper squid
Clams with black bean sauce
Any of the rice porridge soups
Steam stuffed tofu YUM
Clay pot!
shrimp with bok choy

special soy sauce with sliced fresh chili peppers...a must to any meal

Sit down, order, and enjoy. Don't expect them to fold your paper napkin when you get up to use the bathroom (it is much better than it was pre-remodel)...but do know you will have a satisfying meal.
author: Liz C.

description: Pretty tasty. Added benefits are it's significantly cleaner than most Chinatown restaurants, my waitress spoke English, and they take credit cards.
author: Tony E.

description: This place was my old stomping ground. If you guys know Timmy, it's the only place you can get Chinese tea past 2 am before they got their alcohol license. I remember the days when they had baby chicken, their oysters were fresh and steamed to perfection, their peaking spare rib, Singapore noodles and beef chow fun could not be beat. Sadly, however, within the last 10-12 years I've  experienced a downward trend on their food quality. I ate their a week ago and not only was I disappointed with the total bill, but with the quality of food which has been the poorest Ive ever had since eating at this place for over 30 years. Unless I'm dragged down there and don't have to pay, I'd order the salt and pepper squid and maybe the on choy but nothing else.
author: Sammy G.

description:
Ate here twice, got food poisoning the second.

It's one of the only places open really late in Chinatown, and the food is passable - if you are willing to take a gamble.
author: Aaron P.

description: When I hear the name Yuet Lee I know I'm in for a treat! I have been here many of times never on once have I been disappointed!!! I recommend this place to all who love authentic Hong Kong style food. I only gave them 4 stars due to a couple of reasons! # 1 Cash only.# 2 waiters are rude most of the time. # 3 parking in that area sucks!!! So besides all that the food is great!!!
author: Duke Of Frisco X.

description:
4th edit . . .

Redux

 -and the pork belly layered between ENORMOUS slices of taro too too HOT as the clay pot it came in.  -as well as the oysters/roast pig clay pot casserole . . .

-and, tonight . . .
We 3 extant maîtres d' boldly asked for a round table set for six, knowing our food would not fit on the 30"x30" square one by the window. **

Ordering -
** HOW CAN THE PLACE BE SOLD OUT OF PORK BELLY/TARO CLAY POT at 6 p.m.???  I was so shattered by the adamant waitress' blatant announcement that I couldn't regroup for the whole time we had to go to plan B . . .

Mustard greens yolk swirl soup
Fried white-battered calamari
Famous black bean sauce clams
Salty egg steamed pork patty
Crispy prawns chow mein
Oysters/roast pig in clay pot
Mango sweet & sour chicken
Steamed rice

-Forgot to order the Tomato beef crispy noodles!

A++ (One LARGE minus for not having the pork belly/taro casserole.)

Rock on,

Aloha,

C
author: Clifford L.

description: The service was excellent and quick. The food was delicious. It's small but homey. I recommend the Peking ribs. They are awesome.
author: Rosemary G.

description:
Came here yesterday night with a bunch of people for dinner. I would never eat here if I had to make the choice but I guess it is a better choice than eating at the DnA aka Broadway Cafe which was the original pick. 

The restaurant gives off the super Chinese feel. We ordered like six dishes. The duck had like no meat. We ordered two beef dishes. That was alright and the choy was good. The clay pot of chicken and oysters sure had a lot of unappetizing chicken. The fish was alright. 

It is like a place in those HK movies where those gangsters eat and hang out and start gang fights.
author: Sarah C.

description:
After many visits over many years to SF this place has long been my favorite hole in the wall in China Town.  It is actually on the border of North Beach/China town just a couple blocks from Columbus.

I ALWAYS get the oft raved about Pepper and Salt Roasted Fresh Squids ($13.25).  This is one of the best squid dishes I have had the pleasure of partaking in.....ever!  A little salty, a whole bunch crispy and very meaty.  Divine stuff indeed.

Took the lady friend for her first time here and she wanted some basic food as we were starving from the long drive from OC.  She chose the Braised Noodles With Ginger And Onions.  These are thin, about the size of vermicelli.  It was subtle in its complexity with VERY fresh julienned ginger, nice dish.

We also settled on Young Chow Fried Rice that was your typical Chinese rice dish with bay shrimp and pork.  

All of this came from the tiny kitchen that is no more than 10 steps away so hot one has to wait a few minutes for it to cool.  I usually come here for a late lunch, so can't speak to the late drunken crowds yelped on but everything I have had here has been great, even while sober.  This time the squid was a little oily but the oil was not greasy, just a tad heavy handed going into the wok.

Make sure you check out the kitchen, I love how every square inch is utilized with woks and pans steaming away.  And to address some of the complaints re; surly service; thats just the way it is in these old school Chinese places.  I dont let their weary persona deter me from cheerily greeting them and I often garner a smile.  Try it, I find it to be a fun exercise!

Loved that they sport a yelp sticker on their window!
author: Dan H.

description:
The food came out freakishly fast.  From what I recall I want to say it tasted great * but my group just finished boozing at Hustlers anniversary party.  We were in the VIP area so we took full advantage of their generous open bar. 

Beef Chow Fun: greasy but the beef was tender
Clams with black bean sauce:  Winner!!

That's all I can recall from the evening... well that and some tranny waiving hello to my group, "hey Asian boys!"  OMG!!!

*results may vary  =D
author: Sun T.

description: So delicious! Love the salt and pepper calamari, beef chow fun, and the sweet and sour pork chops! Everything is so good actually. LOVE!
author: Lisa J.

description: I was feeling a bit hungry because the Moroccan food I had for dinner didn't seem too satisfying.  It was good cuisine, a belly dancer put on quite a show and all, but it was finger foods, you know?  So I made the trek to Chinatown, specifically to Yuet Lee, for some no nonsense, old fashioned comfort food.  I had a Tsingtao beer, plain won ton and clams in pepper, black bean sauce.  The food hit the spot!  I left full & with a grin on my face.  I'm just a simple Chinese man....
author: Michael L.

description: Okay, so I'm a hypocrite and have obviously been back countless times since I wrote my original review. Good calamari, and Justine H. (aka Homer Simpson) loooooves the chow mein. Ask her about it.
author: Suany W.

description:
Food poisoning late Sunday.  I could taste something was off but kept going....
Feeling like crap for 1.5 days and counting.  

Note to restaurant - check your food prep!  I wont ever be going back.
author: David R.

description: Excellent meal. We had pork and shrimp fried rice, ginger oysters in clay pot, salt and pepper pork chop , shrimp chow mein, sea food shopping. How we got here at 5 o'clock and then we were early we got 15% off our bill!
author: Stacy F.

description: I honestly would give this place no stars if I could. I got food poisoning from eating their beef w/ pepper and black bean sauce. My family members had upset stomachs as well. Simply said, I would not recommend this place to anyone. Don't be fooled by the chef's pics with the celebrities placed on the outside wall. This place is nothing to rave about.
author: Tracy N.

description: While not the most aesthetically pleasing or cleanest restaurant in Chinatown, Yuet Lee offers high-quality, authentic Chinese food. The pea shoots are fresh, tender and well-seasoned. Another great dish to try is their Beef and Tomato Over Rice. Noodle lovers should go for the Pan-Fried Noodles. Overall a nice dinner in a decent ambient environment.
author: Derek F.

description: This place is awesome, crispy fried noodles, salt and pepper prawns, black bean clams. I really haven't had anything on the menu that wasn't amazing.
author: Max I.

description: I've been coming here for 30 of the 38 years it's been here and it's just as good today as it has been over the years. Where else can you get a tasty meal at 11:30pm. They don't have the friendliest of people but at least they are consistent.
author: Andrea S.

description: No other words than....AWFUL!!! What a bad experience for our friends from France who wanted to try good Chinese food and good service..and they didn't get ANY. The food was served in SMALL PORTIONS and OVER PRICED. Too oily!! Moreover, the service was UNACCEPTABLE!! They included 20% to the bill saying it was for the MANDATORY tip...(they said it was 15% but we did the math..20%). We got mad and we left less than 10% and the waitress came over saying "that's why we put the tip in the bill, because you people don't leave anything" . She was mad..but it got worse. The owner's brother came over trying to defend her employees saying that the tip on the bill is not mandatory, it's just a suggestion, but we told him he shouldn't do that. He got also mad and KICKED US OUT of the restaurant. He even threw our tip on the floor..but of course, he picked it up later. The worst part came after I realized I forgot my sunglasses and left them on the table. When I came back...my sunglasses were gone. All the employees said they didn't see any sunglasses..BULLSHIT!! My sunglasses were there...I saw the waitress cleaning the table when we were arguing with the owner (we were very calm, just talking, the owner's brother started YELLING..so LOW CLASS ). They STOLE my sunglasses!!! in revenge??!?! they can't just buy their own?? This never happened to me before..so disappointed in this restaurant. For sure, I will never come back to this place and I hope whoever is reading this feedback, think twice before going to this place. NOT WORTH IT!! just go around the corner, and you will find other Chinese restaurants that will offer better service than this one. SUCH AN AWFUL PLACE RUN BY DISHONEST PEOPLE...JUST DON'T GO!!
author: Patricia C.

description: Man, for a touristy restaurant that I've avoided all 24 years I've been alive, this place really isn't that bad. After you order, you get everything within 5 minutes, which is kind of ridiculous (in a super speedy, awesome way). For a Chinese restaurant, the prices suck, but tourists won't know that. Also, you get greasy food at all hours of the night. I don't see anything wrong with that MSG-laden dream.
author: Danny C.

description:
AWFUL! HORRIBLE SERVICE! They have two waitress both with glasses but WATCH OUT for the younger one with round face and short hair as she is extremely rude as she is blatantly told me that I don't tip her enough which is over 20%! also the foods is overly priced!

AVOID THIS PLACE AT ALL COST!
author: Ryu K.

description:
I read all the reviews here and I agree with most.  The food is NOT cheap mainly because it is a huge tourist attraction now, but even with that they still serve decent food here.  I agree it is not very clean but aren't most of the best places hole in the walls? Great late night spot and the best dish in the house is the deep fried intestines..... especially when your hungry...

Over all the food is very good here.....
author: King L.

description:
Food - 3 stars   /  Service & Cleanliness - 2 stars

I was looking for a late night place to eat and the folks at the Renaissance  in Nob Hill recommended this place.

Well, the place was hopping at midnight. I had their beef chow fun which was quite good. The speciality here is sea food and definitely what others were eating looked quite good. That's the positive. 

The service is surly and rude. That would be OK if it weren't for the fact that the place was mess. To top it off, the owner decide to take the garbage out to the curb through the restaurant. That was a total deal killer. He dragged two smelly dumpsters from the kitchen into the main dining hall out the front door.  Fricking disgusting.

Your mileage may vary - be warned of the crap service and the overall hygiene of this place.

There are much better places to eat in Chinatown and much better late night choices in the city.

I will never go back to this place.
author: Shah S.

description: I ate here early August '13. Seeing the staff make wontons at a table in full view brought back warm memories from NY Chinatown as a child. Unfortunately the wontons and soup were very bland. The ginger scallion Dungeness crab was delicious. Actually anything you put in that sauce would be delicious. I'll try the many other nearby restaurants before returning though.
author: Gantsa Maven Z.

description:
After numerous visits to SF, we decided to finally give Yuet Lee a try.  No where near the quality of Chinese food in the San Gabriel Valley but okay for what seems to be a tourist trap.  Here's the run down:

1.  Salt & Pepper Squid.  Best dish of the night.  Well seasoned.  My son's favorite dish.
2.  Seafood Chow Mein (crispy noodle).  Good dish but way too small for the price.  Usually, chow mein comes on a huge platter with lots of noodles to go around.
3.  Roast pork and Catfish Hotpot with black beans.  Not the "fermented black bean" style I had hoped for.  There were real whole black beans in the dish.  

Overall an okay experience but overpriced.
author: Iakona C.

description:
The family and I ate dinner at Yuet Lee the night before attending Outside Lands in Golden Gate Park. 
The first time we ate here was roughly 6 years ago, maybe more. We loved it then and nothing has changed. 
We arrive, we order, I ran to the restroom and upon returning suggested we time them on it. The food arrived before I could get the timer going on my phone. 
We ordered:
Salt and Pepper Squid ( a MUST!) Beef Fried Rice, BBQ Pork chow mein, and a half duck. We got all of that food in about 6 minutes; all fresh, piping hot and so delicious. 
Plenty of food for all! (4)
author: Carrie G.

description: I haven't been to this place in a while, but I remember loving it so much when I lived in SF. I ate here several times. This is the kind of restaurant that does stir fried things well. And deep fried things, too, for that matter. Also, the lobster is good.
author: Melanie M.

description: Better at lunch than late-night, but I'm always thankful for the after-midnight shift!
author: Molly D.

description: My friends took me here for a late night dinner after the bars in north beach. It was packed at 2:30am! the food was pretty good! but they forgot 2 of our dishes we ordered. but it was good for late night chinese food!
author: Brian B.

description:
One of my favorite Chinese (HK style) restaurants! The food is amazing sober or drunk. 
 
Come here to grub after a night of debauchery. Their open till 3am Fridays/Saturdays!  

We always order: 
Lots of Tsingtaos!
Steamed Fish
Beef Chow Fun
Black Bean Clams
roast duck
salt and pepper calimari
Chicken & Shitaki Mushroom Porridge
author: Maggie L.

description: Went with my wife, she had a noodle soup I had sweet and sour Schrimps.  I loved it and she did too. Service was really good, very prompt and very polite. This is probably how the restautants look back in Bejing but I wish it was more clean, it felt a bit dirty, hence the 4 stars. Would I go back? Absolutely.
author: Theodoros K.

description: I've been here so many times!! And also satisfied with the food, and still trying the new dish, good always.
author: Fanny Z.

description:
SALT SALT SALT SALT SALT SALT SALT

I think the place is desperately overrated.  Well, maybe not overrated, but it definitely doesn't deserve such name recognition.

Well the service was good, and price somewhat reasonable (about $40 for three dishes and a beer)

I had the deep fried pork chop, wonton soup, and some spicy chicken dish.  I won't even bother to remember the proper names of the dishes as I won't be returning here.

The food was super salty... though this place gained its fame from being a late-night drunken snack shop, I won't be stumbling in this doorstep. Ever.
author: Eugene L.

description:
The very first time I ever visited San Francisco was Christmas of 1985. At the time I was seeing a guy who lived in the Bay Area. That very first trip sealed my love affair with the city and I vowed that one day I would live there.

On that very first visit, my then boyfriend took me to Yuet Lee. I remembered thinking how authentic the food was and how much I enjoyed it considering I'd been living in Eugene Oregon and they're definitely not known for their great Asian food.

Fast forward 13 years and I'm living in the Bay Area and of course Yuet Lee is one of those restaurants where you know you'll always find something comforting. My favorite is to get the eggplant claypot or the chicken, salted fish and tofu claypot. These 2 dishes always seem to make the day seem brighter.

I don't usually go to Chinatown when I'm in search of great Chinese food. The Sunset district seems to house more authentic establishments. To me, only tourists go to eat in Chinatown, however, there are still one or two places which will satiate your tummy as well as your palate without emptying your wallet. Yuet Lee is one of those places.
author: Anita L.

description:
Came here at 1am and loved that they were still open. We had a few of their items, but remember getting their mango chicken, I would not get this again even though it was on their "special menu".

everything else was decently good.
author: Eric A.

description: Smelled like rotten mop water. Cock roach on the wall. I was afraid to even eat the food. Had steamed rice, seriously, it tasted funky (like they made it with the mop water), my boyfriend seemed satisfied with his soup. I tried the soup broth to see if it would make my rice any better, it was not good either.
author: Norma G.

description:
My favorite Chinese seafood restaurant. (Well, to be fair, the only Chinese seafood restaurant I can ever remember going back to, but that's besides the point). 

My 5 star faves: Salt and Pepper Shrimp with Garlic, Black Bean Sauce Flounder with Asparagus, Salty Fish and Chicken Fried Rice. I've had a few other things like black bean sauce chicken, porridge - pretty decent. 

This is Chinatown - the expectation was set a long, long time ago. It means you have to remind yourself before you go, that you're not coming for the service or the ambiance, you're coming for the food - otherwise,  you'll be sorely disappointed.
author: Candy C.

description:
So after working dinner shift valentine's day, I was exhausted and FAMISHED. We were so busy that I didn't get a chance to piss! Needless to say, we all got no dinner either. 
We tried to eat at Oola but the scary hostess (she had real bad makeup okay?) told us the wait was 45 minutes to an hour. We're restaurant folks so we figured "Okay, she must just be SAYING that in case, yanno?" WRONG! She said "No really, the wait is about an hour"

FUCK IT, WE'RE GOING TO CHINATOWN!

Ahhh neighborhood of my peoples...

Yuet Lee - you saved my life last night. 
Gai lan, ngow naam, kidneys, LOBSTER, steamed fish and 4 glasses of cheap Sutter Home chardonnay..

Susy C. was happy.

Thank you for being open so fucking late.
Thank you for carding me for alcohol - that really cracked me up.
Thank you to the waitstaff for talking to me in Chinese. I hate it when Chinese folk assume I can't speak it just because i'm ABC.

Funny moment - there's a no left turn sign and we saw a car make a left. He was IMMEDIATELY pulled over and the ENTIRE waitstaff started talking about it in Chinese "ooooh they got one! they got one! what an idiot, made a left with a cop right behind him... WHAT!? THEY'RE LETTING HIM GO!??!"

ahhahahahahhahahaa late night Chinese food AND entertainment!
author: Susy C.

description:
I would have given this place a higher rating but the food made me nauseous. ):

I love how late this place opens, until 3am! Great for night owls like myself and those alike, but  I wouldn't come here again.

I ordered a simple won ton noodle soup and it was a mouthful of msg. Up until recently, I was fine dining out at Chinese food establishments. However, my stomach couldn't take it anymore and I could no longer eat msg filled meals. 

I had painful heartburn and nausea upon arriving home...

Perhaps, I should request no msg in my meal the next time? But I feel like it's all pre-made in advance. There's no use..
author: Amy C.

description:
the waiter is very mean. he charged us tip on the bill and didn't tell us( we only 3 people and order in $40 total). If we didn't find it, we will pay extra tip to them.

after we complained, the boss told us that this kind charge is according to government request. It is a lie.

The food is ok. But i think they do this way to cheat customer many times.
author: Alex L.

description:
this place isn't very big but i like that the kitchen is exposed and you can see what the cooks are doing. no shady business going on here!
