among 6 people, we got the salt and pepper pork, salt and pepper calamari, steamed fish, sizzling spare ribs in a clay pot, water spinach, beef chow fun, beef and bittermelon, clams in black bean sauce, and the mushroom and chicken porridge. everything was pretty good. the salt and pepper pork was so good we ended up getting two orders. the sizzling spare ribs in clay pot is also worth trying. i normally don't like bittermelon but the bittermelon in the beef dish wasn't very bitter and it was sauteed with big pieces of tender beef. 

it was about 180 for everything we ordered, including 5 beers. we all left full, happy and thirsty.
author: Bobbie W.

description:
For post 2am meals, it's hard to hate on this place. 

Straight up Cantonese fare. Stick with the standards: pan fried noodles, black bean sauce clams, salt & pepper prawns, shrimp with scrambled egg.

Because of the high turnover, the seafood here is actually pretty fresh.
author: Derrick V.

description: The worst service I've ever experienced ! I have been to many Chinese restaurants and have experienced service that has been far from perfect, but this one takes the cake for the worst I've ever experienced. We took a seat and the Asian lady took my friend and I's order. Everything was okay up until the Asian man with gray hair and glasses began to stare at us THE ENTIRE TIME WE ATE. He occasionally walks by every couple of minutes and just stands next to us as we eat. I couldn't eat because he just stared at us and I felt so disrespected. When they came to get the payment, the cook came out and said, "no tip"? We were going to pay the full price then tip afterwards but we ended up just throwing a dollar on and just left. The absolute worst spot to eat. If you want Chinese food, I deeply hope you reconsider this spot and go to one close by.
author: Clarence M.

description:
4.5 stars for the beef chow fun, made even better as a late night meal at midnight. Amazing. 

Fish & pork liver congee, simple, light but good flavor. Of course the "fon huerng" (rice fragrant) has been better at other places (usually in HK itself) but that's so hard to find anyway.

This is a typical gaudy Chinese restaurant that a typical Chinatown tourist would skip bc it's tacky but then take a 2nd look bc it's full of Chinese ppl. Then they would enjoy this authentic Chinese food.
author: L. B.

description:
the food is pretty decent here...after a night out with the boys bar hopping in northbeach..we frequent this little place..(our choices are usually limited to yuet lee or new sun hong kong...)....

this is the place for the "yuet lee test"..what is the yuet lee test?..if we happen to come across some girls at bars or clubs...our beer goggles and darkness limit our vision..so we enter yuet lee...always brightly lit up with florescent lights....and you get your clear view....the "yuet lee test"...it's pretty "dive" in here...
author: Hen A.

description: THIS PLACE WAS MY SPOT.  I used to go at least 2-3 times a week for years.  It was open late, and in the right neighborhood for what I was doing at that time.  Egg Foo Yung was OFF THE HOOK.  There wasn't anything bad to order there.
author: Aaron F.

description: You definitely do not come for the service but the food is authentic Chinese.  The fried rice was tasty. The chow mien was yummy! The thin noodles were great! The Kung pow chicken was delish!  The BBQ pork was more tender than most!  We were not disappointed in the food! Servers could be more friendly BUT in the end they got the job done... We would come back!
author: Hilary M.

description: 4 STARS - for great , awesome greasy Chinese food open late.  Its a great place to grab some salty, greasy food after the bars close. This place is always crowded after 2:00 am . Love the Calamari and panfriend noodles. Will always come back her for some late grub!
author: Claudine V.

description:
I've been hear sober for a nice family dinner and slightly buzzed for late night grub and the only take away is: overpriced and overrated.  Yes the food tastes good, but $40 for 3 non-seafood entrees is absurd.  Maybe they have a menu with jacked-up prices for non-Chinese speaking Chinese people?

Either way the food tastes decent but is tinged by a bitterness of "I could have gotten more food that tastes just as good for $10-$15 less."
author: Krystle S.

description:
4.5 Stars out of 5.  Excellent quality for SF Chinatown, one of the filthiest, rat infested Districts in SF.

The juk was good here, but this isn't place to go to for juk.   I had a beef juk and they were generous with the cilantro. Yum!  I once had a crab dish pronounced something like "'bae foeng tong" which is "Chiu Chau" style which is very good.  I hate crab (unless it's softshell) because it takes too much effort to eat.  This is the only crab I look forward to eating.  It's fried and has a quasi-tempura like coating to it.

The wonton noodle soup was very good.  What impressed me about it were the freshness of the noodles.

This is the best late night Chinese restaurant in SF Chinatown.  Very good quality and reliable.
author: Tony U.

description:
Yummy place after all the bars close. Love their beef chow fun, clams in black bean sauce, and stir fry ong choy. Beware of the bright lights after bar hours here. Might be a scary sight (coyote ugly).

Cheap eats, fast service, and fast delivery of food.

Yum.
author: Eva Y.

description:
Dudes, get over the dirtiness and just enjoy the food! Delicious, authentic chinese food. But of course, like a lot of other authentic chinese dining establishments, you can order dishes that aren't necessarily on the english menu if you speak their language  = \

I highly recommend the salt & pepper squid and steamed fish. Tasty!

The downside of this place? Parking. But to enjoy food at yuet lee, I don't mind parking next to a dumpster.
author: Ari C.

description: This was a great experience along with great food with great friends. The food was amazing. That calamari and the fried rice and the Peking spare ribs all hit the spot and our group was craving for more. Friendly staff that catered to us, asked us if we needed anything and would clean up our emptied dishes without us having to ask. Definitely coming here again!
author: Lynna O.

description:
I ordered a new dish called Crispy garlic prawns chow mein and I wasnt impressed at all, the photo looked better than the one they brought out and the noodles were not crispy, it was a little too salty for me, plus it was $14.95

thats alot more than chow mein usually costs, I thought it was going to be something special, but it was not any better than the lower priced regular orders of chow mein, I felt like I over paid , the shrimp /prawns were the cheap small type 

with a tip the total was about $18 for a salty plate of chow mein, I dont think I would be comming back unless I didnt have another choice

nothing really great about this restaurant, it's over-rated in my opinion , but the service was very fast

I did see Jackie Chan's photo on the wall, he must have been here before
author: Mr Bolo B.

description: The food is outstanding and I have now found a new favorite place in Chinatown FINALLY! The other reviews about the staff being rude is a bunch of bullshit, maybe certain customers need to check their ego's in at the door. The hours are great also for a late night bite.
author: J.P. H.

description:
OVERALL:1.4   FOOD:1   SERVICE:1.5   AMBIANCE:2   VALUE:1

Oh.  Em.  Gee.  This place blows giant useless balls. When 'ambiance' is the highlight of a Chinatown dining experience, you KNOW it's trouble. Totally overpriced, touristy, and gross.

I don't know what's more embarrassing--having to associate this with my heritage or admitting that I've actually voluntarily eaten here. TWICE.  What's that nugget of Southern wisdom?  'Fool me once, shame on you; fool me twice.....?? heh well, you git my drift...'  

I'll just save y'all the trouble and keep it short:
DON'T EAT HERE (no, not even the salt-n-pepper squid)!!!
author: Amy K.

description: Food was good, prices were fair. I was by no means blown away but it was delicious none the less.
author: Sam W.

description:
I was here with my friend below my review (Raquel) Hi Raquel!!
lol. The service here sucks! The guy taking our order was getting frustrated at us for not being ready to order! Gees, give us a minute to read the menu! Oh yeah...another boo about this place is they don't take CC on orders below $20. 

The oh so recommended salt and pepper squid was really not all that and a bag of chips. I make better calamari than this, and I rarely cook. The calamari was dry and not flavorful,I had to use soy sauce to give this dish some flavor! And this dish was $17 or something ridiculous like that.  Overall, this dish is honestly no bueno. 

But on the other hand, the Beef fried rice was bomb!! The beef was juicy and flavorful, with plenty of beef in the plate not just rice. The rice was good, not dry, or not too mushy. Price was kind of high too but worth it because it's yummy!

Won ton noodle soup is worth it! Hahah my friend was complaining that they only gave her 2 wontons but they actually gave her 4 after she ate half of the bowl, she discovered there were two more hidden underneath the noodles. I didn't get to try it but it looked really good and it was only $6 ! 

So, eat here if you are semi drunk after the clubs on Broadway. Make sure you bring cash!
author: Coco T.

description:
Perfect late night Chinese joint after stomping up & down Broadway on a Saturday night.

BEST SHRIMP WITH SCRAMBLED EGGS. EVER. HANDS DOWN.

Good fried rice too.
author: Allison P.

description:
Exhausted and starving from walking around billions of hills on a hot day, I decided to stop here and have a quick bite while waiting to meet a friend.  I was attracted by a banner on the outside that said 15% off early bird special 4:30-6:30, as well as the tank of live crabs and fish.  I love watching wiggly crabs and big dopey fish!

I was the only person in the restaurant so got a little more attention than I would like, but in general I really enjoyed my time here.  I got a nice big soup and some beer.  I wish I remember what the soup was called - it was really tasty and had rice noodles, chicken and mushrooms among other things.  The bowl was large and reasonably priced.

As a tourist, it was really great to come here and be able to relax right by a window, have a great meal and people-watch.  They have tons of tables right by the windows, and mine had a prime viewing spot of Stockton Street - the market across the street and the bustling crowds going through the busy intersection (Broadway?).  DC's Chinatown has long ceased to be an authentic one, and people-watching there you really just see tourists, Caps fans, and yuppies.  So I really appreciated being able to sit here in San Francisco and see a real Chinatown!

I would come back here next time I am in the area for the people-watching experience and for the reasonable "early bird" prices.  Though glancing through the menu, it seemed some of their full-price entrees are more expensive than I would have expected.  Maybe because there were a lot of seafood dishes, but still, I would think cheaper entrees could be found at some of the other restaurants around the block.  Still, the location is great and I definitely recommend this place.
author: Mattie C.

description:
More of a 3.5 star rating but I'm rounding down because I've only been there once and only ate 2 dishes. Also rounding down because it could have been cheaper for late-night munchies.

So me and my roommate were coming from a lovely night at Bar None in the Marina and were in need of some serious drunchies. Someone had suggested Golden Boy Pizza but after waiting in the ridiculous line for about 15 minutes, we decided we were too hungry to wait any longer for their clam and garlic pizza and opted for another place.

Enter Chinatown. We live in NB and wanted to eat somewhere close because 1) we were hungry and 2) we were drunk and probably not coherent enough to make it anywhere more than a few blocks away. So me and my handy-dandy Yelp app on my phone find places nearby that are open. Aka Yuet Lee. It's open 'til 3am. SO CLUTCH.

We start wandering down Stockton and find it after a few minutes. It is POPPIN'. At 2:15 in the morning! We walk in and are seated right away despite it being busy. I remember it being half-full of people ending a night out and half-full of regular people who were just finishing up their dinner. At 2am? Really? Weird. Anyways, we ordered the veggie chow mein ($7.95? I think) and clams in black bean sauce ($13.95). The order came ridiculously fast (I mean, this IS a Chinese restaurant so I guess I shouldn't really be surprised). Both were pretty good. I feel like I should update this review/rating after going back sober for a second, more complete meal. The dishes definitely satisfied, though. The bill came to $23 and the server put up with me and my roommate's sloppiness.

Definite highlight of my night: seeing a table behind us with one guy shoveling food into his mouth and the other guy slouched over with his head down on the table. Whether he was sleeping or passed out, I'm not really sure, but it gives you an idea of the kind of crowd Yuet Lee gets at 2:30 in the morning.
author: Nicole W.

description:
where else can you go and get chinese food that is great and 1am??  Yuet Lee!  Try the chicken chow mein and the wonton-  very good-  but they raised the prices!

Very tasty!
author: Dean Y.

description:
I went to this restaurant quite often because they open really late. the food taste was okay.

CONCLUSION = RECOMMENDED for LATE NIGHT!!
author: Aris L.

description: Yuet Lee serves very good food, but as far as China Town goes, you can definitely do better for cheaper.  They have late hours though, and if you're looking for a late dinner or midnight meal, this is a fantastic choice.
author: Andrew H.

description: This place is not fancy but is very good food!!! After walking around SF I was yelping a restuarant but walked across this place. I want to give it a deserving review of five stars because of the food!!
author: Christian T.

description:
Notice that there aren't a lot of Chinese locals who dine here? Totally a tourist trap. Skip it and go to one of the other Chinese restaurants in the area. There are multitudes with lower prices and larger serving sizes. 
I ate here once with a group of friends since one guy wanted to try it. Prices are more, portions are less. 

We went to D&A afterward to fill ourselves up.
author: Liana L.

description:
Here we go.  Lets start out with the food.  I had the Black Bean Chicken over rice.  The rice was great!  If I am craving Chinese food, its just not the place for me.

Two of my coworkers seemed to like their dishes better than I.  One had the Vegetarian Chow Mein.  She liked it "It was a bit greasy, but in a good Chinese food kind of way"  My other coworker had the Rice Soup.  He grew up eating it and said it was great.

The servers were very nice and the service was fast!

I will not be going back.  The fly that kept hovering my table was not the most pleasant thing ever.  When the waitress had to scare a pigeon out the door after it waddled its way in wasn't even that bad, it was quite funny.
author: George K.

description:
Dang this place is good all the old school Chinese food taste very authentic. 

Dang I wish I had a stake in this place.
author: DOM d.

description:
"Come for the Salt and Pepper Squid"

When in San Fran, you've got to get your Chinese food fix. That's what I told my visiting East-Coast friend and we sought out this place due to numerous recommendations.

After luckily finding a parking spot for our rented blue Mustang convertible a block away, we walked in and got seated right before a steady flow of customers entered. It was mostly a non-Asian group, which is always a warning sign if the ethnic group of your ethnic restaurant isn't represented that well. 

This is the bare-basics style of cheap booths and tables, with gaudy Chinese décor.  The restaurant did sport a number of celebrities photos on the wall - all endorsing the place, including Jackie Chan, Chef Emril, and Hideki Matsui.   

Service was cold yet competent and our food came out as soon as they were cooked, a few minutes after each other. 

The first dish was my favorite - Salt and Pepper Squid ($13.25). It's the current #1 in their top 10 dishes showcased on their wall. This Asian take on calamari was salty deliciousness. When dipped in the jalapeno-filled soy sauce, the squid went to the next level - the level of orgasm. 

Next came the Beef Tenderloin with Black Pepper Sauce ($15).  Since this was a recommendation from our waitress, it didn't quite meet the high expectations I had. It reminded me of an un-lemony version of one of my favorite Filipino dishes - Beefsteak Tagalog. The meat was somewhat chewy and I had to finish off a healthy mouthful since it was easier to take it in whole. The sauce was solid though and of course we ended up cleaning the plate but I wish we had a chance to try something else instead.

Our last dish was the Chef's Special Chow Mein with dry noodles ($8.75).  It had pieces of squid, shrimp, and various vegetables, but the ratio to noodles and the goods were not in our favor. Still, it was a solid dish and the sauce over the crunchy noodles helped make our meal memorable. 

By the time we left, it was creeping up to midnight and people were still coming in. It's Cantonese style Chinese food, opened late and full of flavor.

While it's still not the best Chinese food I've had, we left content and happy of the meal that satiated us, if at least for another 3 hours...
author: Jonathan C.

description: Chinese food is defined here. not a fancy restaurant, just some of the best tasting Chinese food in SF. "wok hay" (heat from the wok) is extremely good here. it's so critical when cooking with the fresh ingredients they use here.
author: Jeff W.

description: Consistently great big flavors coming out of this amazing little restaurant. Don't let the Decor or lack thereof scare you off. Dive in this dive the food is great
author: Jeff G.

description:
My husband and I eat here usually late at night. He loves this place more than I do. We like the salt and pepper squid, braised beef noodles, lemon chicken and duck ( we love duck) Next time I want to try the dumplings. 

They serve hot tea in an amber colored plastic cup, which I don't like. I wish they'd serve it in one of those Asian style tea cups instead.
author: Paula U.

description:
Excellent flavorful congee and open til 3! I have had bad experiences with boring overpriced congee, but their basic chicken congee is tasty and reasonably priced.  Recommended after a night of work or going out.

Be ready to pay cash.
author: Michael K.

description:
I have Been eating here for over 12 years and always been a favorite.
Salt an pepper squid is a must .

Pros: 
a. the food Is very fresh And extremely flavorful 
b.  Opens very late so you can finish partying in North beach and still catch a good meal

Cons: 
a.  The place is a little run down 
b. The service is not the best 
c.  Cant  find a parking spot close by.
I do recommend this place to many of my close close family and friends over all great food ,good place .
author: Roland Y.

description:
I remember the very first time I came here was around 8pm when I was about to leave SF, and I got hungry so I got the beef chow fun. It was heaven! I tried many chinese food restaurants in SF and honestly they are not very good. This chinese restaurant is awesome, but it is quite small and there are small sanitary issues such as the windows, the floor, and definitely the restroom. 

I always come here for lunch whenever I come to SF along with my mom and sister. I always ordered the Sampan porridge and it is delicious. The won ton mein is so good too. Of course you can't forget about that delicious beef chow fun. 

Good customer service and the food arrives really quick. Price is decent for the amount of food you get. Trust me there is a lot! What's funny is that there are many autographed celebrity photos hanged up on the wall.
author: Carmen A.

description: Stop in here for a quick bite. Never been here before but i would most definently come back and eat more dishes, I only ordered the BBQ Pork Fried Rice, but i'll tell you, i haven't had Fried Rice this great in a long time. Ithing that most be good at a chinese spot is fried rice and chow mein, and this place knows how to do it right.
author: Adrian A.

description:
If H.G. Wells were to place his time machine dead center in Yuet Lee and turn it on, he'd think it was broken, even as the decades actually flew by outside. Bearing that in mind, the restaurant feels like a comfortable old pair of jeans. You probably shouldn't wear it out, but you wouldn't throw it away either.

If you live or work nearby and have a hankering for some quick Chinese food, then it's worth an occasional visit. The menu presents mostly familiar fare, although it's likely they'll make any variations you might like. The one exception is they have a whole selection of jook. Having grown up on jook, I was pleased with their Shrimp Rice Soup. The rice to liquid texture was perfect, and it was nicely balanced with slivers of ginger and scallions and a generous amount of fresh shrimp.

Atmosphere: Perfect for a TV cop show buddy hangout
Service: Fast. One, two, three, food!
Price: Very affordable
Food: Straightforward. Nothing pretentious.
author: Andre E.

description:
This is the chinese food you think of when you think of chinese food being made by chinese people for chinese people.

Sure, the restaurant isn't exactly clean, the food is starchy, not really vibe-y, but the food is legit chinese and the place is open until 3am.
author: Tod L.

description:
I had been biking all day long through SF, probably exhausted and hungry so a raw cow would have tasted good to me...but let me just say this place really had amazing canto food.

Salt and pepper calamari, oyster with roast pork and ginger claypot, flounder with black bean sauce...just writing this makes me hungry for it again.  They have one of those menus where everything sounds good and the hardest part is deciding.  

The vibe is definitely very HK, so don't be surprised that the bathroom is dirty and the waitress is impatient for you to order. It's just a canto thing.
author: Eva O.

description:
I stopped by this Chinese restaurant to have dinner after work. I was offered a table, the menu was placed at for me and the waitress stepped away without a greeting or offering of what specials were currently available. 

I ordered a pork strip with greens for one person. I was told the only rice allowed with the dinner would be white steamed rice at $1.75 per helping or brown rice for $6.95 but a large bowl was only available. I decided not to have any rice with my meal. 

When I received my bill, it was $10.95 approximately. I was amazed on how small the dish and food was I had received for that price. The meal came on a small oval plate with approximately, 2 1/2 size of a kitchen ladle spoon of food.  I decided to stop at Loving Hut to buy one serving of brown rice to go at the price of $1.79, well worth it.

This restaurant is usually popular late at night and I thought I would give it a chance. To me, the small helping of food at that price is not worth it.  Not only that, I didn't feel the restaurant was that clean. 

I also noticed that a bus-person (middle aged man) put some remains for a customer in a to-go carton. All but a tablespoon portion of food was put into the container, the rest went into the bust tray with the dirty dish. He was to busy chatting with a waitress to focus. 

I also noticed one of the male bus-persons, walk out the front door standing right near it smoking a cigarette, then came back into the restaurant. I'm not sure he even washed his hands.

I used to own a maintenance company and worked in several restaurants and bars. I know what I see.

I'm moving on.
author: Donald P.

description: We were looking for a hole in the wall, but all the places in the area started to look pretty similar. We picked this one because it was zagat rated. Really good food. Saw all the reviews about rude service. We did not experience that at all. Went for lunch during the week
author: Alexis D.

description: open late. good salt and pepper calamari. cooked well, seasoned great, nice light crispy breading
author: Eugene H.

description: The reason why people think Yuet Lee serves good Chinese food is because it's 2:00 in the morning and you find yourself in North Beach, drunk and hungry, and desperate for anything greasy and oily that would help soak up all the alcohol.  So your options are limited at this hour of the day as is your judgment for what good food is, and Yuet Lee happens to be one of two Chinese restaurants opened (the other is Sun Hong Kong further down Broadway, which is even worst but at least much cheaper).  I've eaten Chinese food all my life and all over the world, and there's no other reason to eat at a place like Yuet Lee other than that.  Its prices are outrageous.  The food is mediocre at best, super greasy and oily and will likely give you the runs later.  Don't get caught up with all the celebrity photos on the wall, most of them have no idea about authentic and good Chinese food, and don't pay an average person's price when they go out to eat.  They're just playing tourist when they come here, don't get trapped!
author: Jackson Z.

description: walked in the other day with a out-of-town friend and tried their beef ribs with rice and greens. it was served within seconds but of course, it was currently empty and there was a Giants game in progress. the same dish but with chicken my friend ordered was better; the beef was too steamed or not cooked long enough and was stringy and tough, plus the bones were a bit annoying.
author: Tony L.

description: Awesome Asian cuisine we'd been looking for in SF  the beef chow fun is to die for! Wasn't a fan of the wontons in the soup, wouldn't get that again, but otherwise topped the list of favorite meals while in the city!
author: Kelly V.

description: Hell yeah!  This place is the sh*t!!!!!  Hahahahah... Mr. Lee cooks his food with mad flavor and super fast!  The specials here are amazing!  I've been here several times now and practically tried everything.  The shrimps are amazing!  The noodles are amazing!  It's authentic chinese food compared to other places in China Town.  Anyways, what I also like is when I order take out, it's a phone call and then an immediate walk to the restaurant which is less than 5 minutes away- lucky me, and the food is already being boxed for me to take home.  The food is cooked so fast and fresh!  Piping hot when I eat it at home.
author: Limzer L.

description: Probably one of San Francisco's best known Chinese restaurants. I came here regularly since I was little and the food was still good compare to decades ago. Salt and pepper squid, clam in black bean sauce, Peking spare ribs, seafood claypot, on-choy with shrimp paste, ginger & scallion crab, salt and pepper prawn, yang chow fried rice. Everything on the special menu was delicious. The service was quick and attentive. Downside: this place need a little bit improvement and not so clean (typical Chinese place).
author: GeekyDino S.

description: This is a place my parents have been taking me for years. Dishes I highly recommend are the wonton soup, clams in oyster sauce, clay pots, and the chow mein. The service is some of the fastest around. Somehow everything is cooked with a few minutes. The portions are huge so I recommend ordering approximately 2 dishes for every 3 people who is at a table. Some dishes that I did not mention are excellent while others are just okay. This place is open real late, especially on the weekends.
author: Ben U.

description:
I must admit, when I ate at Yuet Lee, it was late night - after 2 a.m.  The line at Sun Hong Kong (or whatever it's called at the corner of Broadway and Columbus) was way too long; my friends and I wanted to eat....and quickly.  When we arrived, there was no wait - woo hoo!  Since I had already had a big dinner, I wanted to be "healthy" and ordered the won ton noodle soup.  Bleh - pretty flavorless, so sad as won ton noodle soup is one of my favorite foods.  The rest of the dishes my friends ordered all seemed to be pretty good, especially the beef chow fun.

By the time we were leaving, the place was packed - clearly the place to go if Sun Hong Kong is full and you have an itch for Chinese food...  And honestly, at $6 per person, what's not to like??
author: Wendy L.

description:
ANOTHER CHEAP DRUNK FOOD SPOT

drunk? hungry? near broadway? baller on a budget? feet hurt and need to rest bar hopping? yah this is the place for you. I've been here once after the bar hopping on broadway. chinese food was good for what you pay for. Always a packed place after the clubs. Just make sure what they serving you is really beef.

http://sanfrancisco.menupages.com/screenmenu.asp?restaurantId=8425&htmllink=6CEA8E1529CCB6D5C6DF461A2BC0117E95A92A2319C9C8689DA42F210F07C97607083F92758FC98B&taglineid=0
author: Jane A.

description: Half as tasty and twice as pricey as New Sun HK for post partying grub. Only go here if the other nearby places around Broadway are closed or packed and you really need to eat after partying.
author: Alex P.

description: This is a great restaurant. Went here for lunch today everything was yummy and cheap.
author: Anna Richel R.

description:
So this place is really amazing, if you're Chinese, which I am. I think a lot of other people didn't enjoy their meal services here due to language barriers or they felt that the waiters were pushy (I mean, they are trying to get you to buy more stuff.)

So here I am trying to tell you what to get and that's that. Hopefully, it'll aid you in your ordering. :D

I do order in english most of the time unlike my Dad because I don't speak cantonese, only mandarin (which they do understand...)

So anyway, order the salt and pepper crab. This is a highlight on the menu! Alright, so if you want to compare it to R&G restaurant at the edge of Chinatown, don't. This one costs about half of what R&G costs, and is still rather good. It's messy, so be prepared! 

Next to order if you're up for fried food would be the salt and pepper squid, I know you're gonna insist it's essentially the same, but look, you don't need to do much work here, just stick a fork in the squid and put it in your mouth!

Also, the ribs here are fabulous... Dripping in sauce or lightly grilled/fried. One of my staples is the fried rice with salted fish and chicken. Honestly not many people like salted fish, so order with discretion. Its more of an Asian thing, so try it before ordering it in such a large plate.

Lastly, my Dad loves and adores the beef with scrambled egg. Less oily than the rest I've recommended and extremely soothing to the soul. And sometimes if you order lots, they give you free soup too. :)

One other perk is that it's open late, so great and amazing for those late nights after clubbing/drinking or simply a late photo-shoot. Enjoy your meal here!
author: Denise T.

description: Not my favorite Chinese restaurant. The food wasn't that impressive for the review they got. It was not well prepared and very greasy. The price are expensive. And the most important thing is the restaurant is not clean at all. I do not think I will come back to this place.
author: Luong T.

description:
Been going there for 15 years, haven't been disappointed yet.  Once I forgot my wallet and owner said no problem, pay me next time! how's that for service.   Generally the first dish arrives in about 5 to 7 minutes after the order is placed, and that's when the place is packed.  If the servers aren't too attentive, its because the place is always super busy, you just have to get their attention, its also possible that you may be a crappy tipper because every time I go in there they bend over backward for me.

As for the food, OMG... you just have to know what dishes to get.  My personal favorites are salt&pepper prawns, crispy fried noodles (hong kong style) and honey BBQ pork...
author: Sam J.

description:
3.5 stars.

Food was pretty good here, but pricey for a Chinese restaurant. We got 6 dishes and 3 beers for 8 people and that came out to $120!! Super pricey if you ask me for late night Chinese food. 

2 crispy noodle dishes
1 beef chow fun
1 salt and pepper shrimp
1 pork spare ribs
1 other beef dish

The food at least was good and the servers were accommodating if not helpful.
author: Ling H.

description: This place serves up a mighty fine ginger and green onion chicken. Other items on the menu (congee, beef in black bean sauce, etc.) are good too but the ginger and green onion chicken are where it's at. Do yourself a favor and order it.
author: Brittany L.

description:
Wow, major improvement since my first visit.  Salt & pepper squid was awesome -- crispy, non-greasy, and perfectly seasoned.  Clams in black been sauce were also yummy.  Loved how the clams were big and juicy.  I think they've topped Boda's version.  Even the Yang Chow fried rice was good (bit on the small side).  My mom got the jook with meat and preserved egg and I was surprised how nicely salted it tasted. 

All in all great meal.  $45 for 3 peeps.  Open until midnight most nights too!
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Fuck your afterparty, my afterparty is some shrimp scrambled egg gravy over rice and duck.
I never know if they are staring at our table because we're drunk or because they're working the turnaround, or if they people watch at work.
YuetLee is fast and I know its not the alcohol - Our food always comes in 5 minutes.  Even for a big group they are fast. They are pretty nice for people who have to deal with drunks. Yes drunks - so if you come late in the night, the only time I've been, you will probably see/hear something hilarious.
author: Cheryl D.

description:
at 2am, anything is good. i can say this is a refreshing change from the usual carne asada fries down in san diego. with that said, the family style meals is nothing spectacular - typical vietnamese/chinese food [fried rice, porridge, crispy noodle basket, chow mein, etc].

i believe it closes at 3am, unless you know the right people. 

word of advise - avoid the bathroom.
author: Vinh H.

description: This place is alright. I know of a better one that is open late in Sacramento (Yummy Juice Cafe). It was late and I was looking for some eats. I would come again if I found myself in the situation and you should come if you are looking for decent greasy Chinese food late at night. We ordered steam oysters, roast duck, and abalone & chicken over rice. The abalone & chicken was the best dish. It had distinguishable pieces of delicious abalone in it. The roast duck was the worst. There was barely any meat on the duck quarter. For the same price I could've gotten a whole duck at Shun Fat supermarket which had more meat and was much more juicier.
author: Tri V.

description:
food here is ok.
come here if you have no other choice.
why waste stomach digestive fluid for an average food.
author: Rina C.

description: My go-to place for late night comfort Chinese food in SF.  I have since moved to the OC, but still fantasize about the clams in black bean sauce, salt & pepper squid, salt & pepper spare ribs/pork chops, and steamed sea bass with ginger and scallion.  The congee is not bad either although I may prefer the congee at Sam Wo.  Is it a dive? Yes, but I find a certain charm in its dingy diner aesthetic,   Also, I have always had excellent, prompt service here -- whether it be at 6pm or 2am.
author: Ivy W.

description: Seafood is strong here.  Brought a friend from China, she was pretty impressed, and she's from a Chinese city known for seafood.  Just don't come in when crowded, you may have to sit near the door, and it can be cold.
author: Steven P.

description:
Decide to come here because "Yuet Lee" is my grandma's name hha how funny. Anyways the food were greasy definitely just like the food in Chinatown in LA. What cool about this place is that they stay open till 3am. They serve seafood and live lobsters (which is good since its fresh). Mainly tourist comes in here, i think it had to do where this place is located, which is just on the corner so its convenient.

They serve Beer :)
author: Lina L.

description:
Pan fried chicken chowmein, Clay pot catfish and a bowl of white rice

All were great food until I look up & hear this during the middle of eating

Waiter: Ahh folks are you done?
Me: No...why?
Waiter: We are closing in a half an hour
Me: Umm...k ( as I bloodshot stare the shit out of him)

*10 minutes later*

Waiter: Here's the check
Me: Excuse me...can you see we're not done eating here?
Waiter: We are closing soon
Me: Well, why did you invite us in if you knew you would be closing soon?
Waiter: Sorry...please...we are crossing(closing)

*5 minutes later*

Waiter: Are you done with those dishes?

This is when I slam my knife and fork, pop up from my seat, transform to a single leg stance and the rest is history after the first kick

Just kidding on the last part but I really had the inclination to be the Black Mamba & Samuel Jackson after being treated that way 

You bet muthafu**ker...kiyahh!!
author: Charmian D.

description: Yuet Lee is overrated and overpriced.  My wife and I went hoping for a delicious meal for our first night on vacation in San Francisco.  We ordered the beef chow mein.  When it came out, there were only a few scarce pieces of beef and three pieces of vegetables in it.  We had also unfortunately ordered the $55 crab.  It was supremely disappointing.  It came out of the kitchen way to fast.  It tasted mediocre at best.  And it was definitely overpriced.  I had walked by another restaurant the next day where the same sized crab for less than $30.  I definitely would not go back here again on my next trip to San Francisco.
author: Ernesto G.

description: Oh ginger and green onions chicken, you never fail me... please don't ever go away...
author: Nathan D.

description:
Ahhh, Yuet Lee.  What would my tummy and liver do without you?!  For all of you out there in yelpland who know what I'm talking about....ahhh, Yuet Lee.

Yuet Lee is one of the typical restaurants on yelp that get such diverse and ridiculous reviews that it doesn't get its true rating justice.  People who give bad ratings give such simple reviews and explanations that it's not really fair to the loyal readers who need "good advice" on where to eat!

The hard facts are 1) it's usually always packed, 2) the clientele is diverse (which politically incorrectly speaking means, local Chinatown people eat here) and 3) they have pictures of celebrities.  I understand the last one is cliche, but that's why it's cool and legit!

Now, for my warranted opinion and review based on numerous dinners (being either sober, drunk or *%$&#!ed up) - this place is a solid SF institution.  Solid 4 stars.

I will share what I usually order (recommended by my fat cantonese friend):
- scrambled eggs with beef
- clams with black bean sauce
- salt and pepper pork
- green vegetable thing (pea shoots? )
- squab
- salt and pepper calamari

Each and everyone one of these dishes are delicious, tasty, filling and fast.  Who cares is if it's overpriced?  That's a relative term and it's in SF.  Who cares if the service sucks or they're rude?  They've been there longer than you've been in SF so who's wrong now???

I have no idea how the other dishes are and if I'm going to get seafood crazy canton style I would rather go to R&G or the Kitchen.  But if I want good, quick and tasty Cantonese food AND I'm in North Beach, then Yuet Lee will always be top of the list.  I know what it is and what to expect...people who expect too much always get let down.  Trust me, I know.
author: Terry L.

description:
First...I have to say, this is NOT your 99cent per item BS type of "Chinese" food. This is NOT Panda Express. I mean you're in Chinatown after all so you can't expect that type of food.

This is however, REAL Homestyle Chinese food. Quintessentially Chinese in food, attitude & even "ambience" (lots of Chinese chattering loudly...wait, that's us)

Been coming here since I was like 5 yrs old, don't even live in San Fran but everytime we go, this is where we go if we aren't having Dim Sum 

Seafood is their specialty, and like everyone before, their Salt & Pepper Squid is amazing! The steamed whole fish is always perfect, never over or under cooked, and full of flavor. Lobster black bean sauce super yummy!

During the day, you'll see someone wrapping up fresh wontons which are delish. Plump with pork & shrimp and just the right amount of spices. Wonton noodle soup is super yum.

Chinese style beef stew is pure authentic... I know typically non-Chinese people don't eat this but my hubby who isn't Chinese LOVES this. So I definitely think everyone should try it, ladle it over your white rice & enjoy. 

Service is super fast-- YES there is a language barrier  so they may seem to be pushy, but if you have ever eaten with a Chinese family...we are all pushy! LOL ;P  But really, we love our food & want everyone to try everything... which whenever we see the owner, he'll offer something new for us to try. Yeah that's the guy in the pic with Jackie Chan--he's a boisterous friendly guy. 

The kitchen is open for you to watch your food being prepared... Its just an experience to listen to the sizzling going on and watch the steam as it rises. You know this is freshly made & not served out of a warming tray. 

Price is neither expensive or inexpensive, medium unless you're ordering things like crab & lobster (hello...those are bound to be more expensive). 

Love that they are open late, so that when I'm staying with my sister, I can just walk down 2 blocks and get my Beef Chow Fun fix or Won Ton fix. 

The only down side is that yeah...it looks run down, could use a different paint color even though the bright green is memorable. A little cramped as many of these older restaurants tend to be. 

Think I need to head back up to the Bay Area really soon...

Oh...and I just have to solve the mystery of the basement... if you want to know, continue reading...



there's low ceilings, tables, a men's & women's restroom, and large sink area where they wash their dishes/pans. Oh...and sometimes an occasional "VIP" or owner's family will sit down there for privacy. Hate to disappoint, no mobsters down those steep stairs...no people under the stairs. lol
author: May T.

description: Needed to get some dinner at night. Was recommended here by the valet. Food was decent. Sizes are big. Taste just mediocre. It was just your run-of-the-mill Chinese food. Nothing too special.
author: Will B.

description:
must get beef chow faun and calamari!!!

this is a dinky place i would always pass by in chinatown but never think of trying until i start working in this area and my boss took us here for lunch. i am a fan of beef chow faun, but dude, the beef chow faun here is "hellllla" good :) it's not like those nasty half assed beef chow fauns where it's still chunky and tasteless. the beef chow faun here is well "chowed" in their wok, the beef is not overly cooked so it's still tenderrrrrrrr....YUMMMM

i love their calamari too!! a tad on the pricier side but def worth trying esp with the special jalapeno soy sauce it comes with :P

i highly recommend this place to anyone who's around this area....they're known for their chow fauns and calamari. if you want, you may even ask them what's good that day and they'll usually give you recommendations of what's good and fresh :D
author: Helen T.

description:
For review #500, I was waiting for something special to happen.  I so wanted to make #500 a 5-star review.

But nothing special happened.... I waited, and waited, but nope -- I still have no 5-star event to review.  That's kinda sad, huh?  

Yeah, it is for me, too.

So, for special #500 - I decided to review one of my all-time favorites, Yuet Lee.

I first came here about 8 or 9 years ago, late at night after clubbing, and a massive group of us chowed down.  I was told it was THE place to get porridge, and I had to say - that was awesome porridge.  

Then, I never came here again until last year, when I happened to walk in and realized, "This is the same place I came to long ago!"  PORRIDGE-TIME!

Their abalone porridge is great - as is their pork and egg porridge.  Their salt and pepper squid, which seems to be their best-known dish is good, but I don't find it amazing.  The seafood soup is very tasty, and their fried rice is pretty good.  Everything I have ordered here has always been quite good to amazingly good.

I know of no other place that takes your order and has your food on the table quicker than this place.  It's like they have a psychic running the kitchen.  That said - late at night, there can be a wait to get seated, so at 2 AM, it's not necessarily a quick meal.

As far as service goes, it's hit or miss.  I've sometimes been greeted like an old friend and at other times, the servers seem irritated that more people came in.  I can't say anyone has been outright rude - but it's basically typical for a Chinese restaurant.  This crass service can sometimes irritate me, but since they consistently give me good food - I don't mind so much.

With Yuet Lee, though, I do have one complaint.  They don't make some of the more typical Chinese soups like sizzling rice soup.  Late at night, I am usually not one to want a meal (rice, meat, etc.) but rather a big, piping hot bowl of soup to myself.  Now they have seafood soup, but again, that is too much "stuff" (squid, shrimp, bok choy, etc.).  It's better than nothing, but it doesn't quite hit the SPOT.  I can't ding Yuet Lee for it, it's their menu and their type of cuisine, but it's just something I wish they had.  That, and hot and sour soup - and this place would be close to PERFECT.

To my knowledge, they are opened until 3 AM on the weekends.  During weekdays, they close earlier, but still a lot later than most places.  If it's 10 pm or later, Yuet Lee is one of the only places that comes to mind for food - and guaranteed, they are opened and ready to miraculously present food to your table in approximately 5.7 seconds.

For food, I go to Yuet Lee for a late night meal.

But if I'm craving my sizzling rice soup - I will just head down the block to New Sun Hong Kong restaurant and get soup.  For everything else - Yuet Lee RULES.
author: Grace K.

description: Ordered the flounder with asparagus, clay pot beef stew, fried squid and garlic prawns.  It's all very good,but a little too salty.  Get yourself a good drink and you're good to go though.  Good food, and lots of it for what you spend on it.
author: Risaia D.

description:
Strictly for tourists or night hawks. The food here is way over-priced and overall a mixed bag. I had beef chow fun, preserved egg and pork jook/congee, an oyster clay pot and shrimp fried rice. 

Everything was really flat, aside from the oysters, which were nice and big and came in a rich broth, and the chow fun, which was only good because of how greasy it was. 

The fried rice is your garden variety shit with a splash of soy sauce for flavoring and nothing more, the jook was absolutely flavorless - I had to add a ton of salt (go to Hing Lung next door instead).

On top of that they treat Asian customers like shit, fawning over the tourists while they just gave us the cold staredown waiting for us to get out and leave the low tip that they expected, and thus deserved, from us.

If you're drunk enough, yeah, go for it, why not. Otherwise, stay the hell away.
author: Keane N.

description:
Decent homestyle Chinese food at a very reasonable price. I love coming here with a large group for the "authentic", unfussy ambience. Don't come here expecting R&G Lounge quality, but do expect to leave this place with a full-tummy and not-so-hurt wallet.

I dig the house seafood soup, salt and pepper calamari, and duck. (Random combo, yes? I'm not suggesting that you ONLY order these items... just recommending some of the better items on the menu.)
author: Debra C.

description: Good food, but service is horrible. The waiter will harass you if you don't leave him more than a five dollar tip. The cups and plates were dirty. I wouldn't recommend this place
author: Jana C.

description:
I was too drunk to remember what I ate.  I do remember there was a noodle dish.  Other than that, I do remember in my confusion that while everyone was eating I had stopped.  So I'm not sure if that means I didn't like the food since I never stop eating.  Fat girl status.  

I will need to come back and reassess.
author: Justine D.

description:
This place is one  my favorite joints in town. Any seafood or roasted meat dish is great. The live crab is the best and a fantastic deal!

They have been here forever and I hope they stay here forever. I would vote to have them subsidized by the city as a public service.

If you're looking for  a super cheap vodka sponge while wasted at 2 am, go to a cheap noodle joint. Everyone will be happier.
author: Statin Island V.

description:
Your food's ready in a blink of an eye.

Bathroom much cleaner than the average Chinese restaurant's.
author: Inigo M.

description:
I loved the noodles here.  I was craving a bowl of noodles and some down right comfort food and this place really hit the spot.  

I ordered 3 items between me and my bf (lol we just came back from vegas and didn't eat for 2 days).  We got the wonton noodle soup, and he got the same thing with duck and we got the preserved egg and pork porridge.  

The porridge was really thick.  I like mine thin, but it was pretty good for what it was.  I wasn't expecting anything "gourmet" but it definitely hit the spot for down right homey.  

The bowl of wonton noodle soup was delicious.  The wontons were nice and big filled with giant shrimp and pork.  It was the perfect amount, so not overly porky.  The wrapper is smooth and fresh, very good.   The noodles were almost like the ones you get in hong kong.  It's still kinda hard but very succulent.  The soup wasn't anything spectacular but still very good and flavorful.

I tried a piece of the duck from my boyfriend's soup.  The meat was really tender, the skin had good texture that seems fit for roast duck in a bowl of noodles and the seasoning of the duck was like normal roast duck.

Yuet Lee deserves 5 stars because they are open late which caters to my needs/wants and the food for the price is amazing.  For all three items our bill was $23 with tip....and we left almost a $3 tip.  So If we weren't being fatties, we could have gotten away with this meal for less than $20 and then some to spare.  

I will definitely make this place my  new late night spot.
author: Zu W.

description:
Unlike most people who have reviewed this place, I ate in the middle of the day and had yet to enjoy any liquor. I am proud to report that it's tasty even if you're not drunk. 

I got the pepper steak (or their equivalent) and was very pleased with the meal. The meat was tender and a perfect compliment to the crunchy peppers and it came with a boat-load of rice. 

The best part beside it being open late? It's right around the corner from where I live....oh yummy Chinese food...how I love you so! Well played Yuet Lee. Well played.
author: Angela M.

description: Fried oysters were inedible....UGH.  Calamari was not up to par. Ginger beef was good, but such a small amount!!  Servings, overall, were small.  Mediocre experience and over priced.  Try another spot.
author: Qween E.

description:
Yep. Still not very good. 

Service was meh. Food was double meh. Specifically, the wonton noodle soup. That soup reinforced why wonton noodle soup is my LEAST favorite of all Asian noodle soups that I've had. 

The fried rice and pan-fried noodles were pretty good. Anything but that wonton noodle soup.
author: Jenny K.

description:
This place is Teh Shit for one reason and one reason only:

Open til 3.

That's right.  You can actually close the club / bar / venue and THEN hit YL's.  And what do you want most when you've just closed the club / bar / venue?

That's right.  A humongous plate of big, tasty, delicious.

I can't actually tell you for sure what we ordered, or how good it was.  But I know how hungry I was, and how I despaired of finding any place open that late that would give me the kind of post-drinking feast I wanted, in the quantities I wanted, at a price that was acceptable.  In that moment, those enormous plates of A-OK Chinese food were like the Sweet Baby Jesus on a Platter.

In noodle form.

Now I just have to remember where it is the next time I need it.
author: Angela B.

description:
There is a famous movie about sales where the motto was the acronym "ABC."

ABC meaning "always be closing."

I too live by a similar motto when visiting little holes in the wall in Chinatown except I change mine to:

"Always Bring Chinese."

Not that I am shy about ordering things or being the only whitey in a place (I spend lots of time in Cupertino so I know how that goes).  

It's to ensure that I don't miss the REAL specials that are usually posted, in Mandarin, on a pink flier, hidden somewhere behind the counter.

Place is pretty good and open late so it qualifies for a revisit.  

We had the shrimp/mushroom porridge and the salted pork porridge.  Also had the salt and pepper calamari.

The last dish I would rather not talk about.  Wasn't my idea.  It was the duck feet clay pot.  Yeah, I tried it, meh.

But I gotta say, there is nothing like having your dining partner stop mid conversation to spit bones out into a small dish.  

It's a sight to be seen.

Oh, and have fun parking.

Daffy.
author: Archie R.

description:
Yuet Lee is an SF staple. One of the rare, late-night, grub down spots to satisfy post midnight munchies. A day-glo green beacon on the corner of Stockton and Broadway, it's the Chinatown go-to for fast, cheap, sometimes fabulous food. 

My faves: anything salt and pepper style - I especially like the crispy pork spareribs. They're perfectly spiced, sprinkled with cilantro and never fatty or greasy. Wonton soup - the wontons are small and delicate with shrimp mixed into the pork filling. The broth is clear, fresh and flavorful. Clams in black bean sauce - this dish suits a particular mood. It doesn't always jive with certain drinks that one may have imbibed before arriving at Yuet Lee, but when it's right - it's oh so right. Savory and lip-smackingly satisfying. Decent fried rice. Pretty tasty jook. 

Unfortunately, the overhead fluorescent lighting is absolutely horrid. Headache-inducing and especially insulting in the wee hours of face-stuffing when garish glare does no one any favors. 

I may have to wear sunglasses the next time I find myself chowing down here. If that does the trick, perhaps I can tack on another star. But as it stands now, an appreciative three from me to Yuet Lee.
author: wendella a.

description: This is my friend Auggie's favourite late night Chinese restaurant.  The mustard green soup, fried pork chops and black bean clams are pretty good.  But I think this is one of those places that is only good when you're still drunk or really hung over.  I went in for lunch and it just didn't taste the same.  Open late and kinda dirty like you want it.
author: Suz L.

description: DAMMIT this place has got me addicted to the salt and pepper squid and for that reason i give 4 stars... its also good during certain days that you get a 15% discount and for those who come out clubben this place is a great for late nite munchies since they close around 3am on fridays and saturdays... anyways love that calamari tho it must be the MSG hahahaha suffering from withdrawels =/ ZOINKS shivers
author: Mary Ann B.

description: The location is conveniently located.  However, worst Chinese food I have ever had in Chinatown.  Slow serivice, duck feet were sour, some clams served unfresh or bad, fried noodles were not evently cooked.  Please watch out, if you must try stay away from traditional Chinese dishes and go somewhere else.
author: changjie y.

description:
Why do I come here?

Consistently good food and the SFPD.

I am usually here, rushing past the denizens of Chinatown and the onslaught of a torrential downpour with my very good friend, to dry off and warm up over a fantastic meal.  We make a point of visiting this establishment when we are in the area and it has never failed to supply us with a fantastic order of porridge and other delectable treats from the sea.

The interior is typical of a Chinese restaurant that never really took the time or money to invest in itself since the 1960's.  But where the money and effort is lacking is made up in the food and human ambiance.  Don't expect customer service, this is Chinatown.  This is where you head to get your table and menu, eat the food, and then leave.  No one is paying for charm or ass-kissing.  Advise to head toward North Beach for that.  However, If you are lucky to get a table near the stove, I find it neat to peer through the small openings to watch them stir fry something interesting in their many woks lining the grill.

My friend usually settles on the fish porridge, the salt-and-pepper fried squid and then my contribution would be to request a starchy accompaniment such as the standard chow fun or the flash saute of Tung Choi greens.  At first, the porridge reminded me too much of the Okayu style rice porridge in Japan my grandmother use to make when we got sick.  In addition, I'm more of a sashimi person and am rarely inclined toward fish that has been boiled.  Hence, the aversion.  However, the porridge here is delicate enough to overpower my negative memories and the white fish influencing the broth: a savory disposition.  Positivity in a round bowl.  Hot.  Steaming.  I cupped my hands around the bowl.

The squid?  Anything fried is good.  Hence my reflections on the salt-and-pepper fried squid.  It is tender and never rubbery, encased lovingly in a very light and crunchy floured coating.  Sometimes slightly oily, but that is usually the consequences of being drowned in a vat of lard.  The Chow fun is a large hot heap of noodles:  wok tossed and brimming with vegetables, shrimp, char siu and bean sprouts.  The very standard smoky flavor is so seductive to the palate.  The Tung Choi depends on the season but the results bring me to the edge of my seat each and every time. Bright emerald greens.  Crispy and flavorful, dotted with small chunks of garlic.  We have also sampled the sweet pea greens too.  Heavenly.  The portions here are large and we usually leave with cartons to go.   Being night owls, we appreciate the fact that there is a decent spot open late at night after catching an art gallery opening downtown.

The  S F P D  bit:

Our most recent visit was slightly more eventful.  After we found parking off Broadway and just finished placing my car in park, the bus in front of us suddenly stopped and several officers of the nearby SFPD went running ahead with their firearms drawn.  R and I literally ran into Yuet Lee and we were seated next to a group of, again, SFPD motorcycle officers taking up one of the larger round tables.  6 huge men in uniform, a usual severe picture except that they had just finisheda very standard Chinese meal and were apparently in high spirits.

The owner of Yuet Lee was having a conversation with one of the officers so to make small talk with the older officer sitting diagonally from me, I inquired about the mayhem up ahead on Stockton.  

"Did you see that commotion out there?  Shouldn't you be out there?"

He smiled, leaned back in his chair,   "Oh that.  That's not our problem.  They've got that under control."  He waved his hand away and then stuck them under his belt.

Another extra star for the ambiance and our funny men in uniform. 

I love them all.
author: Miika M.

description: I can never get enough of this place. Yuet Lee has been around for over 30 years. This is one place I always have to go to when in Chinatown even during the late night. My friends and I always end up going to Yuet Lee after a fun night out. The food is so good. Love getting their salt and pepper calamari, Peking spare ribs, fish, clams, their soups, chow mein and so much more. When I go there I never have a problem with their service.
author: Melanie T.

description: I have never eaten here before until this past weekend and it was tasty! The beef chow fun was so good we ordered a 2nd order. The clams were plump and meaty, the fried noodles with spare ribs was also good and crispy. People at the table loved the calamari, I thought it was ok. The jook was very clean tasting no msg in it I'm sure, not used to that at a Chinese restaurant.
author: Karen T.

description:
Cantonese food usually doesn't wow me but this place was freakin' delicious! We came here last night - there were 6 of us so we were able to  try a variety of dishes. My uncle has been here several times so he took care of all the ordering - duck, chicken, pork, squid, slow cooked soup, stir fried greens, pig liver, etc. It was Thanksgiving all over again. 

Some psycho lady was yelling at the wait staff and making a huge scene - good food AND entertainment?!?! What more can you ask for? 

Next time we go to Bubble Lounge we're coming here for a late night food run. Friday and Saturday nights they open til 3 AM.
author: Connie W.

description: We went here after a long day/night of partying and thought the food was amazing. The waiter was rude, but the food made up for it. I always wondered where this place was and hoped I could find it again and I just saw it featured on Anthony Bourdains show! Yay!!!
author: April B.

description:
one of my favorite "hole in the wall" restaurants here in SF.
Their food here is delicious! I always come for the salty fish and chicken fried rice along with roast duck.=Full tummy! Food is delivered in such a short time. However, servers aren't so prompt as it is a very busy restaurant. But you can expect to have a tasty meal!
author: Sally d.

description: Love the salt and pepper squid with chopped green chili and garlic on top.
author: Adam B.

description: i wasn't a fan. i did appreciate that it wasn't crowded and the food came out quick, but everything was way too starchy and the shrimp fried rice left much to be desired...like bigger shrimps! i think the pics i took speak for themselves. plus, it was super pricey here! i think steamed fish was like $22-24, which is more than double what we usually pay back home.
author: Cat B.

description:
i must have passed by this restaurant hundreds of time, looking for a place to eat after a night clubbing on broadway. i must admit from the outside this restaurant does not look appealing at all, but yuet lee is a place where you really cant judge just by the outer appearance.

a good friend of mine, Helen T (http://htran437.yelp.com/) works in chinatown and recently started coming here and ravesss about their beef chow fun. i finally got the opportunity to come here last night with her to try this beef chow fun she craves all the time. i haven't eaten at that many chinese restaurants and haven't ordered that many beef chow fun, but this by far really IS the best beef chow fun i've had. some beef chow fun ive had are unevenly stirred. you'll have some super salty and some kind of bland, but the noodles here are stirred evenly with sauce and there were huge pieces of tender and flavorful beef!

we also got their fried calamari. now i definitely had a lot of fried calamari, served all different styles, but this particular fried calamari stood out to me. no matter what cuisine, most fried calamari ive had are small curled pieces but the ones here at yuet lee look more like thin slices of calamari with very light batter. small pieces were not hiding under thick layers of batter and it was perfectly crispy. i loved it with some lemon ontop and dipped and topped with their jalapeno soy sauce.

i rarely review chinese restaurants because chinese food is whatevers to me and there's usually nothing special about it, but i think yuet lee deserves a recognition. its open late too! don't let the green and old looking brick building turn you off
author: Katherine C.

description: Yuet Lee just so happens to be my parent's favorite restaurant; they've been going here ever since they moved to San Francisco at least 30 years ago. It's gotten to a point where we don't even need menus to order, we get the same waitress every time and she's pretty much memorized our order. You must get: clams with black bean sauce, peking spare ribs, bok choy with shrimp, fried squid, and beef chow fun to name a few. It's also a plus that they close at 3AM, so it's a definite go-to late at night if you want to fix your Chinese food craving.
author: Mirabella C.

description:
If you are here for a fine dining experience with great looking food then forget about it. If you want some great tasting Chinese food that fills you up then get over there now!

We used to go here at night after class and would order the salt and pepper squid, and on choy, a very tasty vegetable which isn't on the menu. The portions are pretty big for the price and tastes great in an unhealthy sort of way.
author: Richard W.

description:
Their sea food dishes sucked. Salt and pepper squid is like flavorless version of what you get in quickly. I dont know why people crave about. I guess they are all those drunkards who come in late and eat anything that gets served. Clay pot dishes felt like some fermented meat in cheap chemical sauce. Also for the quality of food served they should not charge more 5-8$ per dish, but charging 13-15 $ is  quite expensive for that place. 
Usually I tip 10 -20% depending on food and service. When I tipped 10%, she came and suggested to  tip minimum 15% for the worst food ever eaten in my life time. watch out u need to shell out 15% tip for whatever junk food they serve..

There are lot of good chinese restaurant around. 

Pros- Open late night..

Cons-
$$
Tasteless/worst food.
Worst service.
author: Nifty G.

description: This place is an old family favorite.  Great seafood. Love the rockcod, had the lobster with green onions, the garlic shrimp is good. Crab noodles are great too.
author: B L.

description:
I think this restaurant is catered more toward 'tourists'.  Once you enter, there are celebrities photos taken with the owner.   Parking is difficult so we parked in the garage. $3.00 (1 hour). 

We ordered a peppercorn beef with onions. The slices of beef were of pretty good quality but to charge $15.00 for this dish is bloody murder. 

I was craving "salt fish with chicken and tofu" claypot and it was about $12.00.  

Rice was an additional $3.00. 

50 cents for take out boxes!?!

Anyways, like I said, I think this restaurant caters towards tourists and it opens late (~3am).
author: Jboogie L.

description:
I love coming here to cure the late night munchies!

My friends and I know this place as Uncle Timmy's because DY knows the owner.  Crowd of people outside waiting to get a table?...no problem!  Walk in with DY and you get the VIP treatment!  Just be ready to get the death stare from all those people you just cut.  

No need for menus.  DY just walks up to the kitchen and orders the usual....chow mein, jook, salt and pepper spareribs, salt and pepper calamari, clams with black bean sauce, tripe and on-choy.  The food is always delish and satisfies my hungry tummy.

Great late night eats with quick service.  Can't beat that!
author: Patra I.

description: Terrific, no-nonsense Cantonese style Chinese & Seafood.    Look for the "Green Corner" restaurant on the edge of Chinatown and North Beach. This place is very famous (as evidenced by photos with Food and Travel Celebs).    Despite this, the food is really excellent.   It has a very traditional big-city Chinese "feel" which I really like.   It is also open late.    One tip is to not ponder the menu for too long as the waitstaff seem to like to move quickly and if you don't know what you'd like after 2 passes they become a bit frustrated.
author: Max K.

description:
We got here about 2:00AM on a Friday/Saturday (after a big night at Vessel), and the place was still packed.  After waiting for a few minutes we took our seats and ordered for the 5 of us.  

Here's what we had:

*2 plates of scrambled eggs w/prawns
*BBQ pork chow mein
*chicken w/black bean sauce

Maybe I'm speaking for myself here, but I think we could have easily ordered a lot more, but not because the portions are necessarily small.

Anyway, the scrambled eggs w/prawns were absolutely amazing - perfectly cooked eggs and super tender prawns - I added some of the spicy sauce for a little kick.  The chow mein was tasty, but I'd be willing to try something else in its place next time, and the chicken w/black bean sauce was good, too, though I'd also be willing to try something else next time around.

The place had a good energy, and the owner stopped by our table to check in with us a couple of times (he's the guy in the pictures with all the famous people like Jackie Chan, etc..) to see how things were.  He's a fun guy (not of the mushroom variety) and his presence added to the overall positive experience there.

Anyway, I'd definitely go back there again, and the first thing I'd order is the scrambled eggs w/prawns.  Oh, and the quote of the night was something like, "And yes, the food here still tastes great even when you're sober."  haha
author: Devin H.

description:
I was here on a Sunday night, when most restaurants in Chinatown were closed, and I didn't have time for most of the fine dining restaurants in North Beach, as I had a flight to catch. So, I entered this, as it was the only one open in the area, and looked like service would be fast. And, I was completely bowled over by the food !!!

They had a quite a lot of seafood in the menu, but I wanted something I could finish fast, and ordered for "Crispy Fried Garlic Prawns w/ Chow Mien". It was definitely the best chow mien I ever had, and I have been having Chow Mien since I was a kid. And the prawns, were wonderfully fried in garlic. The taste was strong, unlike a lot of Chinese restaurants in the US, and the smells were completely Yummy!! and a bottle of Tsing Tao beer along with this was perfect. The portions were quite large too, and there was no miserliness in adding prawns. The service, as I expected, was prompt and fast, nothing fancy, but definitely not rude.

The thing is, I was born and grew up in Calcutta in India, which has a large-sized Chinatown from Pre-WWII days of the British. The Chinese there are mostly Cantonese-speaking. So, I've had quite a lot of Cantonese food and especially chow mien. The complaint about SALT in the food is because European cuisine is typically much less salty, and hence, most of the Chinese food in the US is adapted to suit American preferences. So, this highly-salted Chinese food is very authentic, AFAIK, if you are talking about Cantonese food. And yes, the place is somewhat pricy, given that Chinese restaurants across the street with well-appointed interiors, almost charge the same price. If you want to get quality service and quiet atmosphere, I would suggest New Sun Hong Kong at Broadway and Columbus, which also has superb Chinese fare. But, if you like a loud, roadside restaurant with staff running around, greasy, yummy smells filling the air and generally less fancy atmosphere, this is the place to go...
author: Abhimanyu G.

description:
My love affair with Chinese broccoli began here 16 years ago...

Glad to see that this place is still one of the best!  I enjoyed being reintroduced to abalone today...

No lunch specials, white folks!  Just rice plates...
author: Nathan W.

description:
Was eatting with a couple of friends and I swear to God...........I saw one of the biggest cockroaches ever.  This roach fell from the ceiling and landed on my friends head.........then it flew to the chow fun before the waiter grabbed it with her hands.  I know restaurants have roach issues but this thing was huge!!!  Luckily we were almost done.

The food is ok but it's really not worth the money. Their fried calamari is good but that's about it.  Everything else you can probably get at D and A lounge, half a block down, for half the price and it's just as good or better.   Man...............that roach still bothers me.  Lusty lady and then this place.  It was not a good nite.
author: jason g.

description: The salt and pepper squid is the #1 item on the menu and it is there for a reason, simply it is greatness for your mouth!  Hot fresh, slightly salty with a wonderful pepper finish!  I love it.  Now, the rest, busy but fast service.  Great portions and food is hot and fresh!   4 stars is only because of the salt and pepper squid.... Would be a 3  star because of service.
author: David L.

description:
I have been dining here for many years. It was the place to go after a show at Tom Guido's Purple onion. I find myself here for lunch and late night dinner in North Beach/Chinatown. They have a fish tank so you can get really fresh fish dishes. 
Perfect for groups.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
there's a notice of a $.25 surcharge per container on take out orders, no doubt to reflect the added cost of using plastic containers instead of foam in s.f. their curry beef brisket over rice (5.75) is still very good but a little saltier. since i didn't check the tab, i  may have been overcharged 50
cents.
(3 x 5.75)=17.25+1.51(tax) +.75  +  ____  =  21..10 win some, lose some.

as my sunday experience shows,  not all chinese are good in math. (see dol ho review).
author: Victor G.

description:
the food here was just ok.  The salted fish w tofu & minced pork was good.  the fish was a tad salty but it was flavorful.  the clams were nothing special.  The spinach, also nothing special.  the crispy pork (?) intestines were good.

654
author: Heejin L.

description:
Drinking at Rosewood without having eaten anything all day called for some emergency foodies. Yuet Lee was recommended as the place to go. And go we did. 

The duck was excellent. The rice was Chinese. The beef chow fun was delish! But the waiter misunderstood us when we asked for change and then proceeded to be pouty about the whole thing. 

If I go back again and I probably will, I'm not ordering any of the seafood. Dead fishies floating in the tank aren't appetizing. They just aren't. I don't care how clean you think the tank water is, but dead fish should be on ice not marinating in tank water. 

Fish heads fish heads, roly poly fish heads 
fish heads fish heads eat them up. Yum! 

Not here, Dr. Demento. Not here.
author: Kevo M.

description:
Big daddy Lee serves up the best fried rice in the city. period. Back home we say: "Never trust a skinny chef"...   Yuet Lee's owner is chubby enough to certify their food is not only edible, but f*ckin addicting. 

it may be mafia-related...it may have a mysterious basement... it may be a bit dirty, but Yuet Lee and its crew dish out some of the best Chinese grub money can afford. 

Notice a couple of years ago Yuet Lee painted the outside of his restaurant in green. A Feng Shui expert recommended them to paint it so in order to attract money a.k.a. customers. They were already popular before green came in, but what the heck! They're super busy on the weekends, specially since they're open until 3 am. Definitely a late nite/drunk spot. 

*rubs Yuet Lee belly for good luck*
~T
author: Tomas V.

description:
This place opens til 3 AM on weekends which is great for when me and my friends are looking for a place to eat after clubbing.
Not only that, the food here is actually YUMMY! I. At first I thought the food tasted that great because I was hell drunk. But when I tried coming to this place on one random afternoon, I was pleasantly surprised of how great the food actually did taste.

I always order the Beef with Scrambled Eggs, Salt & Pepper Squid, and the fried Flounder. Consistently delicious. 
The only set back is that I always have to order my food really slowly and clearly or the waiter/ waitress will totally mess up my order. Other than that, they're ok.
author: Libby K.

description: Yuet Lee's garlic noodles are simply the essence of life. Perfectly crunchy. Just enough garlic. Can not get enough. GO Yuet LEE.
author: Mark P.

description: Love this place!! Have been coming here since I was little with my parents. Our favorites are the salt and pepper shrimp (if you can handle eating the entire shrimp :) and the rice porridge! I would def recommend this place, and I have now made myself very hungry and craving some Yuet Lee!
author: Morgan B.

description:
Did kermit just vomit all over this restaurant???

The infamous green chinese restaurant.  Could they have chosen a more fugly, tacky, down right awful color?  Guess not.. I really thought that it was just the outside of the building but when you walk in, it's even more green. Holy crap!!!

Anyway.. service is rediculously horrible.. as I assume from every chinese joint i hit up.  But this one tops it off.  The waitress pretty much chucks the menu at me as she seats us at our table..

It usually takes awhile for me to order if I'm not a regular at the restaurant.  But tell me why 2 people kept coming back every minute asking if I was ready to order.  I already told them I would let them know when I was ready but I guess they didn't get the memo..  Literally!!!! Every friggen minute!

Finally decided to order.  Food came out hella fast and I was satisfied.  Came there for the food and not the service.  Nothing much to say about the food except that I'm pretty sure they use MSG on their stuff.  They close late (3AM) so thats another late night option for those night owls. HOOT HOOT
author: Jen A.

description:
1. Open late = good
2. bad lighting = bad
3. stinky stinky = bad
4. food = good

Split it down the middle, 3 stars.  

No soup for you.
author: Rose Q.

description:
They close at 3am.  So when we get there like at 2:00am-2:30am and on a day that is not friday or saturday, the service is pretty good.  Usual days that I go is on a Sunday night around 2am and they're really nice considering we're not chinese.  

Yeah it's pretty pricey for chinese food, but that usually doesn't matter when you've been drinking and the best thing to wash it down with is with some greasy chinese food.  Yes the salt/pepper squid is good, but nothing beats the greasy chow fun and greasy fried rice.  Top it off with the jalapeno-chili-oil-soy sauce and every plate gets licked clean.
author: Raymond L.

description: Awesome seafood chow mein, very good beef w/ Chinese broccoli.
author: David C.

description:
Went here with my dad who was visiting from Houston.  New asia was packed, so it was a last minute decision, but one that will haunt me for the rest of my life.  Three words...salt pepper squid.  That s is like crack rock.  Chinese broccoli with oyster sauce was delicious, kung pao chicken was ok, but the salt pepper squid was amazing.

btw...a little over priced and the service is super pushy and hover-y, but i will be back for the squid and to try some of the amazing looking noodles everyone else was ordering.
author: Rena H.

description:
