Who says you only go to a hole in the wall for the food and not the ambiance?

On a recent late night visit here with a friend, I got to see:

1) The restaurant's beautiful fluorescent lime green walls.

2) The mysterious basement where "VIP" patrons would be ushered in and out of by the owner himself.

3) Photographs of the owner with various celebrities including Emeril and Jackie Chan (and a random pic of Micheal Jordan doing a slam dunk...)

4) One of the waiters rushing outside to stop a bunch of drunk girls who were banging on the restaurant's windows just for kicks.

5) And last but not least, a very hot asian CHP officer coming in for a late night meal.

Oh and the Won Ton Noodle soup with cha siu is pretty good. 3.5/5
author: Trinh T.

description:
The only time I've actually eaten at Yuet Lee is late night. The food is cheap and it comes out fast. Otherwise, I thought the food was too oily, and the utensils were dirty. The last time I ate here was last Saturday and the spoons given to us at the table still had porridge stuck on it. 

If you're looking for something super cheap and late at night, this is worth a look; 2 stars.
author: Ray W.

description:
Worst Chinese meal ever eaten...hands down. Service was horrible, no problem was I ready for that, but when the waitress literally approached me before leaving and called me on my less than15% tip saying something like it was the restaurant policy...I was blown away. WTF... I was being generous, for a disaster of a meal and time.
~clay pot chicken-all fat, bone and rejects of the chicken 
~salt and pepper shrimp-old frozen shrimp that the shell refused to come off. (Since the price was high, I was sure to ask if it was fresh before ordering...um, they lied.) 
~sauteed pea spouts -good, but @14 dollars thatsa little hard to swallow. Never order something not on the menu at Chinese joint like this...sure to stick it to ya.
author: Terri Z.

description: Great late night dive for another drunken night in san fran!   Cash only. I don't remember exactly what we ate, but everything that we ate was satisfying.  Service was fast.   Fresh ingredients, authentic chinese dishes!
author: Helene H.

description:
Hall in a wall Chinese place that's open till late and relatively cheap. 

I wanted to eat in Chinatown where the chinese people really eat so I asked my chinese friend to take me to one as I didn't know any. Told my friend, it's got to be in Chinatown so I can bring my other friends in case they come to chinatown on sightseeing/etc.

If you can't stand the fast food type of restaurant where it seems a bit filthy, then you probably can not dine here but if yo u are more of a gourmet guy and don't care much about the atmosphere, then you can probably try this place.

Food was ok-good, price was good and the service was 3 star.
They weren't rude or understaffed. We ordered Catfish/pork Clay Pot, Kung Pao Shrimp, Rice, Seasonal stir fried veggies(like bok choy), Roasted duck.  The duck was good and the others were 3 stars. But thinking that it's open till 3am and with ok food, I rate it a 3 star. But hey...I live in the south bay so does 3am closing hour really that important?...hahaha.  Closed Tuesday.
author: Kaz S.

description:
Just down the street from one of my fave bars Sip, so it's perfect to go to after a lot of drinking and partying.  Since I've only eaten here with my senses pretty impaired, I can only review it to the best of my spotty and drunken memory.  

Here's the basic deal - its good for when you are really drunk OR kinda drunk and really hungry.  The food is nothing to run home and tell your mom about, but it'll satisfy you for sure.  We have fun here with a big group, and the servers are no-frills, no-smiles, used-to-drunk-people types, who don't let things bother them too much.  

It's still a great way to end the night :)
author: Cindy K.

description:
So what if its a tourist trap - its all about the food!  And for you silly people looking for "ambiance," well, head elsewhere.  if you're looking for down and dirty chinese food, this is a winner.  

too much MSG?  I say not enough.  

had a shrimp omelette thing that was OUTRAGEOUSLY good.  the texture and flavor of this thing were as good as any derivation of egg that i've had anywhere in france.  it was mindblowing, and it had sweet, savory, salty, and a touch sour all working well (there was no bacon on the plate, but you definitely got notes of pig fat).  then we had a soup that had all kinds of animals and seafood, like the kitchen sink of asian soups.  AWESOME.  

I'll admit, I needed my chinese buddy to navigate the menu, but with that egg dish, this place is now added to my monthly destination spots.   complete winner.  

the rest of you snobs either ordered incorrectly or just don't get what sloppy ethnic fair is all about.... tummy happiness.  and always on the cheap.  

(I can't commit to 5 starts cause I've only had 2 things on the menu - but I'll come back later after my next stop)
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
This is a great after hours place for decent Chinese food (not the Panda Express kind).

If decor and cleanliness are high priority - then go to Mel's Diner. But if you want some hearty, greasy Chinese food after a night of clubbing or bar hopping, then Yuet Lee is your answer.

Those with big groups can order entrees and share it family style. I would recommend smaller parties to order rice plates or noodles. Their servings are rather generous.

Caution: Read the signs on the side of the road carefully before parking so your car doesn't get towed during middle of the night street cleaning!!!
author: Tommy T.

description:
We recently came back for some wor wonton soup on 021209, it was cold and rainy.. so soup was a good idea. 

I dont know why but i feel like we're not welcomed whenever we dine in, the lady waitress never smiles, dont speak, no facial expressions.. kinda scary.

But the soup was good, lots of goodies..huge wonton dumplings.. Bf and i couldnt even finish a medium bowl, and thats all we had! 

Check out the faded photos of famous people who visited here..!
author: La La T.

description:
The hubby wanted to eat in Chinatown and have me experience REAL Chinese food. We were wandering about and I was cold so I wanted to hop into the closest restaurant to us. 

We stumbled upon Yuet Lee's and decided to give it a try. It wasn't busy at all. The waitress greeted us and sat us next to the window. The restaurant isn't dirty just old. 

Let's talk about the food... shall we? 

- SALT & PEPPER SQUID. It was good. We enjoyed it. Hubby liked it and he's not that big of a fan of salt & pepper squid. 
- WON TON SOUP. I thought it was OKAY but my husband seemed to have liked it. 
- GAI LAN STIR FRY. It was lightly fried with garlic and delicious. I definitely would recommend it. 
- CHEF's SPECIAL CHOW MEIN. Was really good. Hubby is a fan. 

I'd go again if ever we're in the city craving some Chinese food. I'd recommend it to friends :)
author: Anna K.

description:
Your typical yappy Cantonese joint whose fluorescent lighting over states the fact that the place could use a thorough steam cleaning.  They have good lohan veggies and good bitter melon dishes, if you are into that.  They are also open late, but I have to really question the sanity of eating Cantonese food after a long night on the town...

One funny anecdote from a long time ago.  I was eating at Yuet Lee with a friend from Vermont.  It was late at night and we were really hungry so we asked about the 'whole cat fish' dish, which is usually really good steamed with black bean ginger and green onions.  I think the jaded waiter wanted to give us some shock value, so he grabbed his ratty old net and went to the fish tank and netted a mid size catfish.  As he was absentmindedly walking to our table with the catfish, somehow the catfish slipped out of the net flopped across the restaurant floor under another table where people where eating.  The waiter went nuts, yelling in Cantonese, cursing and wrestling with the fish under the table.  Once he recaptured the fish, it was direct to the chopping block.  Needless to say, we ate veggies that night.
author: Brent H.

description:
1 star for opening late.

If I could help it, I would rather hit Cable Car pizza, Hing Lung half a block down, or the Vietnamese hole in the wall further down Broadway. 

The food is way too fatty and salty. The salt and pepper fried pork was all fat. The other protein was not any better. Every dish was full of grease. 

Prices were a bit steep for this type of joint. $6 for a porridge and $8 for a fried rice for a place that has dirty cooks doing who knows what in the back, jaded servers that have super attitude, and no ambience, these prices are not "San Francisco" prices or "inflation" prices either.

There is also some creepy feeling that there is a whole floor downstairs of Chinese mobsters.
author: benjamin c.

description:
I found that this place falls under the category of "Restaurants to raid after gettin yo' drink on". We came in buzzed and hungry as heck. After getting our water and tea we ordered the Beef Chow Fun (Wet Style), Spare Ribs and Peppers over rice, and the Spinach and Fish Cake Soup.

Beef Chow Fun: This consists of a bed of thin and narrow rice noodles stir fried with beef, carrots, baby bok choy, and straw mushrooms all in a thick starchy beef sauce. They could have added more beef and veggies to the proportion. The flavor was just right.

Spare Ribs and Peppers: Green Peppers and Spare Ribs stir fried in garlic and black bean sauce ~ yum! This dish was what I expected and did not disappoint me. The black bean and garlic sauce soaked well into the peppers and spare ribs (watch out for the little bones in the ribs). 

Spinach and Fish Cake Soup: This soup was perfect to rehydrate after a night of drinking fun. Simple to make and simple to eat. The spinach wasn't boiled to death and the fish cake was fork tender and not too spongy nor tough.

The prices were about $1-2 more than other restaurants of this type but where else can you get food this late?  The 3 dishes + tax came out to $25.

If any of you have a chance to go to NYC you will find many similarities with Wo Hop (http://www.yelp.com/biz/wo-hop-restaurant-new-york). Kudos to the Cantonese speaking waiters for putting up with impatient patrons and for understanding drunken English.
author: Brandon H.

description:
Yuet Lee is 1 of 2 favorite places I go after a night out in SF. Ask any of my friends - I swear by the new zealand mussels with black bean sauce, as well as the sliced fish porridge. Not that it's exclusive to this place, but I also love love love ground white pepper.

This place is so good i even like it sober.

p.s. my other favorite is v cafe on folsom
author: Jane C.

description: Over rated. Better Chinese everywhere else. Service sucked majorly. Sorry I don't want your grimace of negativity serving my food.
author: Ray A.

description:
I have spent years looking for the perfect CHOW MEIN in various cities, and I found one in San Francisco. Chewy yet crispy and great sauce with tons of good veggies. I saw it through the window and knew I had to try it.  One of the top two chow meins I have had in my life (which I have had hundreds of times).

The Black Bean sauce dish we ordered was also amazing, some of the best spiced black bean sauce I have had. ( I always order Ma Pao tofu.)

SO fast, the meal came in literally under three minutes. and this was at 11:30 when the place had no empty tables.

The only bad thing about this place was being asked to leave in order to fill with more people waiting.

GO HERE!
author: Ben D.

description: Had the pork fried rice and black bean clam. The food came out at a frightening speed, though that may have to do with being the only customer in at the time, but still I was very impressed. The fried rice is different from what I normally have. Instead of char-siu they deep fried the pork and cut it into small bits, the salt on the pork added a pleasant surprise to each bit. The clams fairly standard, but delicious nonetheless.
author: David T.

description:
I've been coming here since I was a child.  So let me warn you:  I might be a little biased.

It's hard to miss the shocking green exterior, and I appreciate the fact that Yuet Lee is open till late at night.  The crisp salt-and-pepper squid alone is worth the trip.  There is an imposing fish tank as you enter the restaurant, but don't let that mean that you MUST have the seafood.  Personally (and I hope I don't get slammed for this), I usually don't go with the seafood.  I usually stick with the broccoli with oyster sauce, beef chow fun, and as I mentioned above, the salt-and-pepper squid.

Do not, and I mean it, DO NOT come here expecting glamorous fantastic service by the wait staff.  You come here for the food, hands down.  The wait staff does not fuck around:  they bring your food once it's ready and they do it with one word answers.

That doesn't bother me, in fact, it's something I've grown to appreciate.
author: Yve F.

description:
The best Chinese food I've had in quite some time. I had a pork clay pot dish that was simply stellar. My brother had a dish that he didnt enjoy as much as mine. 

Bad lighting? Who cares. Waitstaff that literally gave you a minute after you asked for one? Great, hurry the hell up and order. Bad lighting? Yeah... what can you do.
author: Justin L.

description:
This place isn't the best restaurant in Chinatown, but they are very consistent and always tasty. It is also nice to know that it will just about be open ANY time, considering serving hours run until 3am (also closed Tuesdays, definitely went on accident once, was very bummed when I arrived).

Yuet Lee is known for seafood. I particularly like the Seafood Noodle soup, substitute the wide, flat rice noodles. I also really like the oysters in the black bean sauce.

Overall,  the prices are not TOO outrageous for the tasty food. The green exterior could be changed tho :-P
author: C B.

description: Not a whole lot to say about this place, but it's a great low-key place to grab a late night meal after being out. Decent Cantonese-style (read heavy, greasy, salty, MSG) food, relatively cheap prices and pretty fast food service and with the check.
author: Patrick L.

description:
Like many other Yelpers have said, this place gets packed since it is open late which attracts the after club crowds on the weekends.  The food is better than Hong Kong Sun aka the other corner spot but think HK's waiters are bit more friendlier than Yuet Lee.

On a busy night, the waiters can be very pushy A*holes...One waiter in particular but won't go there...On that note, Is there a best table/seat in the house in spot like this that deserves a better tip? I'm just saying?!!!!
author: robert c.

description:
Usually, I come and eat at Yuet Lee with at least 4 guys, so we can order a lot of different foods.
So, these are our favorites foods;
Fish Chow mien
Salt and Pepper Roasted squid 
Peking spare ribs
Tofu and Salted Fish Claypot


Other than that, I dunno the taste
author: Wid S.

description: Awesome! When we always go we order the black bean clams and fried squid/calamari. But whatever you order there is good. Great place for late night cravings as well as they're open to the wee hours at night.
author: Windie W.

description: I like the food most especially the Hong-Kong Style noodle... But the only thing tht turned me off was the service!!! Most espcially when their counting the tip right in front of your face! That is bad!!! Aren't you supposed to tip them base on how well their service was?!? But this people check the tip amount and when it is not enough they tell you right off the bat. Bad bad bad... Good food but very bad service.
author: Cherry Love D.

description: I'll make this brief; good food, quick service, good price. Get the BBQ pork fried rice and hong kong style beef chow mein you won't be disappointed.
author: Brian B.

description:
I was craving Chinese food one night and was pointed in the direction of Yuet Lee and Hing Lung (two doors down) by a resident SF homeboy and Warriors fan - Dikshun.

He shared this little spot and noted that their Chow Fun was pretty tasty, "oh and better than the Chow Fun at Hing Lung". You know what they say, "when in Rome..." and so I ordered half of my dinner from Yuet Lee and the other half from Hing Lung. 

Beef Chow Fun - not bad. Not the best I've had but it was good. 
Chinese broccoli braised in oyster sauce - pretty good. Fresh and not to oily. 

I can see how the late night crowd loves this joint. It's pretty big as restaurants in this area go. So you're likely to find seating. It's close to North Beach and open late.  The dinner crowd at 6 pm on a Friday seemed authentically Chinese (always a good sign). The dishes I had here were way better than Sam Wo's... but you can't be the crazy Kung Fu theater like experience of eating at Sam Wo's.
author: Stephanie I.

description: Went here today with some coworkers for lunch. As a vegetarian, it was very slim pickins, but I should have expected that going to a seafood restaurant. It seemed like your standard hole in the wall kind of Chinese place, and I thought my veggie chow mein was actually pretty good. The cook seriously sounded exactly like the guy from the Fugees interludes from back in the day, which of course was awesome. In general, not a bad place but certainly nothing to write home about. The only time I could see myself coming back here is slightly inebriated at like 2am, and if I somehow found myself in this position in Chinatown at 2am I think finding food would be the least of my concerns!
author: Kathryn M.

description:
Pics of Emril, Jackie Chan, and Japanese born Yankee LF Hideki Matsui with owner seems to grab my drunken ass whenever I eat here. I order a rice plate and drink the tea.

Hmmm... soothing... getting sober... Food arrives... gobble gobble, chow, no talking with my friends when food arrives. I am focused, I eat the whole thing. I look up my friends plates are demolished. We start cracking up... "No was talking there for 10 min. bwahahaha... we were just eating..."

Good times, good food for very cheap. Open till late.
author: Jose S.

description:
This is a good place to go for a late-night Cantonese meal.  It's no frills and pricier then the typical Chinese restaurant but the food is very authentic.  

My favorites are:

- salt & pepper fried squid
- parsley beef congee 
- black bean sauce clams
- chicken with ginger and scallions
- dice chicken & salted fish fried rice
- sauteed hollow vegetable

I love having the salt/pepper fried squid with the beef congee and jalapeno soy sauce.

Tip: Great for late night dinners.
author: Lis A.

description:
I've been coming here since I was 5 yrs old.  It was a family favorite back in the day.  Funny that I am coming here now still.  

You know there is true love when you are waiting for your 3 a.m. after drinking food, and a 2 inch cockroach scuttles up the backwall,  across the ceiling, falls off trying to fly and you casually kill it and tell the waitress, who laughs and brings over a napkin to pick it up and casually takes our order.  The surprising part was that I found this completely acceptable because I didn't want to piss her off and not get my order.  This is a true story, I swear.

After the drama had passed, .we all chomped on the black bean clams, salty fish fried rice, two forms of chow mein, and salt pepper calamari and it was DAMN GOOD.
author: Scott Y.

description:
Good location, excellent hours, above-average food.  That pretty much sums it all up for Yuet Lee.

Yuet Lee serves good seafood and so-so meat dishes.  Their oyster pork stew (comes in a clay pot) is definitely worth trying.  Also worth mentioning is their clams with black bean sauce (although my white friend got creeped out by this dish).  However, the lack of brown rice is disappointing.  All in all, nothing beats some Yuet Lee after a long night of partying on weekends.

Menu items are slightly overpriced for what they are worth, probably due to the high influx of tourists around the area.  Waiters and waitresses are generally rude, restaurant is brightly lit and passably clean.
author: Bill T.

description: We came her for midnight dinner all the time!  The food was excellent and service was efficient and friendly!  Highly recommended!
author: Terry L.

description: If you want good late night chinese food, go down the street to Sun Hong Kong.  Much better food and prices.  The only drawback is if you go late, you will be with the other drunks staggering in and loud/rowdy clubbers.  Not the restaurant's fault.
author: James W.

description: Even while it was really late and we were all drunk the food only seemed ok. Drunken beef chow fun? Well I guess you can add a half star for the fact that it caters to the night owls..
author: Kim N.

description:
So I'd be foolish to not give this place my unflinching vote of 5-stars. While the food may not be the *best* in the world, it is the anchor that holds down my stomach on many late night SF evenings. Greasy chinese food and a s**t load of rice... the true hangover remedy.

Classically cantonese in both flavor and overwhelming attitude, Yuet Lee is a fairly large venue in the middle of chaotic Broadway. The staff is quick and efficient; probably in hopes of turning over the table as fast as possible. The place is packed once the bars close down so make sure to prep yourself for a wait and to dodge the occasional overly intoxicated 90 lb chick ready to yak all over the floor.

Every item here is pretty good and comes out ridiculously fast. Almost as soon as you order it, it's on the table. Awesome. My favorites thus far are always the calamari, the chicken in black bean sauce, and any beef dish. Ah screw it, it's all good. I would, however, err on the side of caution when ordering any fish items. Check out the tanks by the front door and you'll notice that, besides that the water is green, most of the fish are floating upside down. Not good.

Long live this awesomely reliable late night chinese joint with random pictures of Nicholas Cage!
author: Jonny Bobby G.

description:
I heard this place was good. They have all these reviews posted on their window...which are probably from 1945! I can't imagine anyone would want to eat there. Granted, I love me a good hole in the wall if the food is good!

Ok, please don't serve jook if you don't know how to make it. I mean, c'mon, not that hard to cook rice until it's mushy. This stuff tasted nasty and on top of that, it was all clumpy. TERRIBLE!  I was expecting the won ton soup to at least be decent...the won tons were OK but the broth was even worse than the jook. It had a weird taste and I almost believe they forgot the MSG! So disappointed to have gone to another Chinese restaurant in the middle of CHINATOWN and it be horrible! I can get better won ton soup at Andy's - which is in the middle of white folk town!
author: Josephine H.

description:
When I am in the mood for whole crispy flounder with black sauce, steamed clams, and other Chinese seafood dishes.  I don't even hesitate and I make my way with some friends to Yuet Lee in Chinatown.  They know who I am, the price is right, and the hours are late.  There are other places in town with excellent Chinese seafood, but this place is a tried and proven Chinese seafood place over the pass 12 years.  The staff knows what I want and how I want it cooked.  I've brought other people here and I've made fans out of them.

Warning!!!!  My Chinese friends don't like this place... that's OK.  I like the places they bring me to every now and then and they are all good.  I just like the personalize service I get here.  They've been good to me over the years.
author: Demanding T.

description:
I love this place, it's opened hella late and the food is fresh and yummy! Most don't even know the name of this place. Sometimes it's called "the Coke place" cause of the Coca Cola sign on the roof, other times it's called "the green place" cause of the lovely shade of green paint used on the outside and the inside of the place. It's pretty much a precious gem/hole in the wall.

Of course, I love the salt and pepper squid here. It's just so crispy, thin, and tasty. The clams with black bean sauce is very good, too. We've had the big oysters with black bean sauce served in the shell, too. The sizzling spareribs clay pot is also very tasty. I also like the bean sprout with yellow chives chow mein. We also like the jook (rice porridge) they have here that has bits of pork or beef in it, green onions, and ginger. Yummy!

This place is OG! If you come late at night, you might even see some of the chefs from top SF restaurants here. It's also very safe because the SF police like to eat here too and their station is just right around the corner. 

The pricing is very reasonable, the food is plentiful, and you get leftovers!
author: Vivian L.

description: Amazing food of all kind!! if your the average eater and dont UNDERSTAND world cuisines then shut it :) fantastic stuff here, service is typical china how ever they know the usual customers and respect them, like me :) seasonal is so good, seafood chow fun and chow mains are great, beef is quality and tender, yummy if you dont like this food something is WRONG with your mouth or your just tooooooo spoiled :) thanks Chef for great food! my spot for Chinese for sureeeee!
author: jack d.

description:
I don't know what's better, enjoying Chinese until 4 a.m. or using the giant mirror on the wall to ogle people anonymously (and to also make sure I can see the guy who stabs me in the back with a pitchfork before he does it. Got you on lock, pitchforker).

Somebody once told me that SF resident and star of the legendary "Face/Off" Nic Cage comes here. Haven't seen him, but a lot of Chinese people do come here (none with pitchforks). That has got to count for something -- cos it's Chinese food, you know. Not Popeye's (though Chinese people do go there sometimes).

Over-under on actual, real-life pitchforks in San Francisco? Unless there's a farm museum I don't know about, I'd say 10.
author: Chris R.

description:
I came here with a friend while wandering around looking for a place to try in Chinatown. We're both pretty familiar with Chinese food, so we had standards to hold. This turned out to be a pretty good choice. The ambiance is not good at all, but the prices are right. We got one plate of salt and pepper squid and one plate of clams in black bean sauce. The squid was fried perfectly, tender and not at all chewy. The clams were pretty big and meaty. My only disappointment about the food is that both were branded on the menu as "spicy", but neither were in the least. I guess if I want spicy, though, I should go to a Sichuan restaurant.
The main reason for 4 instead of 5 stars is the crappy ambiance, and the fact that there is a better Chinese restaurant in all respects near my home in Champaign, IL (which is the best I've ever been to in the States).
author: Lydia M.

description:
My favorite chinese restaurant in the city.

Its a dumpy hole in the wall, but its really quite good.  I love the salt-n-pepper deep fried spare ribs, the fresh whole fish is always great (steamed or deep fried), lots of veggie options, and their fried rice is excellent!  Its also open till 3-4am on fri/sat nights so a great place to go after a fun night out.

Also can't seem to find any other good restaurants in all of Chinatown, wtf ?  someone know of a good place for Taiwanese Beef Noodle Soup?
author: Doug C.

description:
I grew up in Asia and recently moved to SFO.  This restaurant is recommended by one of the old lady doing business in Chinatown for 25 years.  I tried the "salty fish and chicken tofu clay pot" and absolutely love it.  

The ambiance is not very fancy but who cares, as long as the food is good.  A lot of Hmong Kong movie stars had been here, Jackie Chen and Eric TSANG Chi-Wa!  

I'll definitely come back and try other dish!
author: Julin C.

description:
The food is absolutely terrible, but it's the only on Broadway open till three.

Garish neon signs and lime green walls -- death if you've got a gnarly headache from too many bloody mary's at the Crow Bar.

If you need something to settle the booze in your belly, I recommend getting the jook. It's safe, relatively speaking.
author: Perci N.

description:
Try their beef and runny egg over rice,juk (jook?), and HK style chow mein. The food or service is nothing to rave about. You'll be seated pretty promptly, as they have 2 floors. The food is standard but the prices can't be beat. I always come here with 5+ people and it's always around $5 per person to leave content. 

It's a good place to come when you need your MSG fix after drinking at 2am, but only having chunk change because you've wasted your money on buying girls and their friends drinks- whom you will never see again (fellas). Especially because it's walking distance from a hand full of bars/clubs/lounges (rising gas prices). 

This place is straight up Chinatown style: loads loud obnoxious Asian peeps, quick, fast, really bad for you food, and even the cockroach you'll find under your seat. (The lady picked it up like it was a piece of lint... *no biggy, no biggy*)
author: Jessica W.

description:
let me start with the restaurant view. it look so crappy and dirty. Second the food is sooo pricey and taste like shit  . the server there were so dam rude no fucking manner they rush me to order food very bad service but wanted good tips . when we put 3 dollars tip they complain about we tips so low .honestly they don't deserve any tips at all we were nice already to put 3 bucks.

i have to say this restaurant was the worst place i have ever been to in my life so dam regret big time.
author: John P.

description:
Seafood soup is nice
Cantonese for Caucasians?
Pics of Jackie Chan
author: Andrew B.

description: Bad food and dirty, dont get fool all the celebraties took picture qith the owner. I am chinese, I dont eat in chinatown. D I R T Y
author: Philip H.

description:
I've eaten here more than once, even because this place is open until 3am, there aren't too many restaurants you can actually eat good food this late in San Francisco, five star to that.
The problem is that the food is not consistent, sometime is superb and some other time is mediocre. But the seafood soup with tofu...you can always count on that.
The lightening is very bright, so, especially if you go there late, is a little annoying .
The service is very fast, but not a minimum of interaction.
Good prices.
author: Sergio D.

description:
I have been coming to this place for over 15 years. I've always been impressed with the pan fry (hong kong style) BBQ chow mein. That chow mein is probably the best there is in San Francisco. 

However, I was just there for Thanksgiving 2012 and though the food was good, I was however, disappointed with the way the head waiter treated me. I noticed earlier in the evening that the head waiter was arguing with another patron at the end of their meal but wasn't sure exactly what it was about. Another table behind me faced the same fate towards the end of their meal as well. When it came time for my final bill, the head waiter came over (not the same one that I've had all night, mind you) and stood next to me, waiting for me to pay the bill. This place was near empty by the time I was finishing up dinner with my father and it was not even close to closing, nor was my father finished with his meal. I pay the bill to get the guy away from staring at us and then the head waiter returns with my change, he says to me, "30%, you must leave a tip at 30%". I'm not sure what thats all about, so I asked the waiter, about the percentage. I was certainly not going to stiff the wait staff, but the head waiter then began to tell me what my tip was to be at the 30% range and insisted I gave him (not the female waiter who had been doing the work all night), the tip. He again stood by and counted the tip in front of me and said I had to pay more (I left a $10 tip as it was). 

Sorry, but I'm not paying nearly half the price of my meal towards a tip. We ordered 2 items...give me a break! 

After this experience, I won't be coming back and certainly, won't be recommending this place to friends that come to experience Chinatown.
author: CB S.

description: If you want authentic Cantonese food this is the place to go!  Food was definitely ready in a flash, quality was great, and food was like grandma's cooking.  Couldn't have asked for more! Would highly recommend to friends and family which I already have!
author: Nathan L.

description: This place must be good.  We sat next to Charles Phan from Slanted Doors.
author: Minh N.

description:
This seems like a popular place for late nighters because they are open until 3am on Fri and Sat. I can see the salt and pepper squid to be great when you are drunk, but I came here for lunch (sober) and the food was just ok. Very greasy and full of MSG. 

I may be back, but only after the after parties.
author: Ava C.

description: Genuine Asian cuisine in Chinatown, open late, late night.  Order sides of rice to compensate for small entree portions.  The salt and pepper fried calamari is excellent.
author: Chet M.

description: i was there , food was bad and expansive .... just lost my money cuz I didn't eat
author: Abderrocs R.

description:
Okay, I see there are several mixed reviews here so let's get things straight about the good and the bad.

Bad
1. Ambience sucks, dirty fish tanks with crab and some fish
2. Kitchen can be seen from dining area and it looks dirty
3. There is a lady who uses the round table towards the back to fill won tons (raw meat!! Yuck!!)
4. Wait staff don't make you feel like you are a king/queen
Good
1. Extremely fast
2. Cheap
3. Location is great if you don't drive (I happen to like Chinatown)
4. Last and not least, the food is great...but the duck is kinda on the greasy side. But hey, walk up and down those Chinatown/northbeach hills for 20 minutes and you will be good.

So all in all, I like the place and have only found out about it two weeks ago and have already been there twice. Until my food starts tasting bad, I see a rat in the kitchen, or I get sick I will continue to go there.

BTW: Chicken fried rice and chicken chow mein is amazing. I haven't had hong kong style chow mein in a while.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
After a fire breathing experience at Vietnam down the street we were still hungry. Yeah, we like to eat, ALOT. We got the go to dishes calamari and ginger beef. I absolutely love the calamari. It's fresh and flashed fried perfect drunk food. The ginger beef is always a can't miss, sustenance when you can barely stand. 
   We came her once before with some friends after a drunken night of Karaoke at Bow Bow. We got the fresh fish prepared house style. It was AMAZING! So fresh that we got to pick the fish, so drunk I made my boyfriend eat the eyeball. 
  A must stop after a drunken night in Chinatown.
author: Douggers M.

description:
Definitely in the upper echelon of late night dining choices in the North Beach / Chinatown area, or anywhere for that matter. Also a good choice if you find yourself in North Beach on a weekend night and don't feel like waiting an hour for mediocre Italian, as the dinner crowds are usually not overwhelming.

You don't come here for the chow mein, general's chicken, cashew chicken, or other such bland Americanized fare. You come here for the seafood (can't miss the salt and pepper squid or the clams in oyster sauce!), or perhaps that Peking spare ribs or the yummy sauteed greens!

No complaints about the service: the waiters are actually remembering us and our favorite dishes. Maybe I should be slightly afraid...
author: Seth R.

description:
Yuet Lee... A place of consistency.  I have never been sober at Yuet Lee.  Timmy is always behind the counter.  Peter is always working the floor.  The food is always great  
     I don't know what any of it is called, they always order for us.  I've walked in there multiple times, intent on ordering my whole meal, but usually as soon as i look at the menu I give up.  It's huge, and you won't see many familiar dishes, but everything I have tasted out of that kitchen has been good.  That's pretty impressive, considering how many things I've tried out of there and having never actually requested any of them.
author: ryan g.

description: One of my favorite holes in Chinatown, but easy to find when your drunk on any late night.  They are open to about 3am.  Try the Flounder w/ bok choy, or the crispy fried chow mein w/ prawn.  Those are two of my fav's. There can be a little bit of a wait when they are busy, but its not too bad. The ambiance aint anything to write about, lino floors and lots of green motif, but hey thats there favorite color.
author: James H.

description:
If you have high cholesterol, a heart condition OR are on a low sodium diet, AVOID Yuet Lee!

If not, they have THE tastiest Salt & Pepper Squid (calamari, basically) EVER!!! 

And their Salt & Pepper Pork Spareribs? So TENDER & scrumptious! 

Be sure to order lots of steamed rice, because one order of rice is barely enough for one person. And you will need something to absorb all the S&P from entering your bloodstream. 

NOTE: It may not be pretty inside, but they are pretty $pricey$ for a Chinese restaurant AND they are CASH ONLY!
(There is, however, an ATM across the street. While it is an Asian bank of some sort, they do accept PLUS, STAR & other major card networks & they will prompt you for language at the start of your transaction).

Also, do not be discouraged if when passing by their window you notice all their tables are occupied; they have a secret VIP dining room in the basement with it's own restroom!

Hey, if it's good enough for Nicholas Cage, it's good enough for me!
author: John Eric S.

description: This place was awesome.  Seafood was so fresh and taste was perfect.  We ate so much.  I think the waiters were staring and laughing at us.  Great chinese seafood restaurant.  Sat down pretty quickly.  Parked a bit far though in a pay lot since it was raining and since there's like no parking close by.
author: Amy L.

description:
So one day, while perusing Chinatown with its loads of tourists, dwellers, and smells - I realized I wanted some good Chinese food. I pointed over at this corner restaurant not knowing what Yuet Lee was. Saw a "people love us on yelp" sticker and gave it a try. The restaurant is pretty small and has that grimy feel you get from the seats and tables wiped down from a dirty towel.

I was overcome by the sight of the food however. Interior aside, the food looked great. I was browsing the menu when all I could do was look at the table next to us with their mountain of crab and ice cold Tsingtao. I quickly ordered a beer of my own and we ordered some braised beef and noodles along with some salty fish chicken fried rice. The food came out in a matter of minutes and I could have sworn we finished the food faster than it came out.

Service was attentive, but then again we sat literally right next to the cook. I was definitely impressed by the food and will definitely come back here the next time I'm in Chinatown.
author: John B.

description:
Overpriced...

There are better food out there, even the late night joints.
author: Stanley L.

description: If I could have given a 0 star rating, I would have. My husband and I ate here last Sunday after a nice outing to San Francisco. Even though this place looked somewhat dirty and the waiter was kind of rude when we walked in, we decided to give it a chance. What a HUGE mistake. My husband ordered the clams and I had the pork and oysters in a ginger sauce. It was somewhat strange since we received our dishes in less than 10 min, so I'm guessing they are not made fresh. His dish was far too overcooked and rubbery. My pork was fairly good, but the oysters were so disgusting that I literally almost barfed. The waiter was by far one of the rudest people that I have ever encountered. He looked so annoyed when we took literally 5 min to decide what to order, and was really snippy when I asked for more water. We were only partially done with our meal before he handed us the check. When we paid the check, we were only going to leave 10% because the service was horrible. When the waiter saw this--- he said "4 more dollars". The food is way overpriced and the waitstaff is rude--- do not go here. My husband and I were both really sick for the rest of the night.
author: Julia T.

description:
Our bill was 48 bucks.... we gave the lady 54 bucks... what followed was a big scene that was very embarrasing to me and my friends... the lady was complaining saying we didnt pay enough, and with her broken english, we kept thinking she was blind because she didnt the cash, but really she was complaining that we didnt leave a 10 percent tip, she kept saying we owe 2 dollars more or some shit, fuck it, the service sucked, the food was okay, but its not as good as its cracked up to be...

dont eat here unless you you wanna be forced to pay a large tip.
author: Jeffrey B.

description: I came here to eat with my girl.  It was pretty good. I like the mango chicken it was lean not fatty.   Also had long beans and beef.  I forgot the third.  Gave a 10 dollar tip for 30.00 which was too much.
author: John F.

description:
Man I'm loving the pan-fried noodles. They might be even better for breakfast. And the salt and pepper squid was AWESOME.

Duck was so-so, and the beef clay pot was pretty good too. When I come back though I'm definitely hitting up some more pan-fried noodles.
author: Stu M.

description:
Don't want to put them out of business, but a bug was discovered in our food.  Enough said.  We immediately left.

For those reading, maybe this is the first time it happen?  I would say don't reject this restaurant unless you read this from others.
author: Sandra L.

description:
Excellent Chinese short-order kitchen! 

If you want Americanized Chinese food or a formal dining experience don't go here. It will be loud, flourescent, everything will have bones in it, lots of dishes will be really salty, and the waiter/waitress will be short and curt with you, just the way it should be.

Especially important because of the hours, most places where you can really eat like this close by 7PM, but Yuet Lee is open very late and conveniently located to pounce on after a North Beach barcrawl.
author: Essron J.

description: My friends and I came here on 1-17-10 about 2am.  We ordered the salt and pepper pork chop, beef chow fun(narrow instead of the wide noodles),and the small order of soup which includes sturgeon,parsley,thin slices of ginger.  The food is good and we killed them.
author: Jer W.

description: Taste wise the food was good. However the service and quantity of the plates were terrible! Our waitress never came to the table other than bringing the plates of food, and in the end demanded a $8 tip for minimal service!! I don't freaking think so. But because I am a too nice I gave them $2 of tips and even then a lady who was not even our waitress demanded bigger tip. The quantity food was horrible, we demanded a full order but seemed more of half a order of food but were charged full price. As I looked around at the other tables I could not help but notice that everyones had much larger food portions except us, which led me to believe the waitress has something against us. This will be last time I will be coming to this place. But if you decide for yourself be prepared for mediocre food, overpriced, and horrible service.
author: Mayra B.

description:
EXPENSIVE FOR SMALL PORTIONS!
-When I opened the menu, I wanted to leave immediately but one of my friends wanted to try here. The prices are doubled compared to other restaurants.
-The food are served on small plates.

I ordered the seafood with rice and it was horrible. It was not even seafood! It was mostly bokchoy! The price for it was outrageous, almost $10! For $10, I would have expected better quality and bigger sized dishes. 

The restroom was extremely dirty. I would have expected it to be clean since there were so many waiters just standing there. 

This place is just to cheat tourists.
author: Winnie Y.

description: I went there twice, tried out their Beef Chow Fun & Clam w/ Black Bean Sauce.  Simply the best in the Bay Area.
author: Pat Y.

description:
So somehow after a long day trip up to and through Napa valley, we make it back to the city. Exhausted and craving something quick and easy, we swing by Yuet Lee around 9 or so for some Chinese before planning to go out with other friends. Now, I had been here at least two or three times in the past year, but this was the first time before midnight. (I was about to say the first time sober, but we did just come back from Napa... still, it was probably the first time I remember everything about eating here). Anyway, the three of us just ordered pretty standard noodles (one with seafood, two with roast pork) and the food turns out pretty quick and really hits the spot.

Don't come in here expecting world-class Chinese food, but if you're just looking for a nice late-night fix, this should do it. Also, the decor is bright yet dingy. The smell? I don't even notice.. We are in Chinatown after all. Feels about right to me.

After we finish eating, our bill comes out to $19.20-something and my friend decides to treat us. Hands the waiter his Visa but the waiter points out that it's a $20 minimum for credit card. "Seriously? Uh.. can you just put in 20?" ... -= befuddled silence from the waiter =-... "..or.. sure, just add a Coke. I'll take it to go."
author: Alex C.

description:
I have not dined in there yet BUT really want to give a word on their Chinese tamale.  They used to make these giant tamales which will be hanged up next to the kitchen.  It's tasty, giant in size and worth the price.  My hubby loved it and he would request me to buy one for him every time I went to Chinatown.

However, one day when I passed by Yuet Lee and just in the mood to give my hubby a surprise on this tamale, the worker there told me that they did not make it any more.  I asked her why and she told me that the demand was not that high but there are a lot of efforts to make one.  Too bad, my hubby is still searching for a replacement now but cannot find one yet.
author: Roserrele W.

description:
LUVIT.
LateNight Chinese Food, open till 3am.
Need I say more?
The foodis..... as i remember it FABULOUS!

(would i go back sober and ruin my precious fond memories?Nope.Drunkard Ignorance is bliss)

wait.  i just ate raw egg
author: Tak H.

description:
drunk food is never actually good.  it is just good when youre drunk. i was not drunk.  but my drunk friends were drunk.  and they were hungry.  so i found myself here again.  once in a blue moon.  in flurescent ugly lights after a night out.  

the food is not great.  i wouldnt even call it good.  some things are ok.  we got a spinach tofu fish ball soup and it was gross because the fish balls melted in my mouth.  maybe they were rotten.  scrambled eggs with shrimp over wide rice noodles.  scrambled eggs with beef over rice.  beef chow fun.  chow mein.  thousan year egg pork porridge. satay beef.  all decent.

i think the staff there try to deal as best as possible with all the drunkards.  theyre pretty good.  seated all 10 of us really quickly downstairs.  the place is a bit dirty.  but what do you expect.  $10 per person. for our late night meal.
author: claudia y.

description:
Dad had beef w/ cashews, broccoli, and mushrooms, along with some won ton soup. He loved it.

I had noodle soup w/ barbeque pork. It was OK.

So I'll average the review to 4 stars.

Service was good and price was reasonable.
author: Randy W.

description:
This is one of the best places to go in SF at 2:00 am after all the clubs and lounges close.  It may not be the prettiest restaurant, but the food is really yummy and is delivered to your table quickly.  This is especially good after a long night of drinking, when nothing tastes better than Chinese food that is clearly not good for you.  

My top picks are the salt and pepper spareribs, crispy noodles with chicken and salty fish fried rice.  The salty fish friend rice never smells the nicest, but it sure is tasty. Try it and you'll see what I mean.
author: Trisha H.

description:
Considering we called in our order at around 2:30 a.m. and arrived at 3:01 to a table with our food laid out and nice and hot...I give it 4 stars! 

After assembling my new IKEA furniture from midnight to 2:30ish....we were famished. This place isn't better than some of  the places in Alhambra and Monterey Park down south but it holds its own.

The bok choy sum & black bean clam dishes were really good. Peking ribs were ok/decent.
author: Sabrina L.

description: Great food. Always open. Friendly service. Look up the 10 items posted on the wall under the heading 'famous' items before you order from the menu.
author: Jishnu M.

description:
A late night (off work late for me, late class for my friend) quest for wonton soup led us to the Chinatown/North Beach area at 10:30 PM.  With the intention of going to Tuttimelon on Broadway afterwards, we decided to stick around Stockton/Broadway so we could walk to our frozen cravings after dinner.

I yelped a few places for wonton soup, since that's what both of us really wanted, and Broadway Cafe and Yuet Lee came up.  My very Chinese friend also recommended these two, and so we parked and tried to decide which one to go to.  I'd been to Broadway Cafe, and my friend had eaten at Yuet Lee before, so he wasn't feeling adventurous and made the executive decision to skip Broadway Cafe.

Breakdown of the 3-star score (which is sad, considering the previous reviews are 4- or 5-stars):

Location: 5 stars.  Parking is easy at night (no meters).
Cleanliness: 4 stars.  Great for a Chinese restaurant that isn't white-washed.
Service: 4 stars.  Efficient and not super friendly, but still courteous.  I asked the guy if he liked BBQ pork wonton soup, or the beef stew won ton soup, and he said he didn't like either of them.  Kudos for honesty and not trying to sell us anything he didn't like.
Menu: 5 stars.   I need to come back here when I'm absolutely starving.
Prices: 4 stars.  I've seen cheaper, but I've also seen more expensive.  Portions aren't as big as I thought they were going to be.
Bok Choy: 4 stars.  Greasy, but oh-so-delicious with the garlic sauce.
Wonton Soup: 2 stars.  The wontons were okay (but nothing compares to my grandma's wontons), but the noodles were like a mass of over-bleached, over-permed hair, and the soup was so bland that not even salt and soy sauce could help it.

Overall, it's a pretty good place but NOT for wontons.  I'd seriously just come back here for bok choy.  Oh, and if you speak Chinese, you should ask the waiter if they like beef stew or bbq pork wonton soup.
author: Tori S.

description:
Even though the atomsphere is lacking, the food isn't. Its not exactly cheap, but the portions are very good (I only had the chicken chow mein, but it was plenty for my appetite at the time). The seafood looked good especially the oyster as many people seemed to be ordering them.

Update: Had the Young Chow Friend Rice (shrimp & bbq pork). The pork was so good that I should have just gotten the pork friend rice without the shrimp. Also order the Noodles with Seafood which I really can't recommend. The noodles were decent but the shrimp and scallops just didn't have much flavor. The other items, mainly squid and slimy mushrooms, just seemed to be thrown in at the last minute.

Update: Made a BIG mistake and ordered the BBQ Spare Ribs in Black Bean sauce. I expected the same small spare ribs I found at most chinese restaraunts growing up. These however, were small pieces of actual rib with an even smaller amount of meat surrounding. I couldn't even bring myself to finish them and stuck with the always safe BBQ Pork Chow Mein instead.

Update: The BBQ Pork Fried rice is consistently good, as well as the Pepper and Salt Squid.
author: Nicolas H.

description:
Salt & Pepper Squid... Yuet Lee doesn't spend a dime on decor, but what they do spend on is quality food. Their authentic style dishes warm your soul, be careful for the line.. it might just wrap around the door.

Enjoy a delicious meal.. I've never been disappointed.. and that's a first.
author: Aimee C.

description:
Amazing salt and pepper squid. I'm the skinny chick ordering two plates (no joke. They always ask when I sit down if I want two plates!) And the garlic watercress hits the spot for some veggies.

Top it off with some ice cold Tsing Tao around midnight, and you've got a pretty typical San Francisco old-skool Chinatown experience.

They do accept credit cards now (recent development).
Closed Tuesdays (odd day!) and it's got a ton of fluorescent lights (that's why it's 4 and not 5 stars).
author: dj z.

description:
How can you go wrong with fresh seafood and fast service? Can you ask for anything else?? Ive been coming here since I was 10 and it has been the most consistent in everyway. The owner has been there and I still remember wen he was a little thinner. =) I always order the beef with scrambled eggs,salt and pepper squid,ginger pork and oyster clay pot,Bbq pork and hk style crispy noodle!! all are a great choice. and it closes super late!!!

 If your ever around the broadway area check this place out. there are allot of drunks that go there late night so I wouldnt bring kids out with you that late. also good luck trying to find parking during the day..
author: Joseph G.

description:
I've had plenty of drunken nights that have been cured by Yuet Lee.  Their eggs and beef over rice is my food of choice but tell them to have the eggs and beef and then a side of rice.  Otherwise it'll come in a more runny egg style, which is still great, but not as good. 

I once saw Daniel Dae Kim from Lost here eating.  I tried to make eye contact with him so that I could tell him his Korean was getting better.  But he was focusing on what looked to be a Lobster dish.
author: Dan Y.

description:
I am not kidding when i say that you should probably not go here sober.  I believe that they don't actually wash their dishes. 

regardless, it is delicious after hours....just don't look around at the decor or toward the kitchen area...or directly at your waiter.
author: Roy N.

description: The best fried calamari I've ever had. Perfectly fried light and crispy. Everything was amazing. Chow mien noodles were perfect. The fried spare ribs reminded me of fried chicken. Crunchy salty juicy goodness. Curried beef with rice, and Kung pow prawns. This is the best Chinese food I've ever had. If ur in San Fran u must go down to Chinatown and feast on this goodness.
author: Scot Y.

description:
got to San Fran around 10, and my friends and i were craving Chinese food.
found this little place a couple blocks from our hotel.
got in and the waitress gave us a weird look but we ignored it (we were starving)
i ordered the Mongolian beef and a side of steamed rice, my friends got seafood chow mien, vegetable beef (or something like that) and wanton soup.
the wait time was average and the meat was decent for a little place on the corner.
but the manager would always pass by and glare at us, the waitress continuously ignored my friends and only paying attention to me, leaving me to continuously flag her down to ask for more water or another soda. 
we ate our fill and asked for the checks (we ordered separately)
she came back with our checks and change and reminded us every time before she handed us our change back that it didn't include tip. 
we told her we knew and she reminded us again.
my friends were annoyed by the service so they didn't want to tip
i left 3 dollars since she got my sodas and didn't want to leave nothing,
as soon as i put the money down the manager came over to the table and counted the dollars.
he then said "oh 3$ but there's 4 of you, who didn't tip? that's not enough tip"
my friends were dumbstruck , even i repeated that last part.
my friend threw down a dollar and we just left .
it was a rude way to end a night.
never going back there
author: Manny P.

description:
I dont even know the amount of times my alcohol influenced friends have come to this spot after a night of partying. This place has simply came to known as the "Green Restaurant" to me and my friends. Usually the place is packed around 2am on a friday or saturday night. The service is average at best, but what can u expect from a fast paced chinese restaurant filled with a bunch of drunk hungry people at 2am? I must admit, they do tolerate a lot  tho..  from people throwing chicken in the air to spur of the moment waterfights. LOL =X  We even got a lecture from one of the waiters complaining to us once, saying that one of our friends ALWAYS comes in too drunk, and starts wandering in and out of the restaurant acting a fool (No names but his name starts with a R and ends with YAN. LOL!) 

Enough about our experiences, the service is fairly accommodating considering the circumstances. They tend to rush you tho at 2 cuz they're about to close at 3am. We love coming to the Green Restaurant. The salt and pepper calamari is soooo good. They also have a good variety of other foods, ranging from rice dishes, noodles, seafood, porridge etc. Pretty good for greasy chinese food. Definitely satisfying, week in and week out. Just dont let them catch you trying to grab one of the fish with your hand from the fishtank! HAHAHA. Two thumbs up for the Green Restaurant!
author: jeff y.

description: I don't know what made us eat at this place, but I'm glad that we did. I guess it was the funky color of the restaurant that caught my eye. Walking into the establishment is not really impressive by all means, but like they say "you can't judge a book by its cover". Oh yeah there is a picture of Nicholas Cage and the owner on the wall. Just thought that was a fun fact. The staff was very welcoming and provided us with exceptional service. There was not one time during our meal that my glass of water was ever empty. We ordered the usual that we order at a new place, Salt n' pepper pork, pan fried noodles w/ beef and bok choy. Oh, and a side of white rice. I was impressed because the quality of the food is what you would expect at a fancy restaurant. If you are in the area, you have to drop by and give it a try. Oh yeah if you you leave less than what the bill is at the table, a lady will run you down, let you know and demand you leave a tip. Ha ha ha. True story don't ask.
author: Michael C.

description:
Perhaps I am not accustomed to Cantonese fare, but I found this place unappetizing.  The seafood soup had little taste.  The squab was dry.  The shrimp with scrambled eggs was mushy.  But maybe it's supposed to be that way.  I plead ignorance, but ignorance is this case was not bliss.

(Disclaimer: I was drunk enough at that point of the night, where I wouldn't trust my own judgment.  But then again, greasy food usually tastes amazing at that time of night. )
author: Paul K.

description:
The city offers many options for the starving person, who leaves the bar/club/party/art show/ whathaveyou once the announcement for 'last call' has been heard and he/she stumbles outside into the cold wondering where they should go to soak up all the nectar that was consumed from the previous hours of debauchery.  From liquids to solids, where to go?.....theres the typical pizza joints, the crepe spot i kindof ?enjoy on 11th...and other cafes of sorts around downtown.....,
but if your looking for something that taste good sober or not, a place that is filling, and  food that is good to 'soak up' the 'mixed' juices..look to this famous location where pictures of greats like "jean claude van damm'' standing with the chef hangs on the wall along side other pictures of notable celebrities...... 

a destination i would want to go to even when im not in the city,... there have been times where i have craved this place at 2 a.m when im at home in the east bay...and drove out there....just to get some food.... 

The decor is what it is...but service has always been fast and simple and the food speaks for itself....try the calamari......
author: dates w.

description:
Stardate...February 26...4:18am...spent a quiet Monday night with a few friends having take-out Italian from Buca di Beppo's and in the midst of writing the review I get a phone call from my infamous jeweler neighbor Khoren..."...uhhh you seem to have a lot of light on in your place..."  followed by me saying  "...are you outside my door?  do you wanna have a drink?"  

Three quarters bottle of Grants scotch whisky later around 2:10am we called a taxi to pick us up to head out for some good ol' "solid" chinese greasy food to soak up some 40 proof out of our system.  
This called for some spare ribs with black bean sauce over rice, prawns with crispy pan fried chow mein, and a side order of salt & pepper prawns w/ soy sauce and as much sliced jalapenos as you have left in the place!  There's nothing like GOOD-greasy (yes there is a difference b/t greasy and "good" greasy) chinese food late at night after some significant EtOH consumption.  Yuet Lee opens til 3am and never disappoints when you need some gastric filler.  And, if you know the owner, you can order the "special" tea that's served cold w/ a hint of "hops & barley."

Well, I've gotta be up in 2 1/2 hours to shower and freshen up and head to the airport for my 8:30am flight to Santa Barbara so I'll wrap it up here.   Catch you on my next review from the central coast wine country!
author: Rick P.

description:
This place reminds me of the little hole- in- the- walls in my home town.  Greasy, a bit out of place, your dinner floating in the fish tank as you walk in and you can't forget the old bossy Asian Lady telling you to sit down now.  

The quality of the veggie food was okay.  The tofu didn't take the freshest and the sauces weren't spectacular.  The location is fun! Right in the middle of China Town.  You feel a bit caught up in this foreign land and wonder if your still in SF.  The plethora of open markets of produce and fish is amazing to see.

BUT the Chinese broccoli was very good!

VEggie Friendly: Somewhat.
author: ashley l.

description: Came here when visiting San Fran at the advice of Yelp and was not disappointed. Super divey and super delicious. The salt and pepper squid is a revelation as is the tenderloin with pepper. Cannot complain about anything and wish I was still around the corner.
author: Alexandra S.

description:
I don't go here until I am pretty drunk and want chinese food...this used to happen to me a lot until I weighed 300 lbs. and then I stopped both.  

Thank goodness.

My friend once tried to free the catfish from the fish tank.  He thought he was funny until one of the staff came at him with a butcher knife.
author: Dan D.

description:
Good. Fast. Greasy but not overly so.

OK for a whitey like me to go to, not know
how to pronounce anything on the menu
properly and still feel welcome.
author: Mike R.

description:
The food's pretty good, but I always feel like I spend four or five bucks on a meal more than I should have.  It's not the highest quality, and it's not the nicest setting-- so why does dinner end up 15-20 per?

Is it to repaint the restaurant in the same brilliant green every week?

Is it to keep the riffraff one or two blocks away?

Did they shell out an appearance fee for Nicolas Cage, who is wearing an absolutely ridiculous hat and jacket in a photo hanging on the wall?

I've been multiple times, and I can't put my finger on it.  Time to call in the I-Team.  If "Yuet Lee" means "Service Charge" in Cantonese, I'll be pissed.
author: Jeff M.

description:
don't get stuck in the basement seating.. what ever you do don't go down there.  it's roach infested.  If it's full upstairs..wait for an open table.  I still like the food.. but I think their prices keep creeping up higher, due to all you tourists!! lol.  I don't eat in chinatown too much just because it's dirty.  yuet lee is one of those places when you don't feel like exploring and settle because you know your gonna get a decent flavorful product. 
As with all Chinese restaurants I stay away from most beef dishes because they tenderize it to the point of beyond regonition because they use cheap cuts of beef.
author: David T.

description:
I dropped by here on a Sunday afternoon and ordered "sliced sturgeon and tender vegetables." It was good, if rather squidgy, until I pulled out a very long hair. Nasty, and also very odd, since the guy in the kitchen (and standing next to Jackie Chan, Emeril and others in pictures lining the wall) has a shaved head.

But I was hungry, so I sent it back and ordered beef dumpling noodle soup instead. The dumplings had a certain ginger-chive zing to them, but the broth and noodles tasted of little more than MSG. It took a few Fernet Brancas at the Vesuvio to settle my stomach and restore my spirit.

That said, several large Chinese parties and a smattering of tourists seemed to be really enjoying big plates of mussels and crabs. If I had enough cash and a big enough group, I might come back to give it another go, but probably not.
author: Eric S.

description:
I've dined there twice. For some reason it's one of those grungy Chinatown restaurants that is very popular with a diverse crowd. It's not that cheap, and it's not all that good. The food is tasty enough. I liked the Peking Spare Ribs, and the Gai Lan. The Pan Fried noodles was ok, I've had better. 

I liked it enough to go back, and I suppose I might go back again if I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Adrian L.

description:
So we stumbled on this place purely on a whim needing food before I went DJ'd at Rosewood Lounge. We saw the place was packed but it looked like it would be a great quick meal; its amazing how correct that statement was!

This place serves up some damn tasty food and all of it fresh and rather good on the wallet. We had a nice dish of Prawns and Veggies, again just wanting a quick meal before I headed up the street for some wicka wicka wicka! Overall it was great, I honestly was a bit shocked about how tasty this dish was and how fresh everything tasted.

I can not wait to return and try their garlic crab! Another great highlight of this place is the fresh tanks they have. Tanks are usually a great sign and this place is serving up some fresh stuff!

So you will arrive like this.....all cute and skinny and stufff

   (\.......(\
  ( = ' . ' =)
   =(   .   )=
      n---n   


And Leave Like This....



          (\.......(\
         ( = ' ~ ' =)
   =(          .         )=
            n---n   

Bloated n fatty!
author: Jay D.

description: It's the "what's open this late Denny's" of Chinatown.  But it's really good.  Service here is fast, abrupt, and almost rude...but you come here to eat some good Chinese food, and not to be greeted.  They have a cool downstairs area that they open up when the upstairs gets overcrowded.
author: Ernesto L.

description: I only go there past 1am on Friday or Saturdays, but their fried rice is a must have for anyone coming from the clubs or bars.  You must ask for their finest house wine when there...it's not on the menu, and you might just get it in a red cup if you're lucky..
author: Bryan L.

description:
Pretty good place! It opens til late and the food is pretty good. You have to pay $20 minimum before you use your credit card though. 

I got the chicken fried rice. Yummy!
author: Magi Y.

description:
3.5 Stars
Open late
Know for their seafood dishes 
I'd come here again late night
Better quality than DNA for the seafood
Service is also better here
For those of you trying to gauge a good Chinese restaurant look for locals eating there

Trust me..... I am Asian
author: Po L.

description: I had a horrible experience here.  I get along with cabbies and this time our cab driver took us for a late night snack.  He actually came in and ate with us because we wanted to thank him for taking us.  I ordered a wonton noodle soup and I wanted to love it but I couldn't .  It tasted like ammonia, like the broth did.  I ate as much as I could but I thought wow, maybe they accidentally spilled some in there?  Made me kind of nauseous.
author: Shiho F.

description:
Great Place !!!
Did you know that the owner paints his house the same color -- GREEN !
No JOke
author: Roy L.

description: Last time I went here was almost 3 years ago the "catfish" hotpot as inedible... grossly over cooked, and my friends dish was i don't know what and equally disastrous. The service was rude and they kept us waiting around forever, when we finally left we thought a 10% tip was appropriate for rude service and AWFUL food, they yelled at us and demanded we tip them more. In retrospect, I should have demanded my money back. Too bad there are so many sucker tourists that eat there because this place could use a real change.
author: J R.

description: Expensive expensive expensive.  If it weren't for my friend's birthday, I would have gone elsewhere.  Bleeh!
author: C L.

description:
Seriously - another over hyped and over rated place.  This is like a mini House of Nan King except they have a variation of sauces in different color.  

Why on earth hubby and I decided we should give this place a try after our last visit over 25 years ago (separately) is beyond us.  Somehow we figured it just can't be that bad...it's definitely not good.  If not for all the heavily liquored patrons, this place likely will not last for all these years.  Ever notice the majority of the patrons here are non-Asians...yeah, enough said.

We came here to try their wor wonton - it's basically wonton with a mixture of stir fried seafood and meat w/ gravy pour over the wonton.  If it's good, it's damn good.  They have it in 4 sizes.  At 11ish, the place was pretty busy.  We didn't want to wait so we shared a big round table with another 2 couples.  We ordered the medium wor wonton ($9.50?)and was told there is a $6/person minimum.  Really?  I don't remember seeing any sign or on the menu but whatever.  We added the eight precious noodle ($6.50?).  The waitress must have told us 3x that we already have a soup with the wonton and should get something stir fried instead even though we told her again and again we wanted the soup noodle.  Maybe we should have listened to her because the noodle was not good.  It was over cooked and tasted soapy, this happens when they didn't rinse the noodle thoroughly.  The wonton was not good, just meat.  The soup was not good, salty.  The one American couple next to us had bbq pork that did not look very appetizing at all - too much red dye and extremely dry.

Nothing worse than having an unsatisfying meal before going to sleep.  No more Yuet Lee.
author: Gloria H.

description:
My favorite restaurant in Chinatown, and I'm really picky.  For a long time I walked by here without stopping in because it's always full of white people and that seemed like a really bad sign. But who knows why, the usual rule of thumb doesn't apply in this case. Their seafood is REALLY good. I've brought a lot of Chinese friends here over the last couple of years; they were always skeptical but after a meal starting bringing THEIR friends. So I know it wasn't BS, they really liked the food.

For best results, stick to the seafood--steamed fish is the freshest (you vet the live fish prior to sacrifice). Oysters, clams, squid, shrimp, all top notch. I don't much like crab, but I've heard those are also excellent. It's not seafood, but I've had spareribs in various preparations and they're always delicious too. However, the duck was disappointing, not as fresh as I like.

Prices are higher than some places in Chinatown and the ambience is fluorescent & formica, but in addition to the great seafood I love the family feel. Always the same friendly, familiar faces whenever you show up, morning or night. Very simpatico.
author: Bambooo S.

description:
After an evening of being with gay men and having a gay boyfriend in his drunken state put four crumpled dollars in my hand and say, "Turn that into Shrimp Fried Rice", I acquiesced to their desire of grubbing at Yuet Lee. 

This place is crackalackin' at 3 AM!! 

I find it pretty insane people want to consume heavy food at this time of night (well, morning!). I mean, really. Wow. I didn't even finish my bowl of congee. Overall, it's a restaurant that gets a lot of action because it is right at the end of the tunnel that connects Chinatown to Downtown (from South VanNess) and it's right on a corner with fluorescent lighting. The lighting almost reminds me of those bug lamps people use to attract and kill insects. Sorry, not the best metaphor (especially describing a place where you eat!) but it fits. The food definitely was not horrible but it wasn't great either. It's two levels so if you don't see a seat for 10 of your friends after a night of drinking and dancing, not to fear, you can wobble your butt down to the subterranean seating. Lastly, please beware of the bathroom (have you ever seen Trainspotting?), I would rather get a UTI than use their restroom - that says a lot!
author: Dorothy S.

description:
late night chinese, you're bound to run into someone here that you saw at the club just minutes ago. in fact i did!

the prices are a bit steep for the chinese food you're getting, but you're getting it late night.

they ran out of chow fun noodles at 2am, i was really looking forward to some. but that salt and pepper fried porkchop was deeelish!
author: Ameer N.

description:
We had taken a tour of China Town (8/20) and our tour guide recommended this place for authentic Cantonese food. Everything written about the décor and service is spot on but being from New York, we've seen much worst. After all, we were here for the food and not necessarily the ambiance. It was 8:30 pm and the place was busy but we were seated right away. Two menus were flung at us and within seconds a lady was asking us what we wanted to order. As typical in many Chinese restaurants, the menus tend to be quite extensive and this place was no exception. We asked the waitress for some suggestions and she pointed to a few of the specials. (Hint: There is a Top Ten list of most popular dishes located right above the second table to the right as you enter.) I ordered the Crab Sautéed with Ginger and Green Onions which at $28 was a little steep and my gf the Peking Spare Ribs (Sweet and Sour) for $8.25. We ordered a bowl of rice, which we were told would be extra and two Tsing Tao. 

Within minutes, the spare ribs arrived. Actually, they were more like pork chops. The portion was pretty large and well prepared although my gf thought they were a little too sweet. The crab would take a little longer since they had just fished it out of the tank. When the crab arrived, we were shocked at the size of it. This thing was massive! The gf worked on the legs and claws while I dug into the meat inside the shell. Good eats! We had two more Tsing Tao and before we knew it, a check was slapped on our table. Total came to $65.75 which for Chinese food is on the high end but I did order a pretty expensive dish. Next time, I'll probably stick with the more common dishes. Overall, it was a pretty decent meal. Definitely worth trying but only if you're in the area.
author: Jorge S.

description:
I had been having fierce cravings for some salt and pepper shrimp or squid when the manfriend actually volunteered to go have wontons with me. In my mind I knew that head-on shrimp were not going to go over well with him but the craving wants what the craving wants. That being said, Yuet Lee will reside on a special list of meals that we've endured throughout the years. There was the beef noodle soup out in the Sunset that was dominated by plentiful chunks of all manner of offal, the other beef noodle soup that had what I found to be wonderfully gelatinous (two words that do not go together in a whitie world) beef tendons, the various strands of jellyfish and delightfully cartilaginous chicken feet, tripitas tacos, fish heads, etc. These special meals all have the common factor of some tasty little morsel that I relish; unfortunately these are the same bits that the manfriend finds completely inedible and an utter mystery as to why anyone would think of eating them.

We sensed the impending dining tragedy as we sat down and went over the menu. The subject of chicken chow mein was broached and my hackles were raised. One might as well be ordering sweet and sour pork, fried rice, and some fried wontons. EEK! In the end, he settled on kung pao shrimp (not the most authentic dish, but I thought it would be better than a meal of chow mein), I went for salt and pepper prawns, and we split some wonton noodle soup. The wontons themselves were very flavorful (hello msg) but the broth was bland. Luckily the small saucer of fresh jalapenos and soy sauce added some flavor to the broth. Kung pao shrimp were coated in a gloppy reddish brown sauce that tasted like sweet and sour take out from the steam table. I was shocked when we got the bill and saw that this horrifying rendition weighed in at $11.50. That is when the manfriend pointed out that while the chicken chow mein may not have been a specialty of Yuet Lee, it would have been a much cheaper mistake. Point taken. 

The salt and pepper shrimp ($15) were well fried but were not the best version that I've had. I prefer a lot more in the heat department and more chili slices as a garnish. However, they were a tasty albeit expensive lunch for me. The concept of eating shrimp peels, heads, eyes, etc and the fact that these guys still had their vein intact did not sit well with my dining companion. As I was trying to convince him to stick with seafood, he pointed out that most of the crabs, lobsters, and a few of the fish in the tanks weren't looking so good. Koi Palace this was not. 

I begrudgingly said that we could get him a slice of pizza or a sandwich later and we both added it to our special bitter meals (aka excursions into Chinese cuisine) list. I foresee a solo meal of salt and pepper squid in my future.
author: Candice L.

description: Finding a good place to eat in Chinatown is pretty hard but after living in Nob Hill for 3 years I found this late night treat to be one of the best.
author: Noelle M.

description: Quick, cheap Chinese served up without attitude. I like that.
author: Jason R.

description:
I went here once, around 1am on a Saturday night, and when I got home, I was deathly ill.  I ate this HK style chow mein dish (the one that is crispy with bok choy, chasiu, seafood, and other stuff), so something in there was the culprit. 

Like the other reviewers said this place is popular because of its location and its late hours. When it gets crowded at night, they might ask you to share tables with another couple/group.
author: Cary W.

description:
Grease, anyone?  How about MSG?

The menu touts the food as "flavorful without being greasy."  I got the seafood lo mein and I could not BELIEVE how greasy it was!!!  Terrible.  With tip and all, it was $14.  The dish came to 10.25, actually, and with tax, 11.20.  But WOW, it was VERY greasy.  Also, I got a headache afterwards that suggests to me there was MSG in the food.
