It was very salty and had this addictive sort of overtone-taste that might be my imagination but I THINK I can recognize it as MSG.  Anyway, the food is EXTREMELY GREASY!

What I love about the place is that they don't play music, and it's not crowded or loud.  Also, it's weird in there, surreal, I mean.  But honestly, if the food is that greasy and salty, I can't ever go there.
author: james b.

description: These reviews really make me scratch my head.  We were wandering down the street, on our way to some infamous tourist trap restaurant in Chinatown that had a line out the door, when someone saw our "no-way-are-we-waiting-for-that" faces and told us this place is the best around. Huh? It was dirty looking  - probably not actually dirty - the servers really seemed to rush us, and the food was nothing special. In fact, I preferred the box of cheez its I resorted to later that night.  I've had better Chinese food in Trenton, which says A LOT.
author: Meg L.

description:
this place came recommended to me by a few old-timers in the neighborhood.  i was not disappointed one bit.  i had the dumpling soup, steamed crab, pork & tofu clay pot, pork w/ Chinese veg. and a prawn dish.  i really dug everything.  and the service was excellent.  i'd heard some stories about the poor service, but i had no such experience.  

when i go out to eat, i'm not very concerned with ambiance.  i don't mind funkiness, as long as it's strictly atmospheric.  

you want good chinese seafood?  give this place a try.  you want atmosphere and your ass kissed?  maybe this ain't your place.
author: Nathan Z.

description: Overhyped, overpriced, and underportioned Chinese food - especially so considering the hole in the wall atmosphere you're subjected to.  It's your classic ghetto asian restaurant, replete with sticky tables and chairs only you're pay an extreme premium.  The food was decent, but certainly far from spectacular.  We should have known by the patrons, the type of restaurant this is - a pure tourist trap.  If I wanted to blow $75 on dinner for 3, I'll gladly drop it more comfortably at R & G Lounge .  2 stars only because the food saves the review.
author: Dennis Y.

description: Yuet Lee has been around for a long while now, but it only a few months ago that I had a chance to sample the food here.  The bright green exterior goes well with the well-lit interior.  It seems to draw people in...only it's usually tourist or the late-nite party goers.  I'm sure the locals are all somewhere else...down the block.  Aside from that, the food at Yuet Lee is really good, however portions and price are suck.  We ordered some clams in black bean sauce, some Chinese broccoli, and a ginger/scallion crab...it was over $40 from what I recall.  The plates are small and the prices are for the tourist.  What ever happened to cheap Chinese eats?  Oh, it's down the block.
author: JeFF T.

description:
our family has been visiting this corner restaurant for over 37 years.
we normally order tripe, steam fish with black bean sauce, steamed clams.  simply - they are the best.  the food comes hot and very quickly - always perfectly prepared.  the atmosphere is genuine - no pretense - no need for fancy clothes - no fancy service.  the best time to come here is after 11 pm.  the variety of people coming through the door represents the variety of nationalities in san francisco.  i just love hearing many languages within a short distance.
author: ed f.

description: Don't go here if you expect five star service, it's a Chinese restaurant in China town.  I think the food is great any time of day, drunk or sober.  The seafood is fresh and you can't beat the beef with scrambled eggs.  Mmmm, mmm.
author: Mitra W.

description:
I wanna say something to the people who are saying "Oh this restaurant is DIRTY, the bathroom STINKS" etc because what I wanna say is "Don't expect the waiters to be so-called friendly with lots of stupid jokes in Chinatown".  I go to Yuet Lee only to eat to satisfy my taste buds.  

Although it does not look very hygienic in this restaurant, usually Chinese cuisine is known to cook food completely so you won't get sick, you know that they don't serve sashimi here.  

And my friend from Hong Kong agreed with me completely about food - their seafood dishes like oyster shells (their specialty) or crab cooked with ginger and peppers - these dishes coming out from their woks are absolutely great food in this city.  

Again, if you care about such things like service, stay away from Yuet Lee.  If you are true food lovers, then go ahead and have one dish that may not be too expensive for you.  You will want to come back here.

There are a few things I don't recommend though.  Soup noodles here are very plain and I don't personally enjoy them.  Besides them, almost everything is great.
author: T T.

description: Salt and pepper calamari.. dip it in the jalapeno soy and enjoy. When your eating here, your either drunk.. or very drunk. This late night staple is the place to be for above average Chinese food late night. Your not going to get super service.. hell, your lucky you don't get a thumb in your soup.. but overall.. cant beat this place for late night carb and grease intake after a night of debauchery.
author: Alan N.

description: A friend from san Francisco took us here and we loved it.  The 6 of us had salt & pepper squid x 2, wanton soup, chicken noodle soup, kung pow shrimp, shrimp fried rice, chow mien, a couple of chinese beers, and a side of white rice.  It was all very good and with the tip came to about $100.  I hated having to share the squid and loved everything.  The fried rice was very good and the wantons had shrimp inside.  It was authentic and delicious.  We would definitely go back.
author: Joe P.

description: My favorite Chinese restaurant...right on Broadway. Try their seafood for sure.
author: Ringo L.

description: No atmosphere, open until 3 am. The fish dishes are excellent - fish in black bean sauce, salt and pepper squid, fresh crab. Ask the waiters if what you are ordering is good. They will tell you the truth. Cash only. Closed Tuesdays.
author: Vena V.

description: Great late night grub after the bars close... I always come with a group and it's generally $15 a head so it's more expensive than a burrito but worth the price at 2:30am!
author: Thel D.

description: This place is great.  Personally, my fiancée and I loves this place. The service is quick and terse, but the food is to die for.  Especially those that enjoys great, homey Chinese food.  Be sure to ask for food that are not your typical Chinese food. You will not regret it.
author: Jason H.

description:
i found out recently that my mom used to make my dad go to yuet lee to buy her wonton soup when she was preggers with me and had cravings. which means i was consuming this place's food since BEFORE I WAS BORN. little did she know that 22 years later i would stumble into the same restaurant after a drunken night out, not knowing that in a way, i was returning to my roots...

anyway, the restaurant. the food here is great, they have tons of variety, (almost) any chinese dish you can think of, they have it, and it's of good quality, very cheap, and big portions... although it could be considered a little greasy... but it's all part of the sacrifices that must be made for amazing chinese food.
author: Jessica W.

description: If you are looking for late night dining than nothing compares.  The food ain't healthy, but there's no better Chinese food at 2AM.  I think some people crave sweets and some people crave salty foods.  I'm the latter and that's why it's always the salted fish chicken fried rice for me.  It's not for the faint at heart, but if you've had enough beers and you want to try something different and very tasty than give it a shot.
author: Young P.

description:
its good, but not great chinese food.  the fried rice and noodles dishes are good, and some of the clay pot dishes are okay.  avoid the tofu stuffed with fish paste as its very boring.

open late.
author: shaun l.

description: Very old school place and it is always busy. Food is what you expect from a run-of -the-mill Chinatown restaurant; greasy, piping, msg-laced hot plates straight off the wok. Prices are actually not that cheap relative to other Chinatown places but still in the cheap category. Salt and Pepper pork chops were great and super crispy. Opened late night, so beware of drunk people late night. I personally would recommend D&A Lounge for the munchies.
author: Ed L.

description: Mmm. This place is so delicious. I tried my favorite Ong choy with garlic and I was just in heaven the entire time.
author: Paweena P.

description: Hole in the wall restaurant. Their main ingredients are SALT, MSG, and OIL.   Service is bad also.
author: Prescott T.

description: Love this place. Whilst its deceiving from the look/ decor of the restaurant,  the food is highly satisfying. We walked in with no expectation as we never been before, but it was great. Famous for their seafood, we tried the pepis with black bean sauce. Also offered on menu was fried "pigeons", it was just nicely done. As a hotpot, we got the beancurd with anchovy and chicken. Yum. It was a cheap meal too, i think we paid nothing over $40 for a dinner for 2. They open daily until late, and it sure looks like a well established institution right in the heart of chinatown. Conveniently located cnr Broadway / Stockton. Tables are tightly arranged and if you have a small party, sometimes you'd be asked to share a large table with other patrons.
author: Ada W.

description: This place used to be GREAT 10 years ago,. Now it's greasy and bland....I would avoid it.
author: Lala B.

description:
I used to love going to this place because of the cheap and tasty food.  Also, the long hours are great when you are hungry at night.  However, I went in their one time with my girlfriend and we were only in there for a minute and the waiter came up to asking us if we were ready.  I asked for a minute.  He literally gave me a minute and came back.  I said that I will let him know when I have decided.  He started getting pushy and started suggesting a bunch of stuff so that I would hurry up and get the hell out of there.  He got upset when I said to him that we were not ready yet.  So, I turned to my gf and we agreed to walk out of there.  The owner (that fat face guy in the pictures on the wall) said, "That's alright" like as to say, "I don't give a shit about your business...see, look at the line."  I will not go back.

P.S. For real, I saw the cook digging in their nose.  I guess that is for added taste.
author: John L.

description: This place is ALWAYS busy 24-7.  I've eaten here twice in my entire fat life and its not that great.  I will never understand why this place and San Tung are always busy.  My fatty guy will never understand.
author: Fatty A.

description: Best ham dan in town - every thing I've ever had here since I was wee has been yummy, hot and fast (except ham dan)! Tea in brown plastic cups, bright green window frames, cheap wood laminate tables, and lots of frying and boiling action in the kitchen. I love this place, will always love coming here, except on Tuesdays (they're closed)!
author: Holly F.

description: I used to love this place, but on our last visit, the restaurant seemed filled with tourists armed with their guidebooks.  Unfortunately, none of them looked any happier with their meals than we were.   My fish did not taste fresh, and the greens we ordered were overcooked and covered with a gummy sauce.  My husband's chicken was a disaster on a plate.  The dishes are cheap, and mismatched, and our tea was served in tall plastic glasses.  This place just screamed, "Tourist Trap".  I will never go back.
author: Vicki T.

description: Food used to be so good here. Last two time we went there, it sucked. The taste isnt as good as before. I really dont know what changed. Maybe the chef? I would much rather go to other places until i start to see some solid reviews on here.
author: Ernie P.

description: Truely great, truely Chinese food.  It's cheap, fast, and always on point.  It can get crowded, and its completely no frills.  Straight up great chinese food in chinatown.
author: Rachel P.

description: I was told that the crab is the dish to get here, unfortunately we didn't get it.  Instead we got bbq pork won ton, beef chow fun, and chicken kung pao sauce.....I think the food was just ok.  I'm giving it 2 stars although I will go back for the crab so my rating may change on my next visit.  I  do think this place is worth trying again.
author: Gina C.

description:
My good friend and I went to the city after seeing "Glutton for Punishment" on food network to hunt for some good noodle dishes.  Actually we were looking for some real Hong-Kong style homemade noodles like the show...ones you can see being made through the front window.  But no luck...we guessed SF just doesn't have any joints like that.  So we decided to just eat at this place since he saw the reviews on the front of the entrance.  I must say this is probably the best chinese food I have ever had.  We got a seat right away and the service was quick.  Kind of "what do you want and here it is...no bullshit" type of service.  We first ordered the noodle soups (him fishball and me roast duck) which were okay.  My friend actually thought it was ramen soup so he kept saying, "Can't you get this at Foodmax at 10 for a dollar."  It was funny but he was right...so we ended up ordering the Shredded pork with pan fried crispy noodles. Gosh, this was freaking good.  I think that made us change our minds about the place.  Just that dish alone was great.

The only con was the bathroom...I think there were major body fluids on the floor so I had to do some acrobats to use the toilet and not get contaminated.  Otherwise, at the prices, it was pretty good.   I would suggest getting the noodles pan fried and crispy...so delicious!  I had the leftovers earlier and they were extremely good.  Also, the menu is pretty decent...lots of different choices that I usually don't see on a chinese restaurant menu.

I heard they are open late...could be great for drunken nights with your friends or an afternoon lunch.  Someone said there were chinese mobsters downstairs??  I don't think it should be a problem...you're pretty quick to eat and go here.  So no one will hassle you into playing mah jong against your will.
author: I AM L.

description: The food is pretty good but the atmosphere is disastrous.  The last time I was there the staff was chopping raw chicken at a dining table next to me.
author: Brian T.

description: Brought our own liquor for a private feast in the basement. It helps to be friendly with staff. Great seafood, crab legs and oysters were great. Roasted duck was a treat. Open late for a good late run of Chinese food near Broadway.
author: Erik W.

description: Dropped by while walking around Chinatown showing a tourist the local area. We were starving and needed some sustenance, STAT! And we were not disappointed. We ordered some cheap eats: noodles, poridge, and rice plates and they showed up in a flash. I got the pork ribs with black bean and it hit the spot. Maybe I should ask for more spice next time I'm here.
author: R H.

description: Great place and easy to find: It's the neon green place with the searing florescent lights (keeps the drunks from lingering I guess!), at the corner of Broadway and Stockton.  This place specializes in seafood and while the other items are fine, the fresh seafood is really where it excels.  The clams with black bean sauce are great, and the Won Ton soup reminds me that, yes I do like GOOD Won Ton Soup! Open till 3am.
author: Fredricko B.

description: This place is a landmark and if you know what to order you'll be peaslently surprised. The shrimp and eggs are good if tyou ask them to prepare the eggs so that they are not runny.  But ther are millions of dishes to choose from Ramsey would go nuts looking at the menu but hey this is different kind of place.  Got to to go there at least once to expirinece what it's like and I'll tell you one thing I'm going back.
author: James S.

description: The dodgy decor seemed to promise authentic Chinese food. The half-obscured handwritten letter by Emeril Lagasse was another indication. We certainly weren't let down. The Hong Kong noodles (I had roast duck with wonton; friend had braised noodles with ginger and onion) were generally very good, although I did wish the roast duck had less fat and more crisp. We also shared a beef tenderloin stir-fried with black pepper sauce. It was some of the best beef stir-fry I've had in a long time. Servings were very generous.
author: Ethan C.

description: Never disappoints.   But I rarely come before midnight.  Everything is pretty good, especially fresh fish from the tanks, fried rice.  Love the homemade jalapeno peppers in soy sauce condiment.  Salt and pepper squid or prawns is perfect.  Not so sure about the weak hot tea served in plastic water glasses.  Inexpensive and fast.  Cooks and waiters have been here so long they seem like childhood friends.  Sometiems they are in a mood.  Decor and cleanlienss can be sketchy, as with the street outside.   Hands down beats an all night diner for something good and familiar to eat after clubbing or upon return from a cross-counry road trip.
author: Gil S.

description: I love me some clams in black bean sauce at 1:30 am. Their Hong Kong style noodles also kick butt. Go to Hing Lung down Broadway for the porridge. A little fluorescent and bright green.
author: patrick g.

description: Let's just say that I don't come here looking for a four-star dining experience.  I don't come here expecting table service that matches French Laundry, nay, at best Denny's.  Even the cleanliness of this place is at best dodgy.  What I do look for and find everytime at Yuet Lee is fresh striped bass from the tank, steamed with garlic and scallions and a soy dressing.  I also find the sound of a sizzling wok, the sight of gas flames, and the smell of reducing master sauce from Yuet Lee's open kitchen at three in the morning, to be an ethereal experience.
author: Sam R.

description: This is one of the best dives ever, garish green decor and all.  Yes, it's true, the salt & pepper squid is to die for, their roasted duck is succulent, and the Hong Kong style noodles are so yummy.  I go there so much the wait staff knows me and even when they're in a snarky mood they always smile for me.  :)
author: Emily C.

description: As it says on the sign outside, this is a Seafood Restaurant. all other fare is average. Order salt-n-pepper squid, mixed seafood crispy noodle, salted fish and chicken fried rice, and some vegetable. Can't miss.
author: Kevin F.

description: Gotta love this place.. food is good and service is super fast!. One of my top destinations after a night out in the city!. A hole in the wall but always hits the spot!
author: DON G.

description: Heard wonderful things about this spot, always walked by... finally checked it out one night after the bars.  We got seated downstairs, which was kind of hole in the wall-ish.  We ordered many dishes, including fried rice, noodle dishes, a beef and radish dish, etc.  Service was eh, the food was pretty good.  I don't know about coming here sober, but drunk it was extremely lovely.
author: Sarah F.

description: Food is pretty decent but small portions!  Fresh Fish is some what overpriced $25 for a small fish . Its not a bad place but  I can get a better deal elsewhere. I wouldn't mind going back if they charged less or made bigger portions.
author: Sparky W.

description:
Jackie Chen and Samantha Brown were there :) hahahaha
Their Salted Pepper Squid and Pecking Ribs were delicious.
Can't miss the Squid...Their GOOD XD
It also close to a cheap parking lot if you don't feel like finding a meter around.....
Come for early bird for a certain days and you'll get 15% off
author: Angela A.

description: Went late night after being out in North Beach. Fried rice was good. Didn't exactly seem like the cleanest place but I felt great the next day.
author: Mike C.

description:
I came here with my two friends to try their famous salt and pepper squid. We also ordered a seafood soup, ginger pork and oyster clay pot and sauteed pea sprouts. The food is super affordable, nothing we ordered was much more than $10 and service is really fast. Let me warn you though, this restaurant is nothing fancy, it's kind of dirty and you get chipped plates and such but hey man, for $10 a dish (that feeds a few people each) what do you expect? On to the food...
The famed salt and pepper squid were really tasty, the squid tasted fresh, it wasn't greasy and had really nice flavor to it, I'd happily eat another plate of these. The seafood soup was really delicious, the broth was nice, light, clean and clear and it was chock a block full of seafood, oysters, mussels, fresh chunks of white fish and squid. The real star of the night for me was the clay pot, it was delicious, the oysters were succulent and flavorful and their was some kind of really firm fleshed fish in there as well, and I love when clay pots have some green onion in them. The sauce was delicious, really, really savory with good meaty flavor to it. I will definitely order it again. This place is open until three in the morning which is good to know for those late night cravings. I definitely plan on going back and trying their salt and pepper crab.
author: Cathy T.

description:
After reading through the reviews and passing by Yuet Lee one night we made it a point to come by and try it for ourselves. We are definitely coming back for more. We arrived at 11:30am on a Saturday to have lunch before stocking up on food at the markets on Stockton St.  We ordered three dishes, Pepper and Salt Roast Fresh Squids, Deep Fried Oysters and Abalone with Chicken Noodle Soup. The recommendations on the Pepper and Salt Squid are ON THE MARK, the dish is amazing, fresh, delicious, and a big portion. We loved the deep fried oysters too, also huge super fresh. The soup was healthy and soothing, and the noodles were perfect. We threw in some spicy sauce to give it a little kick. We couldn't finish everything so we took our leftover squid and soup to go. The meal was $40 - including two beers and a soda. So really all that amazing seafood and huge bowl of soup for $30 and we had leftovers. 

In terms of decor, who cares if it's bland and not pretty to look at (the bathroom was super clean by the way). We also had great service,  so overall the experience for us was great. The food was amazing and we enjoyed hearing it all cooking away while we watched the passersby from our table next to the window. It was the right way to start a Saturday before hitting the crowded markets on Stockton.
author: D G.

description: "Very traditional, old school chinese food- good, but not at all imaginative or to-die for."
author: Jocelyn L.

description: Loved their chowmein and crab in ginger and black bean sauce !!!
author: Sutanuka L.

description: It's alright. It's not the best, but it's decent. The service is very fast. They don't try to be too friendly but they are not rude either. The wontons are pretty good - handmade. :)
author: Pika C.

description: Best late night Chinese, 'nuff said. My man Yuet is a legend, he's the big guy with the lazy eye. Try the salted fish with chicken fried rice. Word.
author: ed h.

description: It was 2am. I'd met this wonderful new boy some weeks before online. On our second date, we went to a film festival and had the munchies late that night. So, he took me to Yuet Lee. The lime green decor & diner feel of the place reminded me of some other late night eating excursion in NYC's East Village or in [fill in your choice of the many fine NJ diner establishments here]. I don't remember what we ate, but it was all good! Little did I know that this place was a litmus test of my coolness. It's been seven years, so I guess I passed. Of course, we've gone back, but not enough times. Can't get enough of those naughty Peking spare ribs! Mmm... spare ribs.
author: G Z.

description: I have been to this joint many times in the past.  The food is OK in my opinion.  I don't understand why many people are so crazy about the food at this place.  I was there last Friday for a friend's birthday dinner.  We had about 18 people so we had to go down to the basement for our birthday dinner.  The moment I walked downstairs, I thought I was going to faint.  It smelt so bad...  I didn't know what the smell was, but it was gross.  The floor was sticky.  After we ordered our food, I saw a cockroach running around the wall behind where my friends sat.  That gave me goosebumps.  On the bright side, at least the cockroach was not flying...  Anyway, long story short, I don't think I will ever go back again...  By the way, despite the nasty eating environment, my stomach was fine...
author: Michelle H.

description: Easily the best Barbeque Pork Chow Mein I have ever tried. It's this weird, garishly green restaurant in Chinatown, but the food is excellent and cheap. I was slightly beyond sober when I ate there, but I would definitely go back any time.
author: Michael E.

description: I love the fact that its open late. Sometimes I we order things that are very good, and other times not so much. The service is usually alright or pretty good. No complaints.
author: Elaine H.

description: This is my go-to Chinese restaurant. The clams in black bean sauce and fish fillet with asparagus in black bean sauce are really good. If you wanna take it easy, the rice plates and chow mein are delicious, too. Very highly recommended.
author: Steve C.

description: One of the late-night haunts I always go back to, especially after a long night at Vesuvios.  The food is incredible, inexpensive, and Peter (always our waiter for some reason) isn't the least bit surly, even though we have frequently given him cause to be.  All the ambiance of a flourescent-lit high-school cafeteria with aquariums, but very, VERY worth the trip. Yes, the outside sign is atomic-lime green, but at least you can't miss it. Try the salt-and-pepper squid -- I'm assured by friends who like food with tentacles that it's the best around.
author: Jude F.

description: I don't get it, I'm not sure why this restaurant is so popular.  Maybe it's what I ordered (ordinary, greasy, below average chicken fried rice)?  I would give it another try, but I really don't get it.
author: Debbie Y.

description: 3.5 stars really. I don't think I've ever been here for a proper dinner. When I have been here, it's been after a night of clubbing. It's one of the few places open late, til 3AM, and if you want an alternative to diner food (Mel's, Video Diner, Sparky's, etc), the Chinese food here and at New Sun HK here hits the spot. A jook joint for you after you've gotten your jive on. Try the steamed fresh flounder, the Maine lobster, the Dungeness crab, the vegetable dishes, and the crispy-style Hong Kong chow mein. And of course, the jook (zhou in Mandarin). The pidan is good. And yeah, the ham dan (salty egg) is not bad. "Yuet Lee"'s name, "Yue4 li4" in Mandarin, means "Joyous Advantage".
author: Hao L.

description: Ok... the food here is just ok. It may be good if you're drunk after clubbing. It's a DIRTY Chinese Joint. They messed up on our bill and expected us to pay additional for tip. Tipping is up to the customers discretion not what the restaurant tell you. Over all we had a bad experience there and most likely wont be coming back.
author: Ani W.

description: They make gristle glisten. One of your best late night eats options
author: Jean W.

description: Good food, very reasonaably priced and the staff are alwys really lovely.  Chicken with cashews always good, though was disappoined with roasted duck the other night.  There was no duck, only duck fat and skin.  Waste of 10 bucks.
author: Carrie A.

description: Good for 2am after clubbin when nothing else is open (including new sung hong kong)
author: Will M.

description: Four or five years ago, this joint was THE best place in Chinatown to grab excellent food at reasonable prices. But, things went downhill from then, and I can no longer recommend this place to anyone -- unless you're drunk, in or around Chinatown or North Beach, and need a bite to eat on a Saturday midnight.
author: Sunny Y.

description: Great supper place for the late night snack! Great value for the food! My friend knows the owner so we get comped for free soup and sometimes the dishes. They have good steamed egg with shrimps and pork, stirfry noodles, salt and pepper ribs and many other dishes!
author: Yan M.

description:
open late and one of the more authentic Chinese restaurants, as far as well know ones are concerned, this place has a very genuine feel. the food is great and always fresh.

look for the huge green awning.
author: Darrell L.

description: Solid Chinese food!!  Great salt n peeper squid and the fried pig intestines kick ass.  Clams and black bean sauce are killer with a bowl of rice.  Open late and the food seems better at night as opposed to daytime hours.  They serve it up good & fast for this drunk chunk!
author: goldberg d.

description: Great after a late night of partying, especially the beef porridge with green onions.   The boiled chicken with ginger and scallions is *really* good.
author: My N.

description: I don't get how people are saying this place is expensive. I thought this was one of the cheaper group dinners I've had, especially for the amount of food and quality of it. Pretty fun and pretty tasty. Open late. And one of the friendliest wait staff, especially for typical Chinese restaurant standards. I'll be back for sure.
author: Jon N.

description:
hands down one of my favortie if not my favorite chinese restaurant in the city.. the owner a family friend.. not to fluff up the name.. but in true honesty i love this place from a special place in my heart..

when it is cold and rainy out i always come here and order the cilantro and chopped meat congee..food for my soul..

i've never left this place not feeling happy about what i ate..
author: Timothy W.

description:
i used to come here after clubbing with heavy head and red faces. expecting the greasy Chinese food will prevent my hang over tomorrow. and its always work ! 
to be honest with you, i never come here sober. so i don't know how they are during the day :p.. i am pretty sure its taste alright ! 

excellent server and food for supper :)
author: sherly A.

description: Another throw back favorite of mine for simple reasons.  Good family style Chines food.  Open late - I've been here for more than ANY other spot, after the bars close,  and a great location, just off Broadway outside the tunnel and before the drop into North Beach.  I could also add that the element of the fish tanks is always cool with me for dining Chinese.
author: Brad C.

description: Expected it to be good since they have so many Jackie Chan pictures on the wall, seems like he visited a lot. The portion of the food is surprisingly SMALL. Nothing I had was memorable, but it was good enough. and the good thing is that they open 'til 3am! :D
author: Marlis T.

description: One of my favorite restaurant whenever I visit SF. Chinese brocolli with salted fish, Pork Chop Peking Style, Pan Fried Chow Mein, Duck, Chicken Hot Pot with salted fish, Crispy Chitterling, Clams with Black Bean Sauce, Lobster or Crab with ginger and scallion..just to name a few. Their food kicks ASS. Why am I writing this during lunch time?? I'm getting hungry!!!
author: Danny R.

description:
on a food basis, this place probably gets a 1.  it's really not better than your typical mall chinese fast food.  

when you're drunk, it rates like a 4.  personally there's still better drunk food, but it rates a 4 being . . . well a 4 because i always end up here.  i swear 90% of their business is due to late night drunk eating.

so we'll even out at a 2.  i wouldnt ever eat here if i wasnt drunk.  thats my story and i'm stickin to it.
author: Jason J.

description: Open late, salt and pepper squid, delicious whole fish, best Chinese restaurant in the bay area and beyond. Make sure you check out the 8 x 10 of nick cage in a Tide outfit. Only problem is they're closed Tuesdays
author: Sam F.

description: This place was DELISH.  The steamed oysters were gi-normous and drenched in, well, I guess an oyster sauce.  The deep fried pork ribs were also tasty (I bent my rules a bit and had a little piece, yum).  And the fish-stuffed tofu had a pleasant texture though they were a bit less fish-laden than I had anticipated, though still extremely pleasing.  When the parents visit, they're coming here!
author: Deb T.

description:
My family has been going to this restaurant for years and it still looks like 1981 around here -- what with the neon green paint, orange awning, dirty floors, formica with faux wood finish...pretty, it ain't.  But where it lacks in looks, it more than makes up for in the food.  

Do order the salt and pepper squid (the shrimp is just as good but more of a pain since you have to shell the shrimp yourself) with a huge bowl of rice...also good something on the "specials" menu - the steelhead fish with green onions...absolute heaven.

It is cash only (which is a pain) but there is an ATM across the street if you find yourself a little lacking in funds.
author: Hannah H.

description: I've found the menu to be a little hit-or-miss, but this place generally offers good selection and quality.  They do a nice bitter mellon, though the fish prices can be a bit erratic. Bonus for the late night hours.  I've found it a little hit or miss over the years; I tend to love it when I'm drunk, wasn't so crazy about it on the other days I've been there.  Still, you can do A LOT worse in Chinatown, and it beats the crap out of Lucky Penny and Video Cafe for a post boozing grub down.
author: A B.

description: Well, where else can I get clams with black been sauce that is fresh, fast and Yummm at 1AM? Dried and fresh squid. Seafood, guilan, scallops. Happy as a clam y'all. Boy that lime green paint WOKE me up.
author: miriam b.

description:
rice porridge (congee) is the late night dish that I usually order, with the preserved egg and salted pork it is fabulous!!! Add a little hot sauce if you like to spice it up. the price? $4.50!!!
This place is fun to go alone or with a group of friends. Fun, fast and delicious.  This is not fine dining but it is good eats.
author: Bill B.

description: We found this place due to Zagat's - proof that Yelp knows way more about what they are talking about judging from the reviews below.  I think this place is alright -- the wonton soup is delicious but the rest of the food is too greasy (i dunno, is that what Chinese is supposed to be) anyhoo - my bf loves this place so maybe you should check it out...I on the other hand would say "What about Amici's"
author: Margaret C.

description: the place is much better at night after an evening of drinking.  You won't notice the fat and greasiness of the food.  I've been here on a normal weekend afternoon, and realized that the service and quality was not up to par IMO.  However as a late night spot, I'd say its right up there, I think it closes at 2 or 3am.
author: Andrew G.

description: Quick, cheap Chinese served up without attitude. I like that!
author: RugJones

description: I love Chinese food and seafood; I've tried many Chinese restaurants in the USA and in several countries in Europe, Africa and Asia (although not in China yet) and this is one of  the best I've been to. It's not a flamboyant restaurant but the meals are delicious and very affordable. My favorite dish there, among many others, is the oyster and ginger clay pot. They are open until 2:00 a.m. or so.
author: George S.

description: Poor quality, walk down the street to New Sun Hong Kong!
author: Big e.

description:
COCKROACH ALERT!!!!!  I used to go there few times a week because their late night hours and a few of their dishes are quite good...

The food is NOT cheap and each time I go there I am charged a different price for the same dishes that I order, usually a few bucks more than the price on the menu.  Also they will charge you extra for each of the boxes if you want to take it to go.

Okay, back to the COCKROACH.   I was sitting by the window all the way to the back of the restaurant when I saw something fall from the ceiling right above the big round table they have there.  It landed on a Chinaman's jacket.  This ROACH was at least 2 inches and very alive.  

We did not take our leftover home that night.  Just check your food if you go there.
author: janice g.

description: If you hungry after midnight and don't want to eat Frozen food from the freezer? Take a drive to China town where food come alive even after midnight .This place is  a typical hole in the wall Chinese restaurant where you can get good steamed fish ,noodle or fried pork intestine with plum sauce
author: anthony b.

description: If it's two in the morning and you don't want to eat some fried food or cheesy pizza; then Yuet Lee is the place for you. I have to say that the shrimp omelette has to be one of the best dishes ever invented on any menu anywhere. MMMMM. I can't wait until the next time I'm drunk in North Beach after hitting the bars to eat here!
author: Pascal C.

description:
what's good:  
- open late, if you need food after dancing in North Beach
- for those who appreciate accessibility, there are listed menu favorites, a few pictures on the menu, and they give you both forks and chopsticks (even though my dining companion ordered in Chinese)

what's bad:
- Not expensive, but definitely overpriced.  Once I sat down and saw the menu, I was tempted to walk out and go down the street, but my companion really wanted to try the place that Jackie Chan supposedly likes.
- My table only had a few variations of the noodle soups so I can only comment on those.  The bok choy was overcooked.  (My bowl didn't come with any compared to my dining companions.)  The soup was flat, salty, and yelled of MSG.  Waking up in the middle of the night beyond parched confirmed it.  I liked that the won tons had a whole shrimp inside, however I greatly disliked that they were wrapped poorly, with a thick section of slightly undercooked skin on each.  

I would say this restaurant is forgettable, except that I will never forget how bad it was.

Great for:
Trying that restaurant you always pass and wonder how it is, only to find out that it is terrible.  .
author: mindful g.

description:
Are you Kidding?  If you want ambiance, there are a ton of trendy "authentic Chinese" places with the look and the atmosphere and plain, lousy food.  Tim, doesn't need to work on the look of this place.  You do not go to Yuet Lee for ambiance, you go for the jook, or the salt and pepper calamari or the shrimp and scrambled eggs.

I used to be an event planner in the City and put together walking tours with meals in "authentic Chinese" restaurants and I never at at any of them after the first, initial meal.  The closest thing to Yuet Lee's was Chinatown Restaurant back when it was under the old ownership, but that little secret delight is gone now so it's Tim's or nothing.

The kitchen is open so there is no mystery as to how your food is prepared.  You can't say that for a lot of places in the area.  Not only that, but as a chef and caterer, I can tell you the rule of thumb is to eat where the chefs go after work.  And yup...they are all at Timmy's!

Try the jook, pee before you go so you don't have to go to their bathroom and deal with the green.  The food is worth it and THEN SOME!
author: Sandra C.

description: Delicious Chinese Food......From noodles, soup or favorite stir fry this is the place of thousand flavors.  Delicious.....the only thing is don't stare at the nooks and crannies because the place is due for a major clean up and power steam. Otherwise its very good!!!
author: freewill m.

description: good late night chinese food for the buzzin soul, it's fast, simple and delicious.
author: Pickle R.

description: After seeing Avatar we were hungry for something besides stale popcorn so for some late night food and having always seen this place packed we figured this was a good bet. BAD BET. We ordered something absurdly simple to make: Vegetable Chow Mein and Pork spare ribs and rice. To call it "vegetable" is a joke. There were 3 - count em - 3 limp pieces of Bok Choy and a rumour of carrot peelings, perhaps 5 mushrooms, a couple of pieces of greasy tofu and maybe 10 peas in the chow mein. That's it. Utterly pathetic. To make it worse we had asked if it were possible to have the chicken chow mein with extra vegetables and the grumpy a-hole waiter simply said "no we don't do that" and walked away. I mean how tough is that? What a prick. The pork was considerably more generous - 5 pieces of porkette ribs that were maybe 2 inches each on rice with HEY BONUS 4 pieces of bok choy and some gravy. That was it. We were not fussy, demanding or ordering anything complicated. It was not even 11 PM. They charged $8 for the sad excuse for Chow Mein. I have eaten in many, many really great cheap late night Chinese restos and this ain't one of them. Just stickin it to the Quai Loh I guess because we actually asked for something that would have been very simple to do. Whatever. I wouldn't eat here again for anything. This place is a fuckin ripoff.
author: randi v.

description: what? tip is enforced? portion is small btw
author: J L.

description: the salt and pepper squid is the best calamari in town. everything else is good too, but i always order that no matter what.
author: Eddie G.

description: had the salt and pepper squid, beef soup noodles, chinese broccoli, and  peking spare ribs.  pretty tasty.  i always think it's a good sign when a place has good fresh greens, not too greasy.   though in my opinion, this place is inexplicably over-priced--not particularly nice inside so not sure how they justify it.  next time i will get non-touristy dishes.  salt and pepper squid was good for the first 5 bites, but one can only eat so much fried tentacle.
author: cherie y.

description: this is one of those places that i somehow always end up after a late night out.  it's one of the only restaurants still open at like 2am-ish.  the food really isn't that great...they don't even have real ho fun...so don't order that in noodle soup or chow fun.  the food comes out extremely fast though, so i give them that.  so if you want something late at night and quick, this is a good choice...otherwise, don't come here...
author: lucie l.

description:
do you come here for the non-greasy food?  hell no.  do you come here for health food?  hell no.

do you come here for the best late night food experience?  hell yes.  
you'd better get the beef chow fun and the minced beef with parsely "jook."   those are my personal favorites.
author: Kay W.

description: I've been coming to Yuet Lee for 10 years, but hadn't been in quite a while so decided to drop in for a quick bite last night.  I had fond memories of the salt & pepper squid, and also wanted a dish of good, seasonal vegetables.  What arrived at the table were two plates of very poor ingredients, poorly cooked, and terribly over priced.  The $13.50 plate of squid was obviously not fresh - with chewy spots and both undercooked and overcooked pieces.  And how do they get off charging that much?  The asparagus was properly priced at $8.50, but consisted of very large pieces (well overgrown) with lots of browning.  They had absolutely no flavor, save for the strangely gelatinous garlic (buttery?) sauce.  A real let down during asparagus season.  Top this off with two $4.75 bottled Tsingtao beers (way overpriced) and you're left with a $40 bill after tax and tip!  My wife and I left feeling ripped off, like some Fisherman's Wharf tourists, and certainly won't be back.
author: Pedro, aka Burgundy M.

description:
I have never been to a poorly serviced restaurant before. I have experienced bad service before , but this beats them all. I have been to restaurants that are literally holes in the wall, yet they still have good service, and reasonably priced items. 
1. While my group were deciding on what to eat, the waiter comes up to us 3 times to ask if we were ready. The next time, he  said hurry up , because there are other people waiting. That already irritated me , and I wanted to leave, but we were already there.  
2. When my boyfriend asked for some ICE WATER, the waiter leaned next to the sink we were sitting ( where the faucet head was dipping into dirty dishes already ) and got him his tap water, and no ice. DISGUSTING. 
3. The food did come out fairly quick, a few minutes from when we ordered, but it is not worth the money at all. The place is very overpriced for the quality they serve. 
4. i disagree on above average food, I have had better. We ordered a meat dish , and there was barely any meat. We also had scallops which were $20 bucks by the way ( and again there were 5 pieces and a crap load of onions, and bell peppers ) . 

All in all this will be last time going to this place.
author: A D.

description: this joint gets a high rating just for the salt and pepper squid.  i honestly don't remember what anything else tastes like nor do i care cuz i'll go back here again, again and again just for that.  hooray!
author: Swarup B.

description: You really can't miss this place.  It's on the corner of a major intersection and it's painted in Christmas colors.  That's not to say that you might want to steer clear of it anyway.  I stopped by for some noodles and it was pretty disappointing.  The noodles tasted a bit undercooked and the broth almost tasted canned - almost.  A friend had the fried rice and it was greasy and mediocre.  Nothing terribly tasty.  Just big portions for a good price. We had gelato afterwards and this place was so greasy, the ice cream felt light.
author: Raz R.

description: This place saved me from a night of starvation, when you are hungry in the wee hours in the morning. THIS is the place to go. After millions of times at dennys or ihop, i would recommend coming to this place to try something new and different.
author: Shane O.

description: Decent place to go when drunk and only drunk. Service is terrible. Food is Okay. A great place to go if you are there to satisfy your 2am appetite.
author: Simon S.

description: all i know is that I'm always hella faded everytime that i'm in here, it seems to be the only place still open for decent chinese food on the late night after partying..
author: John C.

description: This place is awesome! An old favorite. It is open late so you can definitely come here after the bar. It's bare minimum. No fancy crap but the food, the food kicks ass. Probably some of the best Chinese I have ever had. The Chinese broccoli in oyster sauce is great and any of the noodle dishes. Oh and the salt and pepper squid is really good. Worth checking out at least once if you have never been in my opinion.
author: KATELYNN R.

description: First time eating in China Town.  Loved it.  It was in my city guide book. You would never know the food is as great as it is.  We had the salt and pepper calamari, clams in a black bean sauce and a plate of roasted duck. My favs were the clams and calamari.  Prices are reasonable ($12 per dish) for the portion size.  Its a small place and the food comes out quick.
author: Shanna B.

description: EASILY the FUGLIEST place in town, the food kicks ass IF you know what to order- seriously.  Fish soup w/cilantro, clams with black bean sauce, fresh crab with ginger and scallions, peking spareribs, lobster black bean, salt and pepper squid, scrambled eggs with shrimp!!!!
author: eiming j.

description: You have to know what to and what not to order at Yuet Lee. If you had a bad experience, you no doubt ordered the wrong thing. The salt and pepper squid (ordered "dry") is unbelievable; the beef with ginger and green onions also amazing, and the Hong Kong style noodles is the best ever. Dont order the won ton soup. Dont order anything Szechuan; it is a Cantonese restaurant, folks! I grew up in Asia and eat Chinese all over the world, but Yuet Lee ranks as one of my favourite food experiences of all time.
author: Anne B.

description: I live in Marin County, where there is no late night dining option spare Denny's, so my friend and I drove in to grab some Chinese. I was startled to find when we arrived that my sweet and sour prawns, which were not listed on the menu, were an incredible $15.50. When I got home and opened the box, I found that they'd only filled it halfway. Additionally, the food was terrible; the sauce had no taste. Even the steamed rice was somehow substandard.
author: Chris T.

description: Okay, yeah, this place is a bit pricey for a casual Chinese restaurant but the food is very good.  In fact, it is currently my favorite restaurant in San Francisco.  My usual order is either Hong Kong-style Seafood Pan-Fried Noodles or Chicken and Salt Fish Fried Rice.  Though I don't do it often, this is the ONLY place I order sweet and sour pork .  My order is taken and the food is served piping hot within a reasonable time.  I and/or my party eats, we get our check, pay within a reasonable time and exit.  No fuss.  The wait staff is pleasant considering the amount of drunken patrons that go in after 10pm.  Your mileage may vary but mine has been damn good so far.
author: James D.

description: We had dinner here on the recommendation of a waiter and long time piano player at a North Beach restaurant nearby.  Having been to Hong Kong, I can say this was as authentic a Chinese restaurant as you will find in the US. We had dungeness crab which was pulled live out of the tank in front us and cooked right away.  We also had a big mound of spinach.  Service was quick and efficient.  It's not as friendly as you'll find in your own neighborhood, but they were very helpful, taking plates away as we finished, bringing us finger bowls to clean our hands.  We had dinner early on a Sunday and the place was packed, with a line as we left.  Most of the diners looked like locals.  Live fish is expensive there, so bring your credit card. They even served a live fish which was still wiggling in the net when it was show to a couple sitting across the aisle.  Decor is typical Chinatown, but you come here for the food and quick service, not ambiance.
author: John S.

description: the noodles had a great flavor to them.  the salt and pepper calamari was good but needed better accompaniment than rice.  will go back to try other dishes.  a bit pricey but portions are big so ok.  they rush you in and out when they're busy but thats ok.
author: Yelper S.

description: random eats, clam and black bean sauce was yummy; the seafood soup was a little bland, but clean
author: Peter L.

description: richter food when it's past 1AM and you're looking for drunk eats.  however, nobody would ever accuse this place of being clean, but then again if it's past 1AM and you're at yuet lee, you're too wasted to care.
author: G. H.

description: This place is listed on the tour guides and draws a lot of tourists- way more than local Chinese or locals in general. They are known for their salt and pepper squid that can not be beat they are so addicting. (I also like the squid from Cha Cha Cha's, but they are different.) I like that they don't use msg on most of their food- you can also request it to make sure they don't add it, if possible. But, there is soooo much more. When I want home cooking, I come here. I love their broth - it's seasonal and often contain Chinese herbs - when I visit, I must have it as I consider it my medicine for the week. Another fantastic dish is their steamed oysters on the half shell - very impressive as well. Those oysters are local and are so big, they look like they're on steroids. They are yummy and oh so Cantonese. Some drawbacks - the horrible green color (just don't stare at it), it can be cold and there could be a wait for seats. But, it's not enough to keep me away from the food. They are closed on Tuesdays, so beware.
author: kim y.

description: Yuet Lee is located on the North side of Broadway on the edge of Chinatown and North Beach.  It's a very good destination if you enjoy seafood.  While there are other good Chinese places in the neighborhood, it's the seafood that sets Yuet Lee apart.  Also the place is also open late which is another plus.  If you go with the crab, the mussels, and the other sea foods you won't go wrong.  Not that you'd go wrong with anything else on the menu. If you're just a chow mein, lo mein,  or fried rice kinda Chinese restaurant aficionado then perhaps this place is not for you as you can get cheaper dishes elsewhere.  In season, the sea bass is incredible.  The duck, in particular, is also mouth watering as well as is the salt and pepper shrimp.  Others have said that this dish is salty, HELLO..it's salt and pepper shrimp.  They do serve other delicacies such as frogs legs and that dish is very good. They aways serve a little  bowl of chiles in sause that adds a tasty touch.  The place isn't fancy by any means but I've been upstairs and in the dining room downstairs many times and I have yet to see anything that won't make me come back.  Parking in the neighborhood during certain hours can be challenging.  I suggest parking above the Central Police Station and walk the block and a half.  Yuet Lee is a very good restaurant if you get the urge for a fish dish late at night and I highly recommend it.
author: Nick C.
